Bernstein, once a heavy smoker, last conducted on Aug. 19 at the Boston Symphony's summer home at Tanglewood, Mass. ``In the past few days, the words from one of his Broadway songs has been going through my head: `Just when the fun is starting, comes the time for parting,' '' said composer Ned Rorem, quoting from ``We'll Catch Up Some Other Time'' from ``On the Town.'' ``Broadway compositions often eclipsed his most important music, his symphonies and chamber music,'' Rorem added. ``If he had specialized, he would have been so frustrated as to be impotent.'' In 1958 Bernstein became the first American-born director of the New York Philharmonic. He stepped down in 1969 to devote more time to composition. ``He was the New York Philharmonic in its spirit and very essence and we're going to miss him like crazy,'' said Nick Webster, Philharmonic director. ``His greatest influence was as a performer,'' said composer-conductor Leon Kirchner, emeritus professor at Harvard. ``There were simply hundreds of kids who went to Tanglewood. He had a very profound sense of musical structure, of the marvelous meanings of musical symbols. He was able to translate them make them intelligible to young people.'' Pianist Jerome Lowenthal, who had played Bernstein's ``Age of Anxiety'' with Bernstein conducting, said: ``Bernstein related to this music. He was a very tortured man and you just had to have a word with him to know that, and at the same time he managed to be embarrassingly charming. ... His success just exacerbated the torture. He suffered from the pressures of superstardom.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Reaction to Nobel Peace Prize
DOC.TEXT: Following are excerpts of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reaction to being selected Monday for the Nobel Peace Prize. He spoke in an interview with Soviet television and several foreign TV stations, and his remarks were translated from Russian by The Associated Press: --- The first thing I'd like to say is to confirm the news. It's quite true. I was just now receiving the ambassador of Norway and he informed me about the decision of the Nobel Committee about awarding the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize and that this decision, as he said, had a definite motivation ... Well, what shall I say? Words fail one at such moments. I am moved. Nevertheless, I'll try to do it. First of all, I am deeply touched as a person, moved by this decision. I perceive this action of the most authoritative organization of the global community first of all not in personal terms, but as recognition of the significance of the immense cause of perestroika for the destiny of the entire world. I think that was what was crucial for the final decision in that committee, which is so serious as we know. They always take sound decisions. ... Secondly, when we were starting our perestroika we thought and above all we wanted at that time to be understood correctly, to be understood above all in the sense that we ourselves need perestroika. We came to the conclusion that we could not continue to live as we had lived, that we needed deep transformations in all spheres of life, and that it was the will of the people ... to develop our policies and to act. But even then we wanted to be understood correctly, in that what we were going to do would have vast significance for all countries, for the entire world because it was happening in such a huge country as the Soviet Union, which plays a great role and bears on its shoulders a great responsibility to the world community.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 12 Injured in Highway Crash
DOC.TEXT: A series of chain-reaction accidents involving more than 20 cars, including one carrying ammunition, slammed into each other today on a smoky, fog-shrouded highway. At least a dozen people were injured, police said. Bullets exploded when the car carrying ammunition caught fire, state police said. ``It was no major thing, no big explosion, just some rounds popping off,'' said Sgt. Joe Lentini. No one was injured by the bullets, but emergency workers said at least 12 to 15 people hurt in the chain-reaction crash shortly before 8 a.m. were taken to a hospital near New Orleans. ``I don't know how many. We transported so many I quit counting,'' said David Bell, an ambulance worker. Cars, pickups and larger trucks littered a mile-long stretch of the Lafitte-Larose highway about five miles south of New Orleans. The fog was so thick state police cars crept toward the scene with two troopers walking in front of the cars to guide them, Lentini said. State Trooper Ernest Dykes said smoke from marsh fires apparently set by deer hunters contributed to the hazard posed by the fog. ``It was foggy but what made it so bad is the hunters are burning the marsh. They do that to make the deer move out so they can shoot them. It was real thick,'' complained David Dumestre, an emergency medical worker. Dykes said the practice is illegal but some hunters burn the marshes anyway. Visibility was so bad, Dykes said, that he could feel the heat from the burning car containing the ammunition, but couldn't see it from 20 feet away.

DOC.HEAD: Ambassador Says Israelis Have No Need to Fear United Germany
DOC.TEXT: United Germany's first ambassador to the Jewish state presented his credentials to the president today and assured Israelis they had nothing to fear from Germany's unification. Otto von der Gablentz, 60, was the first ambassador accredited to a foreign country since unification Oct. 3, German officials said. Von der Gablentz said that his country would never forget the Holocaust, nor Germany's historic responsibility to the Jewish people. Israelis have expressed concern that a unified Germany would dominate Europe and forget its responsibility for the Jewish people over the Holocaust, in which 6 million Jews were killed. ``Israel has no reason to be sad about the disappearance of East Germany. It has good reasons to trust the feeling of responsibilty which we have felt in Germany for our past,'' he said on Israel radio. ``I have deep respect for the feelings of Israelis,'' he said, adding the Nazi horrors of World War II would be remembered in a united Germany. President Chaim Herzog, who received the new ambassador at his residence in Jerusalem, said that he was not sorry that East Germany had ceased to exist. ``I cannot mourn the disappearance of East Germany, which was a hostile nation toward Israel, which was a center for the Palestine Liberation Organization and a center for terror in Europe against Israel and other nations,'' Herzog said. Before German unification, West Germany was a valuable ally of Israel, often defending the Jewish state in the international arena. It paid more than $40 billion in reparations to Israel and Holocaust victims around the world.

DOC.SECOND: BC-Doctors For Sale III, Bjt - 1st Add,0170
DOC.HEAD: DERRY, N.H.: of Ohio.
DOC.TEXT: Dr. John Gibbs, the hospital's director of medical affairs, acknowledged finances played a role in the decision to change surgeons. ``Most of his (Montesinos') patients weren't covered under the DRGs,'' he said. ``The resource utilization was high - the amount of (blood) pump time, a lot of X-rays, and the resources of the hospital.'' Hospitals now must go to considerable lengths to get rid of financially rebellious doctors, but some fear it soon will become much easier. Some medical consultants and attorneys suggest rewriting hospital bylaws to permit ``financial credentialing.'' This would allow review committees to consider doctors' economic profiles, including the profitability of their patients, when deciding whethr to allow them to admit patients. Others worry doctors will shortchange their patients if they are forced to put the hospitals' interests first. Said the AMA's Lang: ``When you base medical staff privileges on economic criteria unrelated to quality, you are setting up a situation where the patient can be harmed.''

DOC.HEAD: Garbo Collection Expected to Net Millions at Auction
DOC.TEXT: The art collection of Hollywood legend Greta Garbo is expected to raise around $24 million when it comes up for auction in London and New York next month. The main part of the Swedish-born star's collection, including three Renoir paintings and one by Pierre Bonnard, come under the hammer at Sotheby's in New York in November. The second part will be sold at their London auction house in December. The top item for sale is Renoir's ``Leontine Et Coco,'' painted in 1909, which is expected to fetch up to $9 million. Garbo, who died in April at the age of 84, conquered Hollywood between the wars and then rejected the film industry after making ``Two Faced Woman'' in 1941. She became a mysterious recluse, but continued to collect art, antiques and furniture and her New York apartment became an Aladdin's cave of treasures. She left her entire fortune to her niece, Gray Reisfield, who she described as ``my dearest living relative'' and who will receive all proceeds from the auction.
