DOC.HEAD: Soviets' Pride in Gorbachev Is Mixed With Anger Over Economy
With AM-Nobel-Peace, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet citizens rushing from store to store Monday seeking food, clothes and other essentials expressed as much anger as pride over Mikhail S. Gorbachev, winner of this year's Nobel Peace Prize. ``For worldpeace and disarmament, he has done an awful lot. But for his own people, he hasn't done much,'' said Bela, 53, a subway rider who declined to give her last name. ``Around the world, he's popular, of course. But here, he's not,'' she added, gesturing at grim-faced passengers carrying half-full shopping bags. Most of the 15 Soviets interviewed in Moscow streets, markets, subways and apartment buildings praised Gorbachev for his role in raising the Iron Curtain and ending the Cold War. But they expressed anger over his domestic policies, which they blamed for ethnic violence, inflation and shortages of staples ranging from gasoline to instant coffee. ``I don't know much about politics, but what I see in the stores, I hold the government responsible for,'' said Lyova Likacheva, a 35-year-old factory worker. ``And what I see in the stores is nothing - they're empty.'' Gorbachev told television reporters the prize would help ``on an emotional and intellectual level'' to raise support for his economic reforms. But many of the Soviets interviewed said they believed he had received the award solely for his foreign policy. The Nobel Committee said his role in international affairs was the main reason for the prize, but also praised him for promoting ``greater openness'' in the Soviet Union. The news that Gorbachev had won the prize spread quickly through the city and seemed to take most people by surprise. There had been virtually no speculation in the Soviet press about Gorbachev's possible receipt of the $700,000-award. Arkady I. Sokolov, a 62-year-old machinist, was one of the few people interviewed who smiled broadly on hearing that Gorbachev was the first Soviet to win the peace prize since dissident physicist Andrei Sakharov in 1975. ``He deserves it,'' Sokolov said. ``Armaments are being reduced everywhere, that's the main thing. ... Of course, I'm proud of him.'' Andrei Tatishchev, 23, said he felt no such pride. ``In international affairs, I think he's done everything right. It's domestically that there is disorder,'' Tatishchev said. ``I would be proud of him if he put things in this country in order. What happens there, outside our borders, doesn't interest me very much as an ordinary Russian person.'' Lena Somochkina, 17, and her classmate, Tanya Fokina, said they thought Gorbachev deserved the award for reducing the chances of nuclear war, allowing freedom of speech and encouraging reform throughout the East bloc. ``He somehow turned our government around completely,'' Somochkina said. ``We used to live behind an Iron Curtain. ... If Gorbachev hadn't come to power, who knows whether there would have been reforms in Eastern Europe?'' The ``only thing'' that Gorbachev ``has maybe done wrong,'' Fokina added, was to undertake hesitant economic reforms that have led to near chaos. And for that, she mostly blamed his aides and government bureaucrats. ``I think they haven't let him - the people around him in the government haven't given him the freedom - to do what he wants,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Wildlife Activist's Office Is Habitat For New Insect Species
DOC.TEXT: The president of the World Wildlife Fund, Kathryn S. Fuller, has ants in her plants. So do lots of people. But the insects Fuller noticed crawling across her desk last year apparently are a brand-new species, never before seen by ant experts. This means scientists at the fund, which is dedicated to preserving wildlife and its habitat around the globe, have a new task right in their own Washington headquarters - making sure the ants survive. The story began when E.O. Wilson, a zoology professor at Harvard University and a leading authority on ants, visited Fuller's office. Wilson, a World Wildlife Fund board member, had just completed an exhaustive work entitled, ``The Ants.'' Fuller asked Wilson to check out her ants. ``Ed's eyebrows just shot up when he saw them,'' Fuller says. ``He immediately identified the ants as members of the genus Pheidole, a neotropical group on which he has specialized. We traced the ants to their colony in a potted plant behind my desk.'' The two collected some worker ants in a vial so Wilson could study them in his lab. Later he asked that some soldier ants be collected and sent to him at Harvard to aid in species identification. ``This is a very surprising find and certainly distinctive,'' Wilson said in a statement issued Monday by the fund. If the preliminary results are confirmed by final taxonomic tests, WWF officials said, the new species could wind up being called ``Fuller's Ant.'' ``I will feel a very personal sense of responsibility for these ants, whether or not they're named after me,'' the fund president said. The potted plant where the ants live was a palm tree, identified by World Wildlife Fund botanists as a Draceana reflexa. The ant colony could have come with the palm from Florida, or possibly was imported with another plant and migrated to the Draceana in Fuller's office. On advice from Wilson, Fuller is feeding the ants sugar water and apple cores, along with cheese, cookies and an occasional Danish. Fund botanists have added to the planter with the host palm tree some neotropical flora that secrete a substance harvested by similar ants in the wild. ``I'm telling people 'm creating a complete tropical ecosystem in here,'' Fuller said. ``It shows you how little is known about diversity in the world, how many species are unknown.'' The World Wildlife Fund describes itself as the largest private conservation organization, with projects in more than 140 countries to protect wildlife and its habitat. So its leaders are determined to save the ants. ``I've given the plant company strict instructions not to touch my plant,'' Fuller said. ``The caretaker told me most of his clients want their plants ant-free. I was the first person to ever tell him to leave the ants alone.''

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Gov't Criticizes Reported U.S. Pressure On Dancers
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed government has criticized what it calls an attempt by the U.S. State Department to pressure Cambodian dancers to defect during their U.S. tour. Four members of the 36-member classical dance troupe have defected during the tour. The troupe was to complete its performances in New York Sunday to end the tour, the first cultural exchange between the United States and Cambodia since the Vietnam War. The State Department says it plans to interview all the dancers to determine if they really want to return home. ``We regret this action of the U.S. Department of State, which is a form of political pressure to serve a political goal,'' said a Foreign Ministry statement carried by the Cambodian broadcast. ``We would like to stress that these dancers, like other Cambodian people, are free to choose their domiciles without pressure from any foreign government,'' the statement said. A transcript of Sunday's broadcast was seen in Bangkok Monday. The Communist Cambodian government was installed by a Vietnamese invasion in late 1978. Citizens are not free to travel; more than 300,000 refugees are in U.N. camps just inside the Thai border. In a statement last week, the Bangkok office of resistance leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk said the defections of the dancers ``symbolized the unpopularity and the lack of freedom and democracy in this Vietnamese tank-installed regime.''

DOC.HEAD: Precede WASHINGTON
Bush Warns Saddam of Consequences of `Atrocities'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Bush warning Saddam against atrocities; comments on budget and Texas GOP candidate. Picks up 9th graf pvs `At least ...'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today warned Saddam Hussein that Iraqi atrocities in Kuwait could lead to trials similar to those held after World War II. ``Hitler revisited,'' Bush said of Iraqi actions. ``But remember, when Hitler's war ended there were the Nuremberg trials. Every day now, new word filters out about the ghastly atrocities perpetrated by Saddam's forces,'' he said. The president's remarks came at a fund-raising luncheon for businessman Clayton Williams, the Republican candidate for governor of Texas. ``His victory will be a triumph for the old-fashioned virtues that made this state what it is,'' Bush said about Williams. Williams is the front-runner in the race against Democrat Ann Richards. Republican Gov. William Clements is not running for re-election. The president also will be stumping for candidates in Nebraska, Iowa, Illinois and Michigan during the two-day political trip. Bush mixed high praise for Williams with an attack on Congress for not coming up with a budget bill to his liking. ``Thirty-seven times in the last 10 years, Congress has missed its own budget deadline,'' Bush said. ``This Friday time's up.'' With that, the president hinted he would not sign another continuing resolution that would keep the government operating in the absence of a budget agreement. By the end of this week, the president and Congress must come up with $500 billion in spending cuts and tax increases to reduce the federal deficit over the next five years. In the race for governor of Texas, one of the states Bush calls home, Williams has spent at least $16 million, including $7.5 million since March. Richards has spent at least $9.4 million, including $5.7 million since March. At least $6 million of the total Williams has spent has been his own money. An independent poll made public late last week said Williams was leading Richards by 51 percent to 40 percent. Why bother going to Texas? ``It's the president's home state and it plays a major role in presidential politics,'' said Michele Davis, executive director of the Republican Governors' Association. ``Once the dust clears after the election, everybody wants to be able to point to Texas and be able to say they played a role in a big win.'' The nasty tone of the Texas race was demonstrated last week when the two rivals had a rare joint appearance and Williams used to the occasion to say, ``I'm here to call you a liar today. ... You've lied about me.'' Williams was angered that Richards had questioned his relationship with a Houston loan broker under investigation by the FBI for alleged money-laundering. Williams was in the best shape of the candidates Bush was trying to help. In Nebraska, Republican Gov. Kay Orr was trailing her Democratic challenger, businessman Ben Nelson. The most recent survey done for the Omaha World-Herald said Nelson led Mrs. Orr by 8 percentage points - 44 percent to 36 percent. The first Republican woman elected governor of any state, Mrs. Orr got into trouble when she backed a tax increase after pledging throughout her campaign to hold the line against new taxes. ``She had to apologize,'' said Davis, who insisted that Mrs. Orr has ``been able to prove that taxes are down'' since she took office and that Nebraska now has the nation's lowest unemployment rate. Davis said Nelson had outspent Orr 2-1 on television. Also benefiting from the presidential visit to Nebraska were former congressman Hal Daub, who is challenging Democratic Sen. James Exon, and Ally Milder, who is challenging Democratic Rep. Peter Hoagland. In Iowa, Bush plans to campaign Tuesday for GOP Gov. Terry Branstad and Rep. Tom Tauke, who is challenging Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin. Bush is visiting Illinois to help gubernatorial candidate Jim Edgar, now secretary of state. His last stop Tuesday is in Grand Rapids, Mich., where the president will campaign for state Sen. John Engler, who is running for governor.

DOC.HEAD: Campaign Battleground in the Courtroom, Not the Countryside
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Larger-than-life campaign posters of ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, her loyalists and political opponents clutter the pristine boulevards of the cities and the bumpy dirt roads to the villages. Colorful party flags flutter atop mud-and-straw huts, modern high-rise buildings, on bicycles, bullock carts and pickup trucks. Loudspeakers blare the slogans of favorite candidates. Despite all the trappings, the campaign for the Oct. 24 parliamentary election lacks the wide public enthusiam that heralded Pakistan's return to democracy two years ago. This election is being fought in the courtroom, not the countryside. When President Ghulam Ishaq Khan ousted Ms. Bhutto on Aug. 6 and called the election three years early, most Pakistanis were pretty fed up with her performance and an ineffective Parliament paralyzed by 20 months of bickering. The caretaker government, made up of former allies with little in common except contempt for Ms. Bhutto, thought it would produce enough evidence to prove she presided over Pakistan's most corrupt and inept government. They boasted she would be forced out of politics for seven years, maybe forever, and the left-leaning Pakistan People's Party founded by her father, the late Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, would be destroyed. Government lawyers crossed the country filing charge after charge against the 37-year-old former prime minister, six former Cabinet ministers and ultimately her husband. But even Ms. Bhutto's strongest critics now privately admit the evidence is questionable and the credibilty of the caretakers - called the ``undertakers'' by Pakistan's Urdu- and English-language press - has been called into doubt. ``We wanted to make her the villian, but instead she's becoming the victim,'' said one government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Now we are on trial and the verdict will be delivered Oct. 24.'' Promises of elections are the threads holding together the delicate fabric of Pakistan's democracy, which unexpectedly returned in 1988 when the military dictator, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, died in a still unexplained plane crash. Pro-government newspapers and state-owned radio and television carry daily reassurances from Ishaq Khan and the powerful army chief of staff, Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, that the polls will be held on time ``come what may'' and that power will be transferred to the choice of the people ``irrespective of who wins.'' But in a country ruled by the military for more than half its 43-year existence, such promises have been broken too many time in the past to inspire confidence. Politicians hurl accusations and insults at each other instead of talking about the real issues that trouble this Moslem country of 110 million people: a soaring birthrate, increasing poverty and rising prices that are putting many of the basic necessities out of reach. ``The politicians certainly aren't capable of running the country,'' said Imran Rafiq Bhatt, a 25-year-old charity worker in the eastern village of Visvian. ``We should give the country to Japan on lease for eight years and maybe they could straighten things out.'' The events surrounding Ms. Bhutto's dismissal and her trials before the special tribunals resurrected from the days of martial law have only served to make Pakistanis more cynical about the future. But analysts say the caretaker government has become Ms. Bhutto's best friend, making her the underdog and helping halt and then reverse her declining popularity and galvanize the disillusioned rank-and-file in her party. Ms. Bhutto, the daughter of wealth and privilege, is cast as the ``poor people's sister,'' the champion of freedom and democracy, the scrappy fighter of political oppression. It is a role she played so well for a decade after her father was overthrown in 1977 military coup and hanged two years later - the daughter of wealth and privilege advocating freedom, democracy and people power. While the caretaker government was busy trying to collect facts and figures in a bureaucratic manner, she criss-crossed the country in a Pajero jeep, inching through the surging, suffocating crowds and appealing to the sentiments of the people, then traveling all night to her next court appearance. Soon the stories of large-scale corruption and mismangement began to fade and sympathy for her grow. ``Her appeal is direct, sentimental and down-to-earth. She still carries the day,'' said political analyst Syed Alamdar Raza. `The coalition in power and her opponents who want to be in power have no one who comes anywhere near her.'' When she was in power and times were good, Ms. Bhutto said in an interview, she occasionally thought about the day when she would give up politics to devote time to her young children, son Bilawal and daughter Bakhtawar. ``Now is not the time to talk or even think about retirement,'' she said during a weeklong campaign swing through eastern Punjab, the country's most prosperous province and home to more than 60 million Pakistanis. Government officials and bureaucrats admit privately they underestimated her drive, her ambition and her steely determination. Even her most bitter opponents calculate she and the People's Party will win about 80 seats in the 217-member National Assembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament that chooses the prime minister. That would fall short of an outright majority but most likely make hers the largest single party.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Winners of Nobel Prizes
With AM-Nobel-Peace, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here is a list of Soviets who have won Nobel prizes:
PHYSICS: 1978 - Pyotr Kapista. 1964 - Nikolai G. Basov, Alexander M. Prochorov. 1962 - Lev D. Landau. 1958 - Igor Y. Tamm. CHEMISTRY: 1956 - Nikolai N. Semenov. MEDICINE: 1904 - Ivan P. Pavlov (pre-revolutionary Russia). LITERATURE: 1987 - Joseph Brodsky (emigrated to U.S.) 1970 - Alexander Solzhenitsyn. 1965 - Mikhail Sholokhov. 1958 - Boris Pasternak. ECONOMICS: 1975 - Leonid Kantarovich. PEACE: 1975 - Andrei Sakharov. 1990 - Mikhail Gorbachev. Sakharov in 1975 was being held in internal Soviet exile for criticism of Soviet policies and forbidden from receiving his award. Pasternak, whose works were banned in the Soviet Union, was forced to decline the prize. His son recently accepted the award posthumously for his father.

DOC.HEAD: FTC Challenges Sales Of Publishing Company
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Trade Commission on Monday challenged R.R. Donnelley & Son Company's acquisition of a smaller publishing-printing partnership, saying it could substantially lessen competition in the high-volume publication field. Donnelley, which has its headquarters in Chicago, bought the Meredith/Burda companies for $570 million in a deal consummated on Sept. 4. The previous week, the U.S. District Court denied the FTC's request for a preliminary injunction blocking the sale. ``We were convinced at the very beginning, when this sale was agreed upon in December 1989, that it did not present legal obstacles,'' said James Ratcliff, Donnelley's vice president for corporate affairs. ``We think we were right on the facts of the law, and that we have a good case, and we will press on.'' The FTC issued an administrative complaint that the acquisition ``created a firm whose share of the market is so high that it has become a dominant firm.'' It said the deal will eliminate competition among other firms in the market. R.R. Donnelly is a printing firm, specializing in high-volume publication gravure printing of the type used for long runs of magazines, newspaper inserts and catalogues. Meredith Corporation, based in Des Moines, is a magazine publisher which also owns seven television stations. It is a partner in printing operations with the Burda family of Germany. ``What Donnelly bought was the printing operations,'' Ratcliff said. ``We are not publishers.'' Included is a magazine printing plant in Des Moines, and catalogue printing plants in Lynchburg, Va., Newton, N.C., and Casa Grande, Ariz. An official in the FTC's Bureau of Competition who asked not to be named said the sale would give Donnelly more than 50 percent of the market in at least one area. The complaint also names Meredith Corp. and Pan Associates, L.P. which each owned 50 percent of Meredith-Burda. A federal judge turned down the FTC's request for a preliminary injunction against the sale on Aug. 27, but the FTC official said the court's ruling was ``just a preliminary assessment of the commission's likelihood of succeeding.'' The new complaint will be heard before an administrative law judge, whose ruling can be appealed to the full commission. If the firms lose both decisions, they can carry the case to a federal court.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Wins 1990 Nobel Peace Prize
LaserPhotos MOSB2, NY101, OSL1, NY18
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev won the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize on Monday for easing international tensions, but claimed it as an endorsement of wrenching changes he has made at home. The Norwegian Nobel Committee said the 59-year-old Soviet leader displayed a ``leading role in the peace process which today characterizes important parts of the international community.'' ``Words fail one at such moments. I am moved,'' Gorbachev said in a television interview. ``I perceive this action of the most authoritative organization of the global community first of all not in personal terms, but as recognition of the significance of the immense cause of perestroika for the destiny of the entire world.'' Gorbachev has been criticized at home because some of his social and economic reforms, called perestroika, have led to bloody ethnic rioting, food shortages, and demands by most Soviet republics for independence. ``We know that there are great problems (in the Soviet Union), but that is not what he got his prize for,'' said Gidske Anderson, leader of the five-person Nobel Committee. ``The big thing that is happening in the world is the reconciliation of the superpowers.'' ``If you will read the text you will see we are talking mainly about international policy,'' she said. The committee's citation said the ``greater openness (Gorbachev) has brought about in Soviet society has also helped promote international trust.'' The committee said Gorbachev had made many contributions to the ``dramatic changes'' in East-West relationships since he came to power in 1985: ``Confrontation has been replaced by negotiations. Old European nation states have regained freedom. The arms race is slowing down and we see a definite and active process in the direction of arms control and disarmament.'' Gorbachev told a Norwegian TV interviewer his reforms were popular outside the Soviet Union because ``the world was ripe for change. ``It had grown tired of the Cold War, the arms race, the hardships resulting from an overload of current problems facing the world community,'' he said. In the past five years, the Soviet Union has agreed to reduce nuclear and conventional armed forces, helped settle regional conflicts in Africa, Asia and Latin America, and withdrawn its forces from Afghanistan. Many world leaders praised the award, but several said they hoped it would lead to even more freedom in the Soviet Union. ``If this prize contributes to the peaceful and quiet transition of the Soviet Union to a society of equal nations and citizens, we welcome it warmly,'' said Vaclav Havel, a former dissident who became Czechoslovakia's president after the Soviet Union eased its grip on the East bloc. Former President Reagan said Gorbachev is ``sincere in his effort to make the world safer'' and ``is dedicated to doing what must be done for the good of his people.'' President Bush called Gorbachev ``a courageous force for peaceful change in the world.'' British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher called the choice ``terrific.'' And French President Francois Mitterrand said Gorbachev was ``the decisive factor in the easing of tensions in the world.'' Some Soviet citizens were less enthusiastic about the honor for Gorbachev. ``I don't know much about politics, but what I see in the stores, I hold the government responsible for,'' said Lyova Likacheva, a 35-year-old Moscow factory worker. ``And what I see in the stores is nothing - they're empty.'' The 71st Peace Prize was the first to a Soviet leader. U.S. presidents Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson won the award in 1906 and 1919 respectively. Gorbachev is the second Soviet nobel peace laureate. Dissident Andrei Sakahorov won the 1975 prize, but was not allowed to accept it until last year. Gorbachev said he would personally accept the award, worth about $700,000, this December in Oslo. The peace prize, first awarded in 1901, was endowed by Alfred Nobel, the Swedish inventor of dynamite. It is always presented in Oslo on the Dec. 10 anniversary of his 1896 death. Nobel endowed four other prizes, in medicine, literature, physics and chemistry, all awarded in Stockholm, Sweden. The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, established by the Central Bank of Sweden in 1968, will be awarded Tuesday. The Nobel physics and chemistry prizes will be awarded Wednesday. Last week, Mexican poet and essayist Octavio Paz won the prize for literature. Two American doctors, Joseph E. Murray and E. Donnall Thomas, won the prize in medicine for pioneering organ and bone marrow transplants.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Iraqi Atrocities Could Lead To Trials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to update with Bush quotes. Picks up 4th graf pvs ``Asked if there... ''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday that Iraqi atrocities in Kuwait could lead to trials similar to those held after World War II, and his defense secretary said U.S. troops will stay in Saudi Arabia as long as needed. Iraq, meanwhile, insisted it would fight rather than withdraw from Kuwait. ``Hitler revisited,'' Bush said in Dallas of Iraqi actions in the tiny emirate that Saddam Hussein's troops seized Aug. 2. ``But remember, when Hitler's war ended there were the Nuremberg trials. Every day now, new word filters out about the ghastly atrocities perpetrated by Saddam's forces,'' Bush said. Earlier Monday, U.S. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney said Americans would stay ``as long as the Saudis want us...as long as it takes to get the job done. No one should underestimate our staying power.'' ``Time is much more likely to be on our side than it is on his side,'' Cheney said, referring to Saddam and the U.S.-led multinational force. Asked if there was the political will in the United States to maintain troops in Saudi Arabia for years, Cheney said: ``There certainly is.'' The defense secretary, who spoke in London as part of a 10-day tour that also will take him to Moscow, said economic sanctions were only just beginning to hurt Iraq. He stressed that America hopes to avoid war. Iraq denied it was softening its stance on the gulf crisis. ``Kuwait is the 19th province of Iraq and this fact will not be changed whatsoever even if we fight a long war for that,'' Information Minister Lafif Nassayif Jassim was quoted as saying. He told reporters in Baghdad Sunday night that he believes a U.S.-led attack is imminent, but that Iraq would not fire the first shot, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. ``We expect the war at any moment and we are ready to fight against the Americans and those who come with them,'' he said. An editorial in Al-Thawra, the newspaper of the ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party, said Iraqis ``are prepared to meet the American troops.'' ``If they start the war, we will make it a catastrophe for those who ignite it,'' the editorial said. ``The destruction will be total.'' Should fighting break out, the statement said, ``All the American interests and those of its allies inside and outside the region will explode, and the fires will eat them at the first hour of their aggression against Iraq.'' The Iraqi statement appeared intended to reassure its citizens and counter reports that Saddam might be wavering in his determination to hold onto Kuwait. Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat met with Saddam on Sunday and said later that the Iraqi president was showing a ``certain flexibility'' regarding his claims to Kuwait. Arafat spoke in Tunis after meeting with the French foreign minister. Diplomatic sources in Baghdad said Arafat is trying to persuade the Iraqis to talk with the French, who suggested Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait might be linked to an Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Saddam said Aug. 12 that he would discuss a withdrawal from Kuwait only if talks also were held on the Palestinian issue. The West Bank and Gaza are home to 1.7 million Palestinians. The official Soviet Novosti press agency said Saddam had indicated to Soviet envoy Yevgeny Primakov that he might remove his troops in exchange for some Kuwaiti territory on the gulf. ``That report is not precise,'' Jassim said of the Novosti dispatch. In other developments Monday: -Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze told Soviet lawmakers the Kremlin has no plans to join the multinational force in the gulf, and assured them any such deployment would require their approval. ``The Soviet leadership has no plan for participation in a military operation,'' he said. -In Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, the wife of the Kuwaiti planning minister said Iraq is fencing off the northern part of Kuwait. ``The Iraqis are setting up a wire fence across Kuwait. They apparently plan to gulp up Bubiyan and the northeastern oilfield,'' said Fatima Hussein, who fled Kuwait last week and was among 750 businessmen, economists and politicians at a three-day conference on their country's future. -The French Foreign Ministry reported Iraqi soldiers have emptied the rooftop cistern holding the water for the French Embassy in Kuwait. The building now has no water, electric or telephone service, and rice is the only remaining food, the ministry said. Iraq's ambassador to France, Abdul Razzak al-Hashimi, denied that the cistern had been emptied. -Spain became the first European Community country to see all its hostages safely out of Iraq when 15 Spaniards reached Jordan accompanied by a five-member private delegation that won their release from Baghdad. Seven Spanish diplomats voluntarily remained behind. There are more than 600 American hostages in Kuwait and about 300 in Iraq. -Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan said his government is considering whether the constitution can be interpreted to allow deployment overseas of armed Japanese troops under U.N. auspices. The constitution, written during the U.S. occupation after World War II, prohibits the use of force to settle international disputes.

DOC.HEAD: Tense Moments in Red Sea Blockade
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.DATELINE: ABOARD USS SAMUEL B. ROBERTS IN THE RED SEA (AP)
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi crewmen of a container ship cursed members of a U.S. boarding team, leading to tense moments before the vessel's master agreed to change course, Navy officers say. In another reported incident, U.S. Marines for the first time joined in a boarding party by ``fast-roping'' from a hovering helicopter onto the deck of an Iraqi ship in the northern Arabian Sea. In nearly nine weeks since the U.N. embargo against Iraq began, the multinational force of naval ships has intercepted 2,350 commercial vessels, nearly 40 a day, U.S. military spokesmen said. They said they could not provide a breakdown by members of the multinational force, nor any updated figures on the number of boardings or diversions of ships. The U.S. warships are part of an international flotilla enforcing the U.N. embargo, which was imposed in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The majority of boardings have occurred in the Red Sea, mainly along the approaches to Jordan's key port of Aqaba. Despite Jordan's assurances to the contrary, U.S. officers say some prohibited cargoes appear to be slipping through Aqaba and being taken overland to Iraq. The Roberts, the frigate USS Elmer Montgomery, and Greek and Spanish frigates are serving as embargo gatekeepers for ships entering and leaving the Strait of Tiran, which leads into the Gulf of Aqaba. The 3,600-ton Roberts, based at Newport, R.I., has conducted about 40 boardings itself and one previous diversion, of the Sudanese freighter Blue Nile, in the Tiran Strait Oct. 5. The tense confrontation occurred Friday when a combined Navy-Coast Guard team from the Roberts boarded the 24,302-ton, Qatar-flagged container ship Bar'zan after following it for eight hours as it headed toward Aqaba. Cmdr. John W. Townes III, captain of the Roberts, said Sunday that some members of the Bar'zan's crew, identified as Iraqis, ``verbally abused'' the Americans, using ``a lot of four-letter words.'' He said the situation never got out of hand. ``It got close but the boarding party has learned that the best thing is to step away,'' he said. The Bar'zan, which had picked up cargo in the United States and Spain en route to the region, agreed to divert to the Saudi port of Jiddah after its cargo manifest was ``found to be unclear as to the ultimate destination'' of some goods on board, Townes said. U.S. military spokesmen said Marines from the amphibious landing dock ship USS Ogden climbed down by rope onto the Iraqi-flagged tanker al-Mutanabbi on Saturday after it was intercepted by the Ogden, the frigate USS Brewton and the Australian missile frigate HMAS Darwin. Once the Marines secured the 66,155-ton tanker, inspection teams from the Brewton and Darwin boarded from small boats. ``After determining that al-Mutanabbi was empty of cargo, the boarding teams departed and the ship was cleared to proceed,'' a statement said. A Navy spokesman in the Saudi city of Dhahran, Cmdr. J.D. Van Sickle, said he did not know why the Marines were involved. The Ogden, which carries about 900 Marines, is among 18 ships in a Marine amphibious task force in the north Arabian Sea.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Veteran Tapped for Selective Service
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday he will nominate Robert William Gambino, a 20-year veteran of the Central Intelligence Agency, to be director of Selective Service. If confirmed by the Senate, Gambino would succeed Samuel K. Lessey Jr. as head of the nation's standby consciption arrangements for the armed forces. For the past 10 years, Gambino has held a variety of positions outside government, most recently as vice president of a research group in Falls Church, Va. From 1960 until 1980 he worked for the CIA. Gambino's nomination was announced during a campaign appearance in Dallas by Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Five American Airlines Authorized To Open Routes To Japan
DOC.TEXT: Five American airlines have been authorized to open passenger and cargo service to Tokyo and other cities in Japan, the Department of Transportation announced on Monday. Three air carriers - United Air Lines, Delta Air Lines and American Airlines - were authorized to serve Tokyo. Delta, America West Airlines and Hawaiian Airlines were authorized to serve two other Japanese cities, Nagoya and Fukuoka. The route awards were granted under a November 1989 agreement which laid the foundation for a major expansion of air service between the United States and Japan. In making the announcement the department noted that the U.S.-Japanese market currently generates more than $6 billion in revenue for both countries. Last year the Japan market ranked third in numbers of passengers, after Canada and Great Britain, and was first in passenger revenue. Monday's announcement is the last of several awards authorizing new flights to Japan. In July, Federal Express, which had been providing all-cargo service to Tokyo, was permitted to serve Nagoya as well. In August, United Cargo Service was selected to operate a new all-cargo service to Tokyo. And in September the department allotted the 450 charter flights authorized by the agreement. Patrick V. Murphy, deputy assistant secretary for international affairs, made the following new selections: -Chicago-Tokyo authority to United with backup authority to American if United does not choose to fly the new route. -Los Angeles-Tokyo authority to Delta with backup authority to American. San Jose-Tokyo authority to American with backup authority to Continental Airlines for Houston-Tokyo service. -Honolulu-Nagoya authority to America West with backup authority to Continental. -Honolulu-Fukuoka authority to Hawaiian Airlines with backup authority to Continental for Los Angeles-Nagoya service. -Portland-Nagoya authority to Delta with backup authority to Continental for Seattle-Nagoya service. Nine air carriers submitted 23 proposals for the new routes, the department said.

DOC.HEAD: Arizonans Hope To End King Holiday Flap on Election Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9-10th grafs, `There are...', with 2 grafs to CORRECT attribution of quotes to pollster Earl de Berge, sted Tidwell. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `A poll...'.
DOC.TEXT: Arizona voters will try to do what their elected leaders have failed at for 15 years: put the costly and divisive Martin Luther King holiday issue to rest, one way or the other. Arizona is one of just three states - with Montana and New Hampshire - that have not made the late civil rights leader's birthday a state holiday in some form. Congress designated the third Monday in January a federal holiday in 1983. Repeated attempts at making King Day a holiday have died in the Arizona Legislature since the first effort failed in 1975. Amid concern that the dispute has hurt the state economically, pollsters and politicians now believe voters will give their blessing Nov. 6 to a ballot measure adopting the holiday. A rival ballot measure would ratify legislation creating a paid King holiday for state workers but eliminate a paid Columbus Day. Polls show scant support for that idea. All sides, including impeached Gov. Evan Mecham who is a leading opponent, have said they will abide by the outcome. The Republican and Democratic gubernatorial candidates favor a King Day. Mecham, who created a storm during his tenure as governor by eliminating a King holiday created by his predecessor, lost his bid to regain the governor's office in the Sept. 11 Reublican primary. ``There's a feeling here that the only thing worse than giving them the holiday is not giving it to them,'' said Jim Tidwell, chairman of the Republican Party in Gila County. ``There are also just a hell of a lot of people who feel that America is a leading nation in civil rights and that we ought to honor that,'' said Pheonix pollster Earl de Berge. De Berge said his own polls show voters favor the holiday by about a 5-to-3 margin. A poll by The Arizona Republic found 55 percent in favor of King Day and 42 percent opposed. A poll by the newspaper conducted Sept. 13-16 found only 18 percent of 601 registered voters surveyed favored the King-Columbus Day swap. If both ballot measures are approved, the one with the greater number of yes votes wins. If both are rejected, the long-established Columbus Day would be retained, and Arizonans would have no paid King holiday. The outcome could end a struggle that has divided the state since the first King holiday bill was introduced and defeated in 1975. Former Gov. Bruce Babbitt, a Democrat, created the holiday by executive order just before he left office in 1986. But Mecham, armed with an attorney general's opinion that Babbitt's order was illegal, rescinded it days after he took office in January 1987. Mecham subsequently issued his own executive order, setting aside the third Sunday in January as an unpaid holiday to honor King, but it never was recognized by supporters of a paid holiday. Mecham was impeached and removed from office for unrelated actions in 1988. The Legislature created a paid King holiday in October 1989 but did away with the state's paid Columbus Day holiday to avoid the expense of giving state workers an additional paid day off. That touched off a firestorm among Arizona's Italian-Americans, who helped gather enough petition signatures to place the issue before the voters on Nov. 6. Lawmakers passed a second bill in May, establishing the King holiday and keeping Columbus Day, in hopes of heading off the public vote. But another referendum drive - this one headed by Mecham - succeeded in collecting enough signatures to place the second measure on the ballot as well.

DOC.HEAD: The Sick, Farmers, Tourists Face Higher Costs Under Budget Plans
DOC.TEXT: Federal payments to doctors and hospitals would go down, driving up costs to patients. The government would be less generous to farmers and college students. And, under the budget deal brewing in Congress, a broad range of fees would increase - from tourists entering the country to inventors filing for new patents. In fact, virtually all Americans would be likely to find themselves digging deeper into their pockets. Rudolf G. Penner, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute and former director of the Congressional Budget Office, sees a silver lining concerning the higher costs: ``They're pretty widespread, so they shouldn't be intensely felt by any particular group or individual.'' The proposals are contained in separate budget-cutting bills the House and Senate are girding to debate this week. The packages are aimed at paring the federal deficit by $40 billion in the budget year that began Oct. 1, by $500 billion over the next five years. So far, the tax increases contained in the plans have received most of the public's attention, with Democrats and Republicans vying to show the voters that the rich will pay their fair share. But it's not just tax increases that the average American would notice should lawmakers and President Bush finally reach a deficit-reduction agreement. In fact, most of the savings in the packages Congress plans to vote on come from spending reductions. Among the programs hardest hit would be Medicare, which helps 33 million elderly and handicapped Americans pay their medical bills. Increases in the program, one of the fastest growing in the government, would be held to $43 billion to $49 billion below the amount needed to keep pace with inflation over the next five years. Although details of the congressional plans differ, it seems certain that the reimbursements doctors and hospitals receive for treating Medicare patients will be restrained. The Senate Finance Committee bill, for example, would hold increases in payments to hospitals to 3.2 percent in 1991, 2 percent below the expected rate of inflation for hospital costs. Reimbursements to family doctors would increase by just 2 percent next year, while payments to specialists - such as surgeons - would be frozen at this year's levels. With their federal reimbursements reduced, doctors and hospitals could be forced to pass their costs onto patients - all patients. The government limits the ability of health-care providers to boost costs for Medicare recipients. Medicare patients themselves are being singled out by the budget writers. The $75 they must pay each year in doctors' bills before the government begins picking up the tab would increase to $150 next year under the Senate Finance bill, $100 under the House Democratic plan. Farmers would also be hit by a significant reduction in federal agriculture subsidies, totaling $13.6 billion over the next five years. Although details were not final, lawmakers tentatively decided to reduce acreage eligible for crop subsidies by 15 percent for each farmer, beginning in 1992. They also agreed to reduce the subsidies in another way: by changing the formula by which farmers receive payments when market prices are low. The five subsidized crops are wheat, corn, feed grains, rice and cotton. College students would also find the Guaranteed Student Loan program stingier, under a measure approved Monday by the House Education and Labor Committee. The loans - which go to 3 million students at colleges, graduate schools, and trade schools - would no longer be available at schools where more than 35 percent of students have defaulted. That is expected to end the program at about 1,000 schools. The committee also decided to reduce the yield banks receive from the government for making the federally backed loans. This could discourage some lenders from making the money available to students. Other measures affecting consumers would: -End, for five years, the options civil service retirees have to receive their benefits in a lump sum. People over age 64 with 30 years of service would be exempted. -Impose a $1 fee on tourists, on planes or ships, entering the United States, including returning Americans, except for those traveling from Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean or U.S. possessions. -Increase U.S. Patent Office fees for items such as patent applications.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Nobel Award Recognizes Value of his Reforms
LaserPhoto MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, his eyes shining with pleasure, said Monday his Nobel Peace Prize reflected worldwide recognition of the importance of his reforms ``for the destiny of the entire world.'' Gorbachev's $700,000 prize came as he delayed shifting the Soviet economy from a centrally planned to a market system. While the Nobel recognition was bound to raise his international prestige, its effect was less certain in the Soviet Union, which is plagued by consumer shortages and ethnic strife. ``It will be an influence of an emotional and intellectual nature because it is ... an appreciation of the cause we are all working for. All the more so because this award coincides in time with a most crucial stage in perestroika,'' he said. ``We are on the threshold of deep changes and reforms ... with regard to the economy's transition to a market system.'' Gorbachev was expected to propose a new reform package Monday to the Supreme Soviet, but his speech was postponed until Friday. The Soviet president said he received the news of the award from Norwegian Ambassador Dagfinn Stenseth at the Kremlin. Gorbachev said he would travel to Oslo to accept the award. He strongly praised the other Soviet peace laureate, the late Andrei D. Sakharov, who was barred from collecting the prize in 1975, a decade before Gorbachev rose to power. Gorbachev recalled Sakharov from internal exile 18 months into his administration. Gorbachev said that when he took office, ``the world was ripe for change. It had grown tired of the Cold War, the arms race ... the hardships resulting from an overload of current problems facing the world community.'' ``And I consider that academician Sakharov was in the first ranks of searchers for the answers that agitated people's minds,'' he said. Sakharov's widow, Yelena Bonner, who in an interview last week with a Norwegian newspaper compared Gorbachev to Napoleon, declined to comment on the award Monday. Gorbachev appeared delighted as he stood before reporters, speaking calmly and slowly. ``I am deeply touched. ... I perceive this action ... as a recognition of the immense value and the immense significance of the great cause of perestroika for the destiny of the entire world.'' ``When we began our perestroika ... we came to the conclusion that we could not continue to live as we had lived, that we needed deep transformations in all spheres of life,'' he said. ``Even then we wanted to be understood correctly, in that what we were going to do was bound to be of great significance for all countries, for the entire world because it was happening in such a huge country as the Soviet Union, which plays a great role and bears on its shoulders a great responsibility to the world community,'' he said. Many Soviets, even those who support reform, are skeptical of Gorbachev's ability to transform the nation. Historian Roy A. Medvedev, a member of the Supreme Soviet, said of the Nobel prize that ``in internal affairs, it won't have much significance.'' Most of about 15 Soviets interviewed at random in Moscow said that although Gorbachev may have helped reduce world tension, his contributions to his homeland were mixed. ``In international affairs, I think he's done everything right - it's domestically that there is disorder,'' said Andrei A. Tatishchev, 23. ``I would be proud of him if he put things in this country in order. What happens there, outside our borders, doesn't interest me very much as an ordinary Russian person,'' Tatishchev added. Shortly after the announcement, Gorbachev gave an interview to Soviet and foreign television reporters. The state news agency Tass carried excerpts. In the Supreme Soviet chamber, Chairman Anatoly Lukyanov waited 78 minutes before informing lawmakers he had ``just learned'' that Gorbachev had won the award. The announcement was followed by seven seconds of mild applause, comparatively brief in a chamber accustomed to long speeches and adulation. Medvedev later told reporters that Lukyanov had not wanted to interrupt discussion of a report delivered by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadaze. A defeated Gorbachev rival, Yegor K. Ligachev, was observing the parliamentary debate when word broke. He told reporters ``I have an extremely positive reaction,'' then rushed away.

DOC.SECOND: AM-AP Arts: Daviau, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0590,0861
DOC.HEAD: The Man Behind the Beatific Look of ``Avalon''
LaserPhoto LA2 of Oct. 11.
DOC.TEXT: When immigrant Sam Krichinsky arrived in Baltimore in 1914, he says at the opening of the movie ``Avalon,'' it was the most beautiful place he had ever seen. If audiences share Krichinsky's memory, they can thank Allen Daviau. As the film's director of photography, Daviau was charged with transforming director Barry Levinson's rich script into equally evocative images. Perhaps no scene in ``Avalon'' reveals Daviau's artistry more than that first scene in which Krichinsky (Armin Mueller-Stahl portraying Levinson's grandfather as a young man) lands in Electric Park, a 1914 exposition re-created for the film by production designer Norman Reynolds. As the first reel unspools, something looks off. As Krichinsky moves through Electric Park, decorated with 18,000 lights, his body movements are slightly jumpy and the colors overly rich. He walks at normal speed, and yet it is clear we are not watching his actual arrival. It is instead Krichinsky's recollection of it. ``This is a very abstract, stylized, idealized memory he's having of brilliant lights,'' said Daviau, whose cinematography won Academy Award nominations for Steven Spielberg's ``E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial,'' ``The Color Purple'' and ``Empire of the Sun.'' ``One of the things Barry said was, `We have to find a way to distance the past sequences from the present of 1948,' '' Daviau said. To avoid cinematic cliches, he declined to use filtration or sepia toning. What Daviau (pronounced Dav'-ee-ow) did instead was film at 18 frames per second, as opposed to the standard 24 frames. He then ``stretch-printed'' the film, using every other frame twice. ``It's missing a third of the information that our 24-frame-per second mind is used to seeing, and it's being restored in an artificial way,'' Daviau said. ``We've seen stretch printing in silent films for many, many years. The difference is, you haven't seen it in color.'' Daviau first used the technique making a bank commercial several years ago. He still alternates between commercials and feature films. ``It's the best mixture in the world,'' he said, ``because commercials keep you busy, they keep you in practice, they make you a lot of money and you meet a lot of directors who are on their way to doing pictures. ``Working in commercials allows you to be choosy about what movies you do. . . . What I was really looking to do happened when `Avalon' came along. ``I really am fascinated with the '40s,'' Daviau said. ``I got to deal with a period that I remember quite well.'' The movie spans 50 years, detailing the lives of the Krinchinskys - Levinson's family - and the world in which they live. Daviau started as a still photographer, photo lab technician and theatrical lighting designer. During the mid-1960s, he photographed rock promotional films with Jimi Hendrix, Aretha Franklin and The Who. Other feature credits include ``The Falcon and the Snowman'' and ``Defending Your Life.'' In 1988, the American Society of Cinematographers voted him best cinematographer in feature films. Levinson and Spielberg both are visual directors, Daviau said, but have different styles. ``Steven is much more interested in the design of the shot; the graphics are very, very important to him,'' Daviau said. ``Barry is a visual director, by all means, but it's a different emphasis. He loves the compositions.'' The cinematographer's job is a curious one. ``It's really a case of choosing to make your presence known. And you pick a look for a film and then you're out to make that look fit,'' Daviau said. ``There are certain things that general audiences may notice about photography that are not the things you do. A lot of times, we're credited with scenery. The things we really do are things that people rarely notice. Most of our work is lighting, color, texture. ``One of the greatest things that you do in cinematography is you guide the audiences's eye to where it should be. You're giving emphasis where it's desired. ``I don't think I would ever want to be known as every film I have looking the same or somebody saying, `Oh! Daviau did that for sure.' I'd much rather shape the look to the individual film.'' In ``Avalon,'' he said, certain details demanded to be examined closely. ``I looked at Armin Mueller-Stahl's face and in a second I saw those eyes. This is one of the most remarkable faces I've ever been given to photograph.'' For the Thanksgiving dinner scenes in ``Avalon,'' Daviau bathed the interiors with warm, comfortable light; pouring in from outside windows is cold, blue light. Near the film's end, Sam Krichinsky settles into a chair to read a newspaper. A few seconds later, when he arises, he's aged 10 years. The framing of both shots is identical. There is no jump in the image, even though the two scenes were done more than a week apart. So seamless is the transition that some in the audience don't notice for several moments that Krichinsky's grown old. And that, for Daviau, is photography at its best.

DOC.HEAD: Peruvian Miners, Railway and Petroleum Workers Strike
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of state mining and railway workers went on strike Monday, and state oil workers plan to join them in a 72-hour work stoppage Tuesday to demand wage increases, spokesmen for the companies said. About 5,000 workers at Empresa Minera del Centro (Centromin) began an indefinite strike on Monday, a Centromin spokesman said, hampering operations at the San Cristobal, Andaychagua, Cobriza, Casapalca mines in the Junin and Huancavelica areas east of Lima. The mines produce copper, lead and zinc. The striking workers represent nearly half of Centromin's workforce. Management at Centromin are not taking part in the salary dispute. The workers are demanding a raise of nearly 200 percent to $9 a day, up from present daily wages of $3.50, according to the Federation of Miners and Metalworkers of Centromin Peru. The Federation said Centromin is offering a 75-cent-a-day pay hike, to $4.25 a day. About 4,000 workers at the state railway company Enafer began an indefinite strike Monday to protest a presidential decree freezing wages until December, an Enafer spokesman said. The strike will affect the cargo route from Lima's port of Callao to the Mantaro Valley, 120 miles east of Lima, the spokesman said. Enafer handles 96 percent of Centromin's shipments. The spokesman said the southern rail routes between Arequipa, La Juliaca, Puno and Cuzco would also be paralyzed. Workers at Petroperu, the state oil company, are set to strike Tuesday for three days to demand wage increases, a Petroperu spokesman said Monday. The company's 10,000 workers plan to shut down offshore drilling and operations in the jungle and coastal regions, as well as the company's five refineries.

DOC.HEAD: Protestant Village Honored For Saving 5,000 Jews From Nazis
DOC.TEXT: The little town of Le Chambon-Sur-Lignon now has a scroll of honor, and 30 villagers have medals, a half-century after they and their neighbors saved 5,000 Jews from Nazi persecution. Israeli Ambassador Ovadia Soafer presented the Medals of Righteousness to townspeople who risked their lives as they sheltered Jews on the run from 1940 through 1944. ``You gave a lesson of courage and dignity, but also a political lesson which statesmen of the entire world should retain and apply as a rule of conduct - don't give in to threats, don't let youself be intimidated,'' Soafer said at Sunday's ceremony. The entire town, in addition to its scroll, will be honored Oct. 22 at the Yad Vashem holocaust memorial in Jerusalem. It is the first community in France to be recognized collectively by the Yad Vashem institute, which customarily honors individual non-Jews who took risks on behalf of Jews during World War II. Marie Brottes, 84, said she and her neighbors, mostly poor Protestant peasants, simply did what the Bible advised. ``You had to see those poor Jews who arrived with nothing - no clothes, no possessions, no family. We helped them because it's written in the Gospel. That's what gave us the courage and strength to do what we did,'' she said in a telephone interview. Just 11 weeks after France fell to the Germans, the collaborationist Vichy government passed laws discriminating against Jews. By 1945, 80,000 Jews had been deported to Nazi death camps. Only 2,500 returned. Sheltering mainly children at first, the people of Le Chambon turned no one away, betrayed no one, attempted to convert no one. Mrs. Brottes and other villagers recall the wartime events in ``The Weapons of the Spirit,'' a documentary film about how, through word of mouth, the quiet, mountain community in central France became a place of refuge for 5,000 Jews. The 90-minute film, shown in France for the first time last week, was screened in Le Chambon before an audience of rescuers and survivors, many never reunited before. ``Le Chambon-sur-Lignon was like paradise, a little corner of the world that allowed us to survive,'' said Joseph Atlas, 14 when he reached Le Chambon after a brief period at an internment camp. Atlas, now a 64-year-old engineer, said residents might not understand why many Jews took so long returning to the village to express thanks. ``At the end of the war, when we discovered the full extent of the Holocaust, we had to rebuild ourselves psychologically,'' he said. Atlas praised the film's accuracy, but said it brought back troubling memories. The film is the work of Pierre Sauvage, born in 1944 to Jews who took refuge in Le Chambon. Sauvage says Le Chambon - inspired by its impassioned pastor, Andre Trocme - was swept up in a conspiracy of goodness. ``Goodness was contagious. It was a situation in which it was almost harder to do evil than good,'' said Sauvage, who is based in Los Angeles and has worked for PBS in the United States. The villagers are hardly inclined to see themselves as heroes. ``They simply thought what they did was normal, and they looked at me as though my questions were stupid,'' Sauvage said. Madga Trocme, 89, widow of Pastor Trocme, said the villagers acted because they knew in their hearts ``anything else would have been a sin.'' ``They acted in the memory of their Huguenot tradition and the persecution they experienced over the centuries,'' she said after seing the film. ``It was war, everybody was in danger. We did what we did because it had to be done.''

DOC.HEAD: Teen Working On Bicycle Safety Merit Badge Dies After Bike Accident
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager trying to earn a Boy Scout merit badge for bicycle safety died of injuries suffered in a bicycle accident, authorities said. Donald Thompson, 16, of Kersey died at Poudre Valley Hospital on Sunday morning, about 24 hours after the accident on a dirt bike track near a Fort Collins park. Thompso This will delay the previously planned LaserColor CDS102, Cincinnati Reds manager Lou Piniella with Los Angeles Dodgers manager Tony LaRussa at Riverfront Stadium for team workouts Monday. LaserColor CDS102 is now planned for the main line by 6:30 p.m.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Chilean Arms Maker Denies Deal for Sale of Air-Fuel Bomb to Iraq
DOC.TEXT: A Chilean arms maker on Monday denied published reports that it is negotiating the sale of a new air-fuel bomb to Iraq through the Libyan government of Col. Moammar Ghadafi. Cardoen Industries said in a communique it has never made such a bomb, which is considered an inexpensive but highly lethal explosive. ``Cardoen Industries has no commercial relations for the export to Iraq of defense material, and has no plans to violate government regulations banning such exports,'' the company said. He said no such exports are planned to any other country either. A British newspaper on Sunday said Cardoen had developed the bomb, and was negotiating its sale to Iraq through Libya. Cardoen is one of Latin America's largest arms makers. During the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, it sold hundreds of cluster bombs to the Baghdad government of President Saddam Hussein. The company says, however, it has now cesead the sale of all military equipment to Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: President Approves Compensation for Cold War's Domestic Victims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 5 grafs at end with reax from lawmakers and victim
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed a bill Monday authorizing payments of up to $100,000 for people who may have developed cancer from nuclear testing or uranium mining in Western states during the Cold War. ``These payments fairly resolve the claims of persons present at the test site and of downwind residents, as well as claims of uranium miners,'' Bush said in a statement. He signed the measure during a campaign trip here. The United States conducted more than 200 atomic tests in the open air in both the South Pacific and in Nevada. ``Atmospheric testing of atomic devices - important to national security during the darkest days of the Cold War - ended in 1963'' when the United States signed and ratified the Limited Test Ban Treaty, Bush said. The bill authorizes $100 million for a Radiation Exposure Trust Fund. Money for the fund would have to be appropriated in a separate bill. The bill provides compensation for people who developed cancer in certain time periods and: -Spent one or two years, depending on their type of cancer, in downwind areas of Nevada, Arizona or Utah from nuclear tests between 1951 and 1958, or between June and July, 1962. -Or mined uranium in Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, Wyoming or Utah from 1947 to 1971. Uranium miners are entitled to payments of $100,000. Persons exposed to radiation and who contracted specific diseases would be entitled to $50,000. Courts have ruled the government was immune from prosecution because national security dictated a need for the uranium, but judges involved in the case urged the miners to seek redress from Congress. Rep. Wayne Owens, D-Utah, an attorney who represented the ``downwinders'' in a federal lawsuit eight years ago, said the bill will benefit people he called great patriots. ``They are victims of the Cold War, and they will now be compensated for their long suffering,'' he said. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, who co-sponsored the bill with Owens, said the formal apology contained in the measure might mean more to victims than the money. ``People were sick of what went on and how callous the federal government seemed to be,'' Hatch said. The apology ``should make people feel pretty doggone good.'' One who agreed was Rula Orton of Parowan, Utah. Her 14-year-old daughter died in 1960 of leukemia that doctors think may have been induced by radiation. ``I'm glad they're owning up to it,'' said Orton. ``I feel very good about that.''

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Minister Discounts Skyrocketing Oil Prices in Event War
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Recent rises in oil prices stem solely from fears of a war, not a supply shortage, Kuwait's oil minister said Monday. Analysts said Saudi Arabia, whose reserves have risen dramatically in the past year, will probably help prevent severe price shocks during a war. The oil minister for the exiled Kuwaiti government, Rashid al-Ameeri, said at a news conference that oil prices would increase in the event of hostilities. But he said they would not skyrocket to $100 a barrel, as predicted recently by a former Saudi oil minister, Ahmeed Zaki Yamani. Ameeri spoke in the Saudi capital, where his government-in-exile has been established since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. A U.S.-led multinational force has been deployed to Saudi Arabia in response to the Iraqi aggression, and the stand-off is entering its 11th week. A trade embargo meant to force Iraq out of Kuwait has cut off four million barrels per day of oil exports from Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Industry experts noted Saudi Arabia, which sits on a third of the world's proven oil reserves, would exert itself to stabilize the market. The Saudis already have been instrumental in offsetting the shortfall in the oil market resulting from the invasion of Kuwait. The kingdom increased its own output by about two million barrels per day to 7.5 million barrels, and convinced other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cartel to increase their output. In addition, Saudi oil officials refer to the four strikes made between June 1989 and April 1990 in a previously untapped central region of the kingdom. During that period, official estimates of the kingdom's proven reserves jumped by about 50 percent to 252 billion barrels. Light sweet crude was trading at $37.75 per barrel Monday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil was selling on international markets for about $21 a barrel in July. Ameeri said the recent increase in oil prices was not the result of any shortage in oil supplies, but stemmed from fears about a war in the gulf. His statements were clearly intended as reassurance. Independent oil industry executives said that the market would suffer a severe upheaval in the event of a Middle East war, but that the extent to which oil prices will rise would depend on the extent of damages to the regional oil facilities and the duration of hostilities. Saudi oil officials, led by the minister, Hisham Nazer, often play up the country's oil production potential. Oil experts note the kingdom is also putting back into service old facilities that were mothballed during the oil glut in the early 1980s. Ameeri said Iraqi troops have placed mines around Kuwaiti oil fields, refineries and other installations. The Iraqis have also ``stolen'' equipment from Kuwaiti oil facilities, he said. ``The damage to the oil industry in Kuwait is huge,'' Ameeri said. He estimated the Iraqis are now pumping about 90,000 barrels a day, just meeting the needs of local power stations and desalination plants. Kuwait's pre-invasion output was 1.5 million barrels a day. Iraq's invasion followed Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's claims that Kuwait had cost Iraq $14 billion in lost oil revenue by overproducing and driving down prices, and that it had stolen $2.4 billion of oil from the Rumailah field between the two countries.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus Rdp Bjt
States Must Get Federal Approval Before Holding Elections For Judges
DOC.TEXT: State officials must get federal approval before holding elections for dozens of state judges, the Supreme Court ruled in a Georgia case Monday. The justices unanimously upheld a three-judge federal court's ruling that such approval is required by the Voting Rights Act of 1965. The decision, announced without first hearing arguments in the case, was the first in which newly installed Justice David H. Souter participated. It came on an appeal by Georgia officials and a cross-appeal by black voters who wanted new elections ordered for judgeships already filled. At issue was the scope of the 1965 law's requirement that officials in southern states and elsewhere get Justice Department approval before making changes in election systems. From 1964 to 1988, Georgia created 77 new trial judges and five new judicial circuits. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh in 1989 said he opposed 48 of the judgeships and the redistricting plans for two circuits. The Georgia General Assembly also voted last year to create six more judgeships. The state had not submitted those to Thornburgh for his approval when a special three-judge federal court last year ruled the state violated the Voting Rights Act. The federal court said the state must get approval from the attorney general for any election changes that could discriminate against blacks. ``The creation of new judgeships does have the potential for discrimination,'' the panel said, because Georgia has rules that blunt minorities' voting power in electing judges. Those rules authorize circuit-wide voting and require candidates to designate the specific opening they are seeking if a judicial circuit has more than one judgeship vacancy. The three-judge court ordered Georgia officials to comply with the Voting Rights Act requirement of federal approval or keep the judgeships unfilled. But the federal court refused to overturn the results of any previous elections because ``the remaining judges would be overwhelmed by the resulting increase in work and the court system thrown into disarray.'' Georgia officials said there is no evidence blacks have suffered from discrimination. They said there are many black judges in the state, though less than the percentage of black citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Attend World Series
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will fly to Cincinnati on Wednesday for the second game of the World Series between the Oakland Athletics and the Cincinnati Reds, White House officials said Monday. Bush will miss the opening game Tuesday because he will still be on a five-state campaign swing that will not get him back to Washington until late in the evening. Officials said Bush planned no other appearances in Cincinnati other than the game at Riverfront Stadium.

DOC.HEAD: Country Music Star Ferlin Husky Hospitalized In Cody
DOC.TEXT: Country music star Ferlin Husky was in stable condition Monday at a Cody hospital after suffering chest pains and canceling a weekend benefit performance. Husky, one of country music's top entertainers in the early 1960s with such hits as ``Wings of a Dove,'' was suffering from what appeared to be angina, said his wife, Marvis. She was arranging to fly her husband to Baptist Hospital in Nashville to be examined by the same medical team that has treated such country greats as Johnny Cash and Waylon Jennings. Husky, 63, was scheduled to perform Saturday night at the Wynona Thompson Auditorium in a benefit concert for the Kidney Foundation. But he complained of chest pains shortly before the show and was taken to West Park Hospital. ``On Saturday night he called me from his hotel and said, `I'm so sick and I can't move and I just wanted to tell you I love you,' '' Mrs. Husky said in a telephone interview Monday from her home in Hendersonville, Tenn., a suburb of Nashville. ``I really think he thought that was it.'' The singer has a history of heart problems. He suffered a heart attack in Seattle in 1983 and underwent heart surgery in 1977. Lately, Mrs. Husky said, ``he's not been feeling real good and he's been pushing himself real hard. He's been under a lot of stress. ... He's neglected going in for checkups.'' Nonetheless, she said, ``he's a tough guy. He said he was so disappointed to have to cancel the benefit. He said he will come back and do it. He will. I know he will.'' At the height of his career, Husky was a recording, movie and television star. He made 18 movies with such stars as Jayne Mansfield and Zsa Zsa Gabor. He once said his selection as Arthur Godfrey's summer replacement at CBS in the late 1950s was the zenith of his career. He cut back on his entertaining career in 1970 and has mostly played concert dates.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sees Long Convoluted Proceeding in Keating Case
DOC.TEXT: A judge predicted ``a long and convoluted'' proceeding Monday in the fraud case against the Arizona developer who formerly headed American Continental Corp. Charles Keating is accused of bilking investors with American Continental junk bonds sold through the now-defunct, Irvine-based Lincoln Savings and Loan. Lincoln's failure was the nation's most expensive savings and loan collapse. Keating, 66, remained jailed Monday in lieu of $5 million bail. But he made his first comment on the case as he was being led into the downtown Criminal Courts Building through an underground garage. ``It's dangerous to be right when government is wrong,'' Keating told reporters. His lawyer, Stephen Neal, asked to explain Keating's comment, would say only: ``Mr. Keating is innocent. He believes in his innocence. He's confident that when the evidence is developed he will be vindicated.'' Keating was chairman of Phoenix-based American Continental, which owned Lincoln. Experts estimate the cost of bailing out Lincoln will reach $2 billion. Prosecutors say investors in American Continental junk bonds lost more than $250 million. Superior Court Judge Lance Ito said he would read the 45-volume transcript of grand jury proceedings before Oct. 26, when he set a hearing for legal arguments on defense motions seeking to have the judge throw out the indictment as insufficient. The judge said he would also decide at that hearing whether to keep the grand jury transcripts sealed and would rule on defense motions for discovery of prosecution evidence. A prosecutor, Deputy District Attorney William Hodgman, said he would ask for reciprocal discovery of defense evidence. ``I expect this will be a long and convoluted discovery proceeding,'' the judge commented. Ito set a tentative trial date of Nov. 26, but conceded that would probably be delayed. Neal said a spring date would be more realistic, and the judge said: ``I'm not overly optimistic on the trial date.'' Neal said he was still pursuing a bail reduction for Keating in federal court after losing similar bids in state appeals courts. Also in court for Monday's hearing were Keating's co-defendants, who are all free on bail. They are Ray C. Fidel, 32, former president of Lincoln; Robin S. Symes, 37, who was its chief executive officer; and Judy Wischer, 42, who was president of American Continental. Each defendant faces up to 10 years in prison if convicted of six or more of the 42 counts.

DOC.HEAD: Richards, Williams Fight Over Insurance
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Ann Richards said Monday insurance companies are working to defeat her because she wants to lower premiums. Republican Clayton Williams is tied to the insurance industry, she said. Richards revealed a letter from the state trade organization of insurance agents, which said a Richards victory in the Nov. 6 general election ``would be disastrous for us.'' ``If you want to protect your livelihood, you can't afford to vote for Ann Richards,'' the letter from the Independent Insurance Agents of Texas said. Richards said, ``They are afraid of me because they know that insurance rates should be lowered in Texas.'' Richards is in the pocket of trial lawyers, the Williams' campaign responded. ``Richards is a political ambulance chaser,'' said Gordon Hensley, a spokesman for Williams. Trial lawyers represent injured people suing insurance companies over disputes in benefits or claims.
DOC.HEAD: Liberals Face Quandary in Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial nominee William Weld has picked up an endorsement from a liberal gay rights organization. The support is more a reflection of his opponents' stands than of his own, some Democrats say. In the GOP primary, Weld faced Rep. Steven Pierce, a conservative Republican. Now Weld faces John Silber, who has gained a conservative image among Democrats. ``Weld is probably viewed more as a beneficiary of certain forces than as a standard bearer of liberal policies,'' said Ann Lewis, a Democratic Party activist.

Republican Senate candidate M. Jane Brady won't obey NBC's request to drop unauthorized network news footage from a campaign videotape aimed at Sen. Joseph R. Biden. Brady plans to mail 40,000 11-minute videotapes to Delaware households as a campaign tool. The $75,000 effort is being paid for by the National Republican Senatorial Committee. Richard Cotton, NBC executive vice president and general counsel, sent a letter dated Oct. 10 to Devine, citing news accounts of the unauthorized NBC News footage being used in Brady's campaign. The videotape uses network footage of Biden's plagiarism problems during his bid for the 1988 Democratic presidential nomination. The videotape uses footage from NBC, ABC, CBS and C-SPAN without permission. After a complaint from C-SPAN, Devine agreed to put a disclaimer on the video's container, dissociating all the networks from the campaign.
DOC.HEAD: Engler's Nickel Campaign Cute, But Tardy
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate John Engler asked voters to send nickels to Democratic Gov. James Blanchard to show their disgust with his tax relief proposal. The governor has a $40 million plan to freeze property tax assessments at the rate of inflation. Engler has proposed cutting property taxes by $500 million a year by rolling back assessments from 50 percent to 40 percent of a property's cash value. In one Engler ad, a hot dog vendor drives home the claim that the average person's savings would add up to enough to buy a hot dog and soft drink at the end of the year. A second ad features an elderly woman who looks up from her magazine and says in disbelief, ``$2.50?'' as the announcer claims that's the total annual savings from Blanchard's property tax plan. A Blanchard campaign spokeswoman said Engler is distorting Katie Wolf said over 10 years, the owner of a $70,000 home would save $4,905, assuming inflation rates of 3.5 percent and assessment increases of 8 percent annually.
DOC.HEAD: Galbraith Brings Marijuana Message, Nelson To Democrats
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial hopeful Gatewood Galbraith convinced country music legend Willie Nelson to join his marijuana-is-the-answer campaign. Nelson and Galbraith acknowledge they are regular marijuana smokers, but say they oppose the use of hard drugs. ``I like the guy,'' Nelson said of Galbraith at a rally Sunday in Lexington. ``Whether you want him for your governor, that's for you to say.'' Nelson says he's been a marijuana smoker for 25 years, but that his intake these days is only occasional. Four others are seeking the Democratic gubernatorial nomination next year.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leader Kim Dae-Jung, on Hunger Strike, Hospitalized
DOC.TEXT: Kim Dae-jung, a 66-year-old opposition leader, was hospitalized Monday on the eighth day of a hunger strike he began to protest a spy scandal and to demand quicker democratic reforms in Korea. Looking haggard and weak, Kim was taken by ambulance to Yonsei University Hospital in western Seoul. Kim, a two-time presidential candidate, had lost about 13 pounds and his condition had rapidly deteriorating. Aides said he had remained in his office since the strike began Oct. 8, drinking only water and being attended fulltime by a nurse. Aides said Kim would continue the hunger strike in the hospital under medical supervision. Acting party chairman Moon Tong-hwan and about a dozen others started a hunger strike Monday, party officials said. About 55 other members of the party would join Moon soon, they said. A mass anti-government hunger strike could create more domestic political turmoil on the eve of the second round of talks between the prime ministers of South Korea and North Korea.
