The talks, to be held in Pyongyang, North Korea's capital, are aimed at easing political and military tensions between the Koreas, divided since 1945. Government critics have charged that the administration of President Roh Tae-woo is focusing on the talks to divert attention from pressing domestic issues. Kim began his hunger strike to demand reforms and call attention to a scandal involving the military intelligence Defense Security Command, which allegedly spied on 1,300 civilians. Kim said he would continue his hunger strike until the government negotiated on four demands - economic reform, dissolution of the security command, early implementation of local autonomy and scrapping of government plans to change the form of government from presidential to parliamentary. In an attempt to appease public outrage over the government spying, Roh fired his defense minister and head of military intelligence last week. He also reshuffled major party posts and appointed a new floor leader to encourage the opposition parliamentarians to return to the National Assembly. The 78 opposition members of Parliament resigned en masse in August, accusing the government of railroading bills and reneging on promised reforms. On Saturday, about 100,000 opposition supporters, radicals and dissidents rallied in Seoul, the second major opposition protest in four months and the first two to take place since Roh became president in early 1988. ``This type of struggle is physically the most peaceful, yet spiritually the most powerful,'' said Kim when he started the hunger protest. Kim staged hunger strikes in 1977 and 1982, but both lasted only two to three days.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Says Those Who Fled East Germany Should Return
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Monday appealed to people who left East Germany to return home and help repair that part of the new united Germany. His remark came as Kohl hailed his party's Sunday election victories in now-defunct East Germany, where his Christian Democrats won the most votes in four out of five states. The victories strengthened Kohl's already good chances of winning united Germany's first national parliamentary vote seven weeks from now. He told reporters steps should be taken to ``encourage those who left the DDR (East Germany), whenever and for whatever reason, to return.'' He said that would be a ``very important contribution to rebuilding'' former East Germany, which is beset by skyrocketing unemployment and other formidable problems. More than 4.6 million East Germans fled to West Germany during 40 years of Communist rule in the East. Earlier in the day, Kohl met other leaders of the Christian Democratic Union to discuss Sunday's election victories. ``The 14th of October is a day of great joy and satisfaction,'' Kohl said. He said the party has a ``favorable starting position'' for federal elections on Dec. 2, in which underdog Social Democratic candidate Oskar Lafontaine will try to unseat Kohl. The Social Democrats were clearly stung by the results. ``It doesn't appear as if we're headed into any shining or glorious victory, but it is still not the reason to give up,'' Reinhard Klimmt, Lafontaine's campaign manager, said. The chancellor warned his party against complacency. ``There is the danger that some might believe the election is already over. There can be no talk of this,'' he said. Opinion polls taken before Sunday's balloting already indicated Kohl had a healthy lead over Lafontaine. The Christian Democrats won the most votes in the newly created states of Saxony, Thuringia, Saxony-Anhalt, and Mecklenburg-Lower Pomerania. Brandenburg was the only eastern state where the Social Democrats won against the conservatives. Final results there gave the Social Democrats 38.2 percent of the vote to 29.4 percent for the Christian Democrats. The Christian Democrats won an absolute majority in Saxony, with 53.8 percent of the vote, and will be looking for coalition partners in three other states. The most likely partner are the Free Democrats, already the junior member of Kohl's governing coalition. Christian Democrat Alfred Gomulka, who won the vote for governor in Mecklenburg-Lower Pomerania, said he may try to forge a ``grand coalition'' to include the Social Democrats. The Christian Demorats' and Free Democrats' combined vote there falls short of a parliamentary majority. The Party for Democratic Socialism, comprising East Germany's former Communists, drew less voter support than in East Germany's first free elections in March. The party still won seats in each state legislature and is the third-strongest party in some areas. Its best showings were in Mecklenburg-Lower Pomerania, 15.6 percent, and Brandenburg, 13.4 percent. The far-right Republicans were shut out of all five state legislatures. The best they did was 1.15 percent in Brandenburg. Parties had to win at least 5 percent of the vote to win state legislative seats. The turnout in the five states that used to be East Germany ranged from 65 to 73.5 percent of the 11.5 million eligible voters. The Dec. 2 vote will install the first democratically elected leader for all of Germany in nearly 60 years. Kurt von Schleicher, the last leader of the Weimar Republic, was chosen chancellor after elections in November 1932. In January 1933, Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler took over through political maneuvering amid a collapsing political and economic system. Kohl expressed concern on Monday that former Communist functionaries may still be exerting influence in eastern Germany. He said a major challenge for eastern Germany is ``dismantling old structures'' left over from Communism.

DOC.HEAD: President Sets Annual Refugee Quotas
DOC.TEXT: President Bush cleared the way Monday for a sharp increase in Soviet immigration into the United States. In his annual determination of the refugee ceiling, Bush authorized admission of 131,000 as refugees into the country during the year ending next Sept. 30. The refugee total is apart from those who apply for entry as routine immigrants. The regions with the highest quotas were East Asia with 52,000 and the Soviet Union with 50,000. The figure for the Soviet Union represented an 8,000 increase over the previous year. White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said the quota for the rest of Eastern Europe had declined ``because the political landscape had changed dramatically'' and fewer people are seeking to leave those countries. Refugee quotas for other regions were Africa 4,900; Eastern Europe 5,000; Near East and South Asia 6,000; Latin America and the Caribbean 3,100; not designated 10,000.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Intercepts Repatriates Haitian Migrants
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Coast Guard cutter intercepted a 40-foot sailboat packed with 91 Haitians and returned them to Haiti on Monday, the Coast Guard said. The boat was spotted Saturday about 500 miles southeast of Miami by the Coast Guard cutter Escanaba, the Coast Guard said. Immigration authorities who interviewed the occupants concluded that they were trying to immigrate for economic reasons, rather than political reasons, and thus were not eligible for asylum. They were the first group of Haitians repatriated by the Coast Guard since Sept. 23 when a fishing boat carrying 136 Haitians was intercepted about 500 miles southeast of Miami. The Coast Guard has repatriated a total of 907 Haitians so far this year.

DOC.HEAD: State Records First Encephalitis Death; Warns About Halloween
DOC.TEXT: Florida's mosquito-carried encephalitis outbreak has recorded its first confirmed fatality, and health officials warned Monday that trick-or-treaters should not go out after dark on Halloween. The victim was a 58-year-old West Melbourne woman who fell into a coma two months ago. She died Saturday one day after her respirator was disconnected. The viral illness is carried by a mosquito that feeds around dusk. Thirty-four people in 15 counties across Central and South Florida have contracted the so-called St. Louis strain of encephalitis since mid-August. Fifteen became so ill they required hospitalization and two people slipped into comas. Twenty-one more people have shown positive results on the first of two tests needed for confirmation. Dr. Charles S. Mahan, the state health officer, called on all Florida communities to hold Halloween activities during the afternoon instead of the evening, as is traditional, in order to reduce the risk of exposure. ``Moving the trick-or-treat hours is a prudent precaution in light of the current increase in the number of St. Louis encephalitis cases,'' Mahan said in a statement. Authorities were looking at a possible second encephalitis death in St. Lucie County last month, but are awaiting test results. Symptoms of the disease can range from headaches and fevers usually associated with the flu to coma and death resulting from brain inflammation. In between, people can experience a stiff neck, tiredness and irritability. Other severe symptoms include extreme sleepiness, tremors and seizures. The death rate from St. Louis encephalitis typically is 7 percent. Eight people died during the last Florida outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis in 1977. The state usually has one to three cases a year, according to Ernie Durfee, a spokesman for the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services. Florida's first confirmed fatality was Alvena Patton, who had been in a coma since Aug. 21, Durfee said. Her husband said his family hopes her death will cause officials and residents to take warnings more seriously. ``The county needs to get serious about this virus,'' said Harry Patton. ``They need to get spray trucks out and try to stop this thing. I know it costs a lot of money, but people's lives are at stake.'' Mahan said that although mosquito eradication efforts have been increased, the recent increase in rainfall could prolong the current mosquito infestation until drier, colder weather arrives.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Interior Minister Gava Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Interior Minister Antonio Gava resigned on Monday, citing health reasons. Gava, a 60-year-old Christian Democrat, had held the post the past two governments. He said his illness prevented him from ``totally devoting'' himself to the job. According to the ANSA news agency, Gava suffers from diabetes. Premier Giulio Andreotti immediately named Vincenzo Scotti as Gava's replacement. Scotti, 57, also a Christian Democrat, has been serving as the party's leader in the Chamber of Deputies. Gava came under fire recently from the opposition Communists for the government's record in fighting organized crime. But in his resignation letter, Gava defended his performance and said he felt ``especially satisfied'' with his contribution to new government anti-crime measures expected to be announced this week. In addition to interior minister, Gava served in previous governments as minister of posts and telecommunications and finance minister. Scotti has served as labor minister and culture minister.

DOC.HEAD: Snow In The Mountains Of The Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell across the Northwest on Monday, with snow at higher elevations, and rain also fell on the northern Plains. Rain, with snow in the mountains, extended over Washington, the Idaho Panhandle and western Montana. In Oregon, showers in the northern Cascades were expected to turn to snow later in the day. Six inches of new snow covered Stampede Pass in Washington's Cascade range at daybreak, but snowfall diminished during the morning. Showers also were scattered in east-central South Dakota and southwestern Minnesota. Elsewhere, showers also were scattered along the southern and eastern coasts of Florida. Jacksonville, Fla., warmed to a record-tying high of 90. Monday's early morning low for the Lower 48 states was 19 at Butte, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 37 at Yellowstone National Park to 93 at Beeville, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Company Recalling Cough Drug
DOC.TEXT: A drug company is recalling three lots of a bronchodialator drug product that may have been packaged in mislabeled cartons, the Food and Drug Administration said Monday. The product is Metaproterenol Sulfate Inhalation Solution, USP 5 percent. Some bottles of the product may have been packaged in an outer folding carton labeled Carbinoxamine Compound Drops, which is used to treat cough and upper respiratory symptoms associated with allergy or colds in children. The FDA advised parents who have been prescribed Carbinoxamine Compound Drops that the correct medication is purple in color with a grape flavor and grape odor. It uses a dropper with four distinct graduation lines between \ and 1 milliliter. The inhalation solution is pale yellow and its dropper shows measuring lines at 0.2 milliliter and 0.3 milliliter. If used as pediatric drops in infants, the inhalation solution could cause nervousness, excessively rapid heartbeat, tremor and nausea. It also could cause hypertension, palpitation, vomiting and bad taste. Both products are made by Pharmaceutical Basics Inc. of Morton Grove, Ill, which issued the recalled in cooperation with the FDA. The FDA also recommended that pharmacists review their records since February and notify any patient who had been given either of the products so they could examine the medications and their labels. The recalled lots of Metaproterenol Sulfate Inhalation Solution, USP 5 percent, are numbers 18222K, 18421H and 18421C. Packages of Carbinoxamine Compound Drops with the same lot numbers also are being recalled.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Industry To Lose $1 Billion In Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: U.S. airlines, faced with a $10 billion boost in the cost of jet fuel because of the Persian Gulf crisis, will incur a $1 billion loss in the final quarter of 1990, the president of the Air Transport Association said Monday. ``The airline industry has never lost that much in an entire year,'' Robert J. Aaronson, the association's president, said in a speech prepared for delivery in Montreal. The industry had profits of $170 million on total revenues of $28 billion in the first six months of the year, the ATA said. Third-quarter figures were not yet available. The airline spokesman called for intervention to stop ``rampant speculation'' in petroleum products on the commodities markets and said rising prices do not reflect the fact that adequate petroleum supplies are available on world markets. ``Soaring fuel prices, which have now risen by more than 100 percent, thrust the airline industry into a crisis the likes of which it has never seen,'' Aaronson said. ``The effects of almost daily rises in jet fuel costs on top of a softening economy can only exacerbate the weakened financial condition of the airlines and lead to wide-scale layoffs and service reductions throughout the industry,'' he said. The airlines have already laid off 10,000 employees and delayed delivery of ``scores of new jets,'' Aaronson said. ' The highly competitive nature of the airlines makes it virtually impossible to cover all costs simply by raising prices,'' Aaronson said. According to Aviation Daily, the average price per gallon paid for jet fuel on the spot market on Friday was $1.42, up from 57 cents a gallon in the days immediately before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Aaronson, the airlines spokesman, urged the commodities markets ``to limit the volatility of speculative trading in oil.'' ``The market does not reflect the reality of the supply situation, and it is incumbent on the commodities markets to limit this rampant speculation,'' he said. ``Speculators are amassing fortunes at the expense of ordinary citizens and businesses,'' he said. Aaronson also called on the Bush administration to reconsider billions of dollars in new taxes on the air travel industry that have been proposed during current budget negotiations. ``No industry or sector of the economy has been hit as hard as the airline industry during this fuel crisis,'' he said. ``Now is the worst possible time to put additional tax burdens on an industry already faced with costs beyond its control - an industry that is scrambling for economic survival.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Issues Arrest Warrant For Defendant in Pit Bull Case
LaserPhoto DX3
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of staging a dogfight for a television news report that cost a star reporter her job was ordered arrested on Monday after he failed to appear in court. The other defendants, former KCNC-TV reporter Wendy Bergen and former station photographers Scott Wright and Jim Stair, were advised of their rights. The three, along with the missing man, Guy Walker, were indicted by the Jefferson County grand jury in September on 15 felony charges accusing them of staging pit-bull fights and lying to the grand jury. The fights allegedly were staged for Bergen's series ``Blood Sport,'' an expose of underground dog fighting telecast during the May ``sweeps'' period when the race for ratings becomes particularly competitive. Jefferson County District Judge Gaspar Perricone issued an arrest warrant for Walker, who faces two counts of dog fighting. Walker's attorney, Antonio Lucero, said his client did not have transportation to Monday's hearing. Perricone scheduled a Dec. 14 motions hearing, and gave the Jefferson County district attorney's office another month after that date to respond. No trial date was set. The judge denied the defendants' request to bar television and newspaper cameras from the courtroom. Bergen, an award-winning investigative reporter, resigned shortly before a grand jury issued indictments claiming she repeatedly lied to the panel about whether the dogfight was staged for her show. Wright and Stair also resigned. Bergen claimed a tape showing a pit bull fight arrived anonymously in the mail. But prosecutors say station photographers made portions of the tape. Bergen spoke briefly at the hearing, saying only ``Yes, I do,'' when asked if she understood her rights and the charges against her. Attorneys for the three former station employees said they will move to dismiss the charges. Bergen was indicted on nine felony charges, including arranging the fights, paying for them, lying about the source of the videotape, lying to KCNC management and encouraging a friend to lie to the grand jury. Stair and Wright are charged with being an accessory to a crime and conspiracy to commit perjury. Stair also was indicted on one count each of dog fighting and conspiracy to commit a dogfight. Bergen's lawyers have said they plan to challenge evidence obtained from Bergen through the use of an informant wired with a hidden microphone. The informant, Mark I. Labriola, has admitted helping Bergen stage several dog fights. He was not charged under a deal with proseuctors.

DOC.HEAD: Bulldozers Clear Key Intersection, Unifying War-Torn Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with Green Line another major dividing line to fall since Berlin Wall year. Picks up 16th pvs, `The major...'
DOC.TEXT: President Elias Hrawi started dismantling Beirut's dividing Green Line on Monday to unify what he hopes will be a militia-free capital after the defeat of rebel Gen. Michel Aoun. Government bulldozers removed mounds of earth, rocks and other obstacles from the Galerie Semaan crossing, on the highway linking Moslem south Beirut with the Christian suburbs of Hazmiyeh and Baabda. Motorists then drove across the intersection, waving their hands to helmeted Lebanese soldiers and honking their horns in jubilation. Lebanese and Syrian army engineering units removed mines from the intersection Saturday, when Syrian and Lebanese troops advanced behind a curtain of heavy air and artillery shelling to end Aoun's rebellion. Syrian and Lebanese troops crushed Aoun's 11-month mutiny in an eight-hour assault Saturday that killed 160 and wounded 800. Aoun remained in refuge in the French Embassy for the third day Monday, with Lebanon insisting that he face trial on a variety of charges, including the theft of state funds. In Paris, French President Francois Mitterrand said he would reject any Lebanese request to hand Aoun over. Scores of his supporters occupied Lebanon's embassy in Paris and its consulate in Marseille, demanding Aoun's safe passage to France. Aoun began his mutiny in November 1989 after rejecting an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war and calling Hrawi a Syrian puppet. The peace plan provides for the traditionally dominant Christians to share power with the Moslem majority. Syrian forces arrested six of Aoun's top lieutenants, including his chief of military intelligence, Col. Amer Chehab. They were interrogating them at the Lebanese Defense Ministry, which was seized from Aoun's troops. The Galerie Semaan crossing was flooded with cars less than 30 minutes after the army command of Gen. Emile Lahoud declared it ``safe'' for civilian traffic. Lebanese army engineering units were removing mines from areas along Beirut's five-mile Green Line in preparation for dismantling it. The Green Line, which has divided Beirut into Moslem and Christian sectors since the outbreak of the civil war, was torn down in the early days of former President Amin Gemayel's term in office in September 1982. However, Moslem and leftist gunmen regained their positions along the line when they ousted Gemayel's Christian-led army from Beirut's Moslem sector in a bloody confrontation in February 1984. ``The Green Line is expected to be totally dismantled in a week or so,'' said the police spokesman, speaking anonymously in line with regulations. Dismantling the Green Line would be the first step toward the creation of a militia-free ``Greater Beirut'' extending 22 miles along the Mediterranean coast and covering the capital's nearby suburbs at the foothills of the central mountains. Bringing down the Green Line would be one more major dividing line to fall the past year - the Berlin Wall, built in 1961 by East Germany as an ideological division to the West, was torn apart last fall during a popular uprising. The major obstacles are the presence of Christian, Shiite and Druse militias in that territory. Hrawi met Monday with a six-officer delegation from the Syrian military command and discussed with them, among other topics, the Greater Beirut plan, a presidential statement said. It did not disclose further details. The Syrian team included Maj. Gen. Saeed Bayrakdar, commander of Syria's 40,000 troops in Lebanon, and Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kenaan, chief of Syria's military intelligence in the country. Syria, in Lebanon under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate, considers the country its strategic backyard. The fall of Aoun has strengthened its hold on the country. Hrawi instructed a two-man government committee to start discussions with the various militias to ``arrange for their withdrawal from the Greater Beirut,'' a government source said. The army ordered a battalion of its military police to enforce law and order in the 80-square-mile enclave formerly controlled by Aoun. Police said leftist and Moslem militias moved into some Christian villages after Aoun's troops collapsed to settle old scores with traditional civil war foes. A police spokesman said Shiite Moslem gunmen of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah advanced to Beirut's Christian suburb of Hadath on Sunday and were involved in ``kidnapping Christians and looting houses.'' A pro-Syrian Christian militia led by Elie Hobeika also entered Hadath and clashed briefly with Hezbollah late Sunday ``over looting.'' Four people were killed and 10 wounded. Leftist militiamen of the Syrian Social Nationalist Party, traditional enemies of Lebanon's right-wing Christians, slipped into the mountain resort of Bekfaya northeast of Beirut, stormed Phalange Party offices and kidnapped a number of Phalangists, the police spokesman said. The Phalange Party, the largest right-wing Christian political group, was opposed to Aoun's mutiny.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Breaks Out at Lebanese Consulate
DOC.TEXT: A suspected arson fire damaged three floors of the Lebanese Consulate and injured an employee and five firefighters, the Fire Department said Monday. The fire broke out on the ground floor of the consulate in Manhattan on Sunday evening and spread to two upper floors before being extinguished, said Fire Department spokesman Tom Kelly. Kelly said a flammable liquid was found at the scene but the cause of the blaze was still being investigated. The consulate had received recent telephoned threats, Kelly said, but declined to elaborate. Three firefighters suffered neck injuries when a ceiling partially collapsed, another broke his wrist and a fifth suffered cuts on his hand, officials said. A consulate employee who tried to put out the fire with an extinguisher suffered smoke inhalation but wasn't seriously hurt, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Israel, Bjt
Bush Administration Displeased By Rejection Of UN Mission
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 6th graf: ``Secretary of State,'' and grafs 11-13: ``State Department,'' with State Dept. confirmation of Baker message to Levy; following graf edited for transition
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration reacted Monday with mild displeasure to an Israeli government decision not to cooperate with a United Nations team investigating the shooting deaths of 19 Palestinian Arabs. ``We want to see that U.N. resolution fully implemented,'' President Bush said as he flew to Texas and Nebraska to raise funds and make speeches for Republican candidates. ``We were a part of it and we think it's the right step. So I'll just leave it there,'' Bush told reporters who traveled with him on Air Force One, the presidential jet. The State Department, going a step further in criticizing the Israeli Cabinet's decision, said through spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler: ``The United States voted for this resolution because we think it is right. And therefore we are disappointed that the Israeli government has decided not to cooperate with the mission.'' The U.S. official added: ``In fact, we think that failure to cooperate denies Israel an opportunity to present its case to the Secretary-General. We are hopeful that the Secretary-General's people will be able to carry out this mission.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III, in a message to Foreign Minister David Levy before the vote, ``made clear our sense of concern over Israel's handling of the situation,'' Ms. Tutwiler said later. The 19 Palestinians were killed by Israeli police on the hallowed Temple Mount, sacred to Moslems and Jews, last Monday. The shootings were the climax to a riot that began when Palestinians threw rocks onto Jewish worshipers praying below at the Western Wall, a sacred site to Jews. Police first used tear gas and rubber bullets, then live ammunition. The United States drafted a resolution for the Security Council to condemn the Israeli police while also regretting interference with worship. The Palestine Liberation Organization, through Yemen, proposed censuring Israel and establishing U.N. oversight of Israel's treatment of Palestinians. Finally, the Council last Friday night adopted a modified version of the U.S. draft, authorizing Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to send investigators to Jerusalem but without calling for permanent U.N. involvement. Israel's Cabinet on Sunday issued a communique calling the resolution ``completely unacceptable.'' It said Israel would not receive the delegation. State Department spokeswoman Tutwiler, confirming reports in the Israeli press, said Baker had interceded with Levy before the vote. In a message through the U.S. Embassy in Tel Aviv, he told Levy that admitting the U.N. mission would not have set a precedent since Israel had accepted a representative of Perez de Cuellar in June, the U.S. official said. ``We would like to see this issue concluded and hope that Israel will find a way to work with the Secretary-General's representative,'' Ms. Tutwiler said in a statement. Israeli reports said Baker wrote Levy he was worried that rejection would focus world attention on Israel instead of Iraq, whose annexation of Kuwait the United States is trying to reverse. According to the newspaper Yediot Ahronot, Baker told Levy: ``At a time when I am sure that you would have preferred that there would not have been any Security Council decision at all, we exerted every effort, including threats of a veto, against the much harsher proposal that had been approved. ``We supported this decision that we felt that Israel should have been prepared and capable of dealing with the violence and rioting without killing 20 people or injuring 150. In the fact that they were not prepared, Israel played into the hands of (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein... ``I am worried that if you reject this mission that is about to travel to Israel, you will put Israel, and not Iraq, at the center of world attention.'' Baker also told Levy the United States would ask the Security Council to reconvene ``to reach a new decision'' on Iraq's aggression against Kuwait. ``We will not allow Saddam Hussein to get off the hook,'' the letter said. Spokeswoman Tutwiler did not confirm the authenticity of the letter or release a text here. She said she had to consult Baker. The administration has taken the position it was not connecting Iraq's invasion of Kuwait with the dispute between Israel and Palestinians. Saddam Hussein has called for considering the two issues simultaneously. Bush in a speech to the U.N. General Assembly two weeks ago said an Iraqi withdrawal could lead to opportunities to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian issue.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Arrested, 2 At Large in Armed Holdup of Card Players
DOC.TEXT: Four masked men burst into a house firing guns early Monday and took 30,000 worth of cash and jewelry from a group of men police said were gambling. At least two of the gunmen crashed through a plate-glass window to escape when police arrived. Two men were later arrested and charged with armed robbery and the other two remained at large, said police in this Portland suburb. Police recovered $5,000 in cash and $6,000 worth of solid gold jewelry, said Police Chief Ron Allanach. Gunmen wearing nylon stockings over their heads forced about 30 card players to lie face down on the floor, firing shots as they did so, police said. They went from one player to the next, pointing a gun barrel at each victim's head and stealing cash and jewelry, Allanach said. The gamblers were believed to be of Vietnamese and Chinese background, said the chief. Arrested were Li Yi Zhou, 18, of the Chinatown section of Boston, and Chanh Tran, 18, of New York City, were being held on armed robbery charges in lieu of $50,000 bond, said police.

DOC.HEAD: First Steps Taken to Remove `Green Line' Dividing Beirut
With AM-Lebanon, Bjt
LaserPhoto BEI1
DOC.TEXT: Instead of gunfire and explosions along Beirut's Green Line, there were sounds of hope Monday as a bulldozer toppled a section of the five-mile border dividing the Christian and Moslem sides. Soon, the battle-ravaged passage was filled with motorists honking car horns in celebration. The first steps in dismantling the 15-year-old barrier came after Syrian and government troops crushed rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun's 11-month mutiny against President Elias Hrawi on Saturday. Aoun opposed an Arab League peace plan that Hrawi was elected last November to implement. With Hrawi's forces in control of Christian east Beirut, a cautious reunification effort was begun. According to plans in the always-volatile Lebanese capital, unrestricted access between east Beirut and the Moslem western district may be possible next week. The Green Line - a zone of earthen mounds, barbed wire, sandbags, overturned buses and other debris - has stood as a symbol to Lebanon's civil war since it was first set up in April 1975. Unlike the Berlin Wall that was erected for ideological reasons in 1961 to separate East from West - and fell during a popular uprising last year, the Green Line took shape gradually and along religious lines as the battles intensified. It took its name from a similar zone erected in 1974 on the eastern Mediterranean island of Cyprus to divide Greek- and Turkish-controlled areas. The Green Line was partially dismantled in 1983 under former President Amin Gemayel's administration with the help of a multinational peacekeeping force. But it was re-fortified in February 1984 when Moslem militia drove Gemayel's Christian army units out of the Moslem sector, beginning years of killings, kidnappings and violence. The Green Line is now dotted with bushes and undergrowth that have sprouted amid the ruins in a city once called the Paris of the Middle East. Tree stumps unrooted from parks stand in long-vacated highways amid twisted traffic lights and rusted road signs. Many roads and alleys are littered with live shells and grenades. The line curves from the war-battered port district through the ruins of the once-bustling downtown commercial district to the foothills of the central mountains overlooking the city. The hundreds of high-rise apartment blocks on either side of the line are riddled with bullet holes and scorch marks from exploding shells. These were the sniper nests, where militiamen from both sides clashed almost daily, killing hundreds of people. Many of victims were women hanging their washing or civilians trapped in the open when the gun battles flared without warning. Despite the encouraging signs Monday, Hrawi still faces a struggle in a country plagued by deep hostilities. There are still Christian and Moslem militia positions on the line. But commanders pledge these will gradually be abandoned.

DOC.HEAD: Corporate Lawyer Charged in Illegal Enema Orders
DOC.TEXT: The former chief legal officer for the company that makes Advil, Anacin and Preparation H was arraigned Monday on charges he pretended to be a doctor and illegally ordered enemas for hospital patients. Roger Kapp, 54, was arrested after police put a tape recorder and a number tracing device on the home telephone of a Lenox Hill Hospital patient. Authorities allege that Kapp ordered an enema for the patient, then telephoned her at home to discuss the procedure. The calls were traced to Kapp's extension at American Home Products, a manufacturer of medicines and medical supplies. Kapp was arraigned in Manhattan Criminal Court on two counts of second-degree criminal impersonation. Each misdemeanor is punishable by up to six months in jail. Judge John Walsh released Kapp without bail and scheduled a Nov. 5 hearing. ``The conduct in question arises from a medical problem,'' said Kapp's lawyer, Barry Bohrer. ``Mr. Kapp has taken steps to address and cure that problem.'' The charges are based on two calls, one in April and one in May. In each case, the caller used the name of a physician actually on staff. Kapp was chief legal counsel for American Home Products for two years until he left about three months ago, said Charles Hagan, who served as chief legal counsel before Kapp. A June memorandum signed by Kenneth Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, warned member institutions that several hospitals had received calls similar to those Kapp has been accused of making.

DOC.HEAD: Students Strike for Independence in Ukraine
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of students went on strike Monday in Kiev, the capital of the Ukraine, to support hunger strikers' demands for independence, Soviet media reported. As many as 50,000 students blocked central streets and marched to the Ukrainian parliament building, where some held a sit-in protest, the independent news agencies Interfax and Postfactum said. The Ukraine is one of 13 Soviet republics seeking greater autonomy from the central government in Moscow. Although its parliament has declared sovereignty - defined as the right to overrule national laws - the students contend the republic should move more quickly and decisively toward secession. The news agencies said 70 to 200 of the protesters broke through a ring of security guards around the parliament building to hold the sit-in. Meanwhile, another column of students marched to Kiev University, occpied one of its main buildings, hoisted a blue and yellow Ukrainian flag and announced an ``occupation strike,'' Interfax said. Postfactum said veterans of the war in Afghanistan ``took part in organizing the demonstration and protecting its participants.'' But no police action against the students was reported. The state-run Soviet press has devoted little attention to the Ukrainian student movement. Interfax and Postfactum are independent agencies established the past two years that distribute information primarily by fax. Student leaders could not be reached by telephone Monday night for independent confirmation. Several dozen students set up a tent camp and began the hunger strike in Kiev two weeks ago. Seven opposition members of parliament joined the hunger strike five days ago, and an unknown number of additional hunger strikers have since set up ``solidarity camps'' in five other Ukrainian cities, according to Interfax. Oles Doniy, a leader of the Ukrainian Students' Union, reportedly read a list of demands to the parliament on Monday, including the resignation of the regional government. Leonid Kravchuk, chairman of the Ukrainian Council of Ministers, refused to step down but told the parliament he was willing to start a dialogue with the students, Postfactum said. The students are also demanding that the Ukraine nationalize Communist Party property, refuse to sign a new union treaty with the other Soviet republics, require Ukrainians drafted into the Red army to serve within the republic's borders, dissolve the republic's parliament and call new elections. Postfactum quoted a student coordinating group as saying that 14 vocational schools, 17 higher educational institutions, 11 technical schools and several research institutes and high schools were on strike.

DOC.HEAD: Opposing Forces in the Persian Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The marshaling of the U.S.-led multinational force in the Persian Gulf is almost complete. Here is a breakdown of the troops:

UNITED STATES - Officials say about 200,000 troops, including those aboard ships, are in the gulf region or en route. The deployment, which could reach 250,000 troops, is expected to be completed by the end of October. Ground forces in Saudi Arabia include the 82nd ``All American'' Airborne Division; the 101st ``Screaming Eagles'' Airborne Division; the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, with about 200 M-1 Abrams tanks and 300 Bradley Fighting Vehicles; the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade; 197th Mechanized Infantry Brigade; the 1st Cavalry Division and the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment. Amphibious capability is provided by 45,000 men of the 1st, 4th and 6th Marine Expeditionary Brigades. There is a Special Forces contingent from the 1st Special Operations Command. The U.S. fleet in the gulf, the Arabian Sea and the eastern Mediterranean totals about 55 ships. They include the aircraft carriers Independence, Saratoga and John F. Kennedy; the battleship Wisconsin with 32 Tomahawk cruise missiles, five missile cruisers, four destroyers, several frigates, plus supply ships and six to eight nuclear submarines. The aircraft carriers have a combined strike force of 180 A-6 Intruder fighters, F/A-18 Hornet fighters and F-14 Tomcats. The Marines have about 60 AV-8B Harrier jump-jets. The Pentagon has also sent 22 F117A Stealth fighter-bombers to unspecified bases; 14 long-range F-111F bombers to Incirlik airbase in southwest Turkey, and another squadron to Spain. There are an estimated 150 F-16s and F-15s; more than 70 A-10 tank-killing Thunderbolts, and unspecified numbers of F-4 Wild Weasel air-defense suppression jets and other combat aircraft deployed at 30 airbases in the region. A squadron of 6-8 B-52G strategic bombers is on the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia. At least 17 U.S. servicemen have been killed in training and other accidents in the gulf region.

BRITAIN - A three-ship flotilla permanently stationed in the gulf has been beefed up to 12 ships, including a missile destroyer, two missile frigates and three minesweepers. They have support ships. Four squadrons of Tornado and Jaguar interceptors and ground attack jets are in Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Oman. Three Nimrod maritime reconnaissance aircraft are in Oman. The 7th Armored Brigade, successors to the famous ``Desert Rats'' of World War II, have started arriving with 120 Challenger tanks and 9,500 troops in Britain's biggest military operation since the 1982 Falklands War against Argentina. British troop strength is expected to reach 15,000.

FRANCE - It has about 14 ships and 13,000 troops in the gulf region. The warships include a guided-missile cruiser, two missile destroyers, two frigates and one corvette with support vessels. France is sending three squadrons of interceptors and fighter-bombers. The 4,000-troop Rapid Action Force is deployed with Arab forces in Saudi Arabia's northeastern desert. It includes the 5th Combat Helicopter Regiment with 42 gunships; the Foreign Legion's 3nd Infantry Regiment with anti-tank missiles; the 1st Spahis Cavalry Regiment with armored vehicles, and an anti-aircraft missile unit. A company of 190 paratroopers equipped for chemical warfare is in the United Arab Emirates. The French deployment is the nation's biggest overseas operation since the Algerian war in the early 1960s.

ITALY - The frigates Libeccio, Orsa and Zeffiro and a support ship, the Stromboli, are in the gulf. The corvettes Minerva and Stinge are in the eastern Mediterranean replacing U.S. units assigned to the gulf. A squadron of eight Tornado fighters is based near Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, to provide air cover for Italian warships. No ground force deployment is planned.

CANADA - The destroyers Athabaskan and Terra Nova and the supply ship Protecteur are heading for the gulf. A squadron of 18 CF-18 fighter jets and 450 military personnel based in West Germany are in Saudi Arabia.
NETHERLANDS - The frigates Witte de With and Pieter Florisz are in the Gulf of Oman. The combat supply ship Zuiderkruis is expected there in November.
SPAIN - The frigate Santa Maria is in the Gulf of Oman. The corvettes Cazadora and Descubierta are in the Bab el Mandeb Strait in the southern Red Sea.
AUSTRALIA - The guided-missile frigates Adelaide and Darwin and the supply ship Success are in the gulf region.
BELGIUM - The minehunters Iris and Myosotis with the supply ship Zinnia are in the Gulf of Oman. The Belgians have also commited four C-130 military transport planes.

ARGENTINA - The destroyer Almirante Brown and the frigate Spiro are expected to arrive in the gulf region soon. Both West German-built warships are armed with anti-ship Exocet missiles. A 100-man army unit will also be sent.

SOVIET UNION - The Udaloy-class destroyer Admiral Tributs and an anti-submarine ship are in the Gulf of Oman. Moscow has indicated it would send ground forces, but only under U.N. command. The Slava-class missile cruiser Chervona Ukraina and the Sovremenny-class destroyer Bystry passed through the Suez Canal Oct.4, ostensibly en route to join the Soviet Pacific Fleet. But they could be deployed in the gulf region.
GREECE - Greece has sent its most advanced frigate, the Limnos, to the eastern Mediterranean. Greece is supplying merchant ships for the U.S. sealift.

WEST GERMANY - It is providing merchant ships to transport U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia and has provided $2 billion toward the multinational force. Germany's constitution prohibits it from sending military forces outside its borders.
DENMARK - It has sent a corvette, the Olfert Fischer. Danish merchant ships are helping in the U.S. sealift.
NORWAY - It has sent the Coast Guard cutter Andenes to support the Danish corvette. Norway has offered anti-chemical warfare equipment.
PORTUGAL - It has commited a naval support ship to the gulf.
POLAND - It will send a military field hospital and a hospital ship to the gulf.
CZECHOSLOVAKIA - It has sent a 200-man army unit with anti-chemical warfare equipment.

DOC.HEAD: NICOSIA: equipment
DOC.TEXT: GULF COOPERATION COUNCIL (Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Qatar and, until Aug. 2, Kuwait) - A rapid deployment force of up to 10,000 troops is based at Hafr al-Batin, Saudi Arabia, 40 miles south of the Kuwait border. They and allied Arab-Islamic forces form the first line of defense. The GCC force has been beefed up with about 7,000 soldiers of Kuwait's 20,000-man army who escaped their country when Iraq invaded. Most of their heavy weapons were captured by Iraq, but some combat jets and tanks were saved. The GCC and other Gulf Arab forces total around 144,500 men, 330 combat aircraft, 800 tanks and 36 major naval units. They are supported by: EGYPT - It has pledged up to 20,000 troops with tanks and heavy artillery. About 14,000 troops - including paratroopers, commandos, chemical warfare specialists and infantry - are in Saudi Arabia. Several thousand more soldiers from the 3rd Armored Division and the 3rd Mechanized Infantry Division, are expected in the next few days. Five hundred troops are in the United Arab Emirates.

SYRIA - About 4,000 troops, mostly elite Special Forces units who have fought the Israelis and others in Lebanon, are in Saudi Arabia. A 15,000-man armored division, with about 270 tanks and heavy artillery, is preparing to go to Saudi Arabia. Some troops are based in the United Arab Emirates.

PAKISTAN - It has pledged to send 5,000 troops, with 2,000 already in Saudi Arabia and 2,000 in the United Arab Emirates, along with 1,000 advisers. About 5,000 advisers are already attached to the Saudi armed forces.
MOROCCO - It has 1,200 troops in Saudi Arabia and 500 in the United Arab Emirates.
BANGLADESH - It has 2,000 troops, including engineering and infantry units, in Saudi Arabia.

IRAQ - The army has seven corps totaling 55 divisions. There are 555,000 regular troops and 480,000 reserves. Regular forces include seven divisions of elite Republican Guards. Iraq claims a militia called the Popular Army has 5 million men. Saddam Hussein has 5,500 tanks, including about 500 high-quality T-72s and 1,000 medium-quality T-62s; 3,500 artillery guns; 200 multiple rocket launchers; an estimated 500 surface-to-surface missiles; more than 330 surface-to-air missile launchers, including captured Kuwaiti systems; 500-plus combat aircraft, including Soviet-supplied long-range Su-24 fighter-bombers and advanced MiG-29 interceptors. The equipment is spread around an estimated 25 airbases. Its main naval units are a training frigate with anti-submarine torpedoes, an estimated eight Soviet-built missile-attack craft and six torpedo boats. In Kuwait, Iraq has an estimated 10 divsions, four of them armored, totaling 170,000 troops; 3,500 T-55 and T-62 tanks, and 1,700 artillery pieces in what appear to be defensive positions. About 250,000 men, including the seven Republican Guard divisions with up to 1,300 tanks and 750 guns, are in southern Iraq as a tactical reserve. Silkworm anti-ship missiles are believed to have been deployed to counter any U.S. amphibious landing in Kuwait. FROG-7 battlefield missiles have also been deployed, including batteries captured in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Backtracks from Earlier Proposal on Fines
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department on Monday urged adoption of sentencing guidelines for corporations convicted of crimes that would force judges to impose fines based on the seriousness of the offense. But the department shied away from a proposal it had earlier advanced under which a company involved in a massive fraud could be fined twice its gain or twice the loss to its victims. The department had endorsed this proposal last February when the U..S. Sentencing Commission was debating two different proposals for corporate sentencing guidelines. The department rescinded its support for one of the proposals under consideration, as well as its own suggestion, after receiving an inquiry from the White House, which had been contacted by business groups expressing concern over stiff fines. The letter by then-Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer endorsing the proposal had been sent without the permission of Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, the department said. Since that dispute, which contributed to Ayer's resignation on May 11, the Justice Department has reviewed its position. It reiterated its support Monday for a proposal that sets fines according to the severity of the offense. The commission was set up under a 1984 law designed to eliminate disparity in sentences. It has already promulgated complicated guidelines for punishing individuals according to the type of offense and the defendant's criminal history. But last winter the commission put off adopting guidelines for sentencing corporations convicted of crimes. ``The system we are advocating will result in stiff corporate sanctions,'' deputy assistant attorney general Paul L. Maloney told reporters. ``We support a system of imposing fines that captures the seriousness of the offense as measured by the commission's existing ranking of offenses'' in the guidelines for individuals, Thornburgh said in a letter to the commission that was released by the department. ``We believe that an offense-level approach, rather than an approach based on gain or loss, accomplishes this purpose,'' Thornburgh said. The seriousness of the offense, and therefore the size of the fine, would be determined by a number of factors, including whether top officials were involved in the crime or whether the company had a history of similar misconduct. Bribery or threats to national security also could lead to higher fines, the department said. Under the proposal outlined by the Justice Department, companies that report wrongdoing as soon as it is discovered and cooperate with prosecutors would be credited with lower fines. Corporate lawyer Victoria Toensing, a former senior Justice Department official who had argued against adoption of earlier proposals, praised the department's letter as offering a ``sensible approach'' for punishing corporate misbehavior. The Justice Department's proposal would help courts distinguish between responsible corporations that are prosecuted for the actions of rogue employees and those whose management flagantly flout the law, she said. The department essentially endorses the same proposal it had supported earlier this year. But Thornburgh's letter said the department no longer supports a provision it had advanced to fine companies the greater amount of tiwce its gain or the loss to victims. Maloney said deparment reviewed comments filed with the Sentencing Commission in deciding on its new position. The White House approved the letter that Thornburgh sent the Sentencing Commission but did not participate in the department's decisions, Maloney said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds Joubert Guilty in Child's Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with reax from Joubert, lawyers, jury forewoman. Pickup 9th graf pvs, `Because of...' Liisa is cq in 6th graf
DOC.TEXT: A man already facing the death penalty in Nebraska for killing two boys there was found guilty of murder Monday in the stabbing and strangling of an 11-year-old boy more than eight years ago in Portland. John J. Joubert, 27, originally from Portland, was found guilty in the August 1982 killing of Richard Stetson. Joubert sat expressionless and blinked as the jury's verdict was read after less than two hours of deliberations. No sentencing date was set. Joubert already is scheduled to be executed in Nebraska's electric chair on Dec. 7 for murdering two boys, age 12 and 13, there in 1983. He had been an airman stationed at Offutt Air Force Base outside Omaha when those crimes took place. Prosecutors had said Joubert would be returned to Nebraska to face the sentence there no matter what happened at his trial in Maine. His lawyer, Liisa Hamilton, said she expects him to appeal the Maine verdict, and will seek to withdraw his guilty pleas in the Nebraska murders. Assistant Attorney General Eric Wright, who prosecuted Joubert in Maine, said he would seek Maine's maximum life prison sentence for Joubert. Wright also explained why Maine sought to try a man already on death row in another state. ``I think people in this state need to understand that we wanted to do our best to make sure that if he ever got out from under his death sentence in Nebraska he'd have no place to go but Thomaston to die,'' said Wright, referring to a state prison. Joubert's reaction to the verdict was, ``No comment.'' Before the jurors began deliberations, they were challenged by both the defense and the prosecution to carefully compare casts of Joubert's teeth to photos of bite marks on the victim's leg. Wright said the casts match the tooth marks. Hamilton said they don't necessarily match, and said she was unconvinced the marks on Stetson's body were left by teeth. But the marks proved pivotal in the jury's final decision, as did testimony from a journalist who interviewed Joubert after the killing, said forewoman Terry Blazek, of Waldoboro. Blazek said jurors were unaware of Joubert's Nebraska convictions. ``Every single one of us had no idea about what happened in the other states,'' she said. Because of pretrial publicity, Joubert's trial was moved from Portland to Wiscasset, a small coastal town about 30 miles to the north. Prosecutors relied heavily on testimony from a journalist who wrote a book about Joubert and claimed that, during an interview about his crimes, Joubert did not deny he killed Stetson. In his final address to the jury, Wright took issue with the defense attorney's attempts to link an alternative suspect to the crime, saying that there was no evidence to support that. Wright also labeled as ``unreliable'' the testimony of Dr. Norman D. Sperber, a forensic dentist called by the defense who said it was unlikely Joubert's teeth left the marks. The prosecutor said Sperber's testimony was riddled with inconsistencies and contradictions. Hamilton attacked the testimony of Mark Pettit, a television journalist who has interviewed Joubert for a book he wrote about the defendant and his crimes. Pettit testified that when he asked Joubert if he killed Stetson, Joubert responded: ``I can't lie to you. I can't tell you I didn't do it.'' Hamilton questioned why Pettit failed to go to the police with that information. ``Why would he make that statement to a reporter, of all people?'' said Hamilton.

DOC.HEAD: Pranksters Hide Door to MIT President's Office
DOC.TEXT: An administrator wanted to show the new president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology the door to his office Monday. But he couldn't find it. Student pranksters wanted to lay out a welcome for Charles M. Vest, the university's 15th president. They hid the doorway behind a bulletin board with clippings from the student newspaper - the banner headline read ``Vest Takes Over Monday.'' The ``hack'' - as such pranks are known at MIT - was so successful that the administrator thought he was on the wrong floor. Vest, who arrived just after the confusion had cleared, was undeterred. The bulletin board was moved to a place of honor in the hallway. Vest went to work, toting a bottle of champagne given him by the pranksters. Vest succeeds Paul E. Gray, who had served since 1980. He served as provost and vice-president for academic affairs at the University of Michigan for two years. Before that he was dean of the university's College of Engineering for three years.

DOC.HEAD: Exiled Kuwaitis Vow to Return; Reports Saddam Fencing Off North
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details of communique released at conference end, details on oilfield. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of prominent Kuwaiti exiles vowed Monday at the conclusion of a three-day conference to return home with the al-Sabah rulers and liberate Kuwait from the Iraqi occupying forces. They insisted in a communique there will be ``no bargaining and no negotiating on Kuwait's sovereignty, independence and territorial security.'' Conference sources said it was tantamount to a message to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein rejecting any settlement that falls short of a total pullout of Iraqi troops that invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Reports from Moscow said Saddam might withdraw in return for some Kuwaiti territory along the Persian Gulf. And in Tunis, Yasser Arafat, chief of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said Saddam was showing a ``certain flexibility'' regarding the occupation. Iraq invaded its oil-rich neighbor after a dispute over the Kuwaiti islands of Warba and Bubiyan, which would provide Iraq with an outlet on the gulf. Saddam also claimed Kuwait was stealing oil from the Rumailah oilfield that crosses 2 miles into Kuwaiti territory. Nearly all the oilfield is in Iraq. Conference sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Saddam appeared to be contemplating a partial withdrawal that would let him keep Bubiyan, Warba and the Rumailah oilfield. About 750 Kuwaiti business executives, economists and politicians attended the conference, which focused on their country's plight and its future. They urged the U.N. Security Council to pursue ``all available means'' to ensure an Iraqi withdrawal and enable its former rulers to return. Oil Minister Rashid al-Ameeri told reporters Iraqi troops have placed mines around Kuwaiti oil fields, refineries and other installations. The Iraqis also have stolen equipment from Kuwaiti oil facilities, he said. ``The damage to the oil industry in Kuwait is huge,'' Ameeri said. ``Almost everything is damaged.'' The conference was called in large part as a manifestation of solidarity between the people and the exiled leadership. With prominent opposition ranks represented, it was also meant to show Saddam his call for replacing the al-Sabah leadership through a referendum would run into a stone wall. The crown prince and prime minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, presided. He told Iraq's leaders in his closing address: ``You have no place in Kuwait and you will have to leave it through peace or war, if need be.'' Saad assured the estimated 300,000 citizens in occupied Kuwait: ``You are not alone in your struggle against the tyranny of the Iraqi regime.'' Originally, 800,000 citizens were in Kuwait. The communique declared ``our condemnation and detestation of all oppression, murder, torture, looting and terrorism committed by the forces of the Iraqi regime against unarmed and innocent civilians in Kuwait. ``We declare . . . our solidarity with our legitimate leadership in the persons of our emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, and his crown prince.'' Fatima Hussein, wife of Kuwaiti Planning Minister Suleiman Abdul-Razzak al-Muttawa, told a news conference Iraq is fencing off northern Kuwait - territory Saddam has long coveted. ``The Iraqis . . . apparently plan to gulp up Bubiyan and the northeastern oilfield,'' said Mrs. Hussein, who fled Kuwait last week. She said the fence extended from the northeastern Matla area, with one third of the Kuwait territory north of the fence, abutting Iraq's Basra region. She said this area includes Warba and Bubiyan and the part of the Ratqa oil field that extends into Iraq under the name of Rumailah. Only about 5 percent of the oilfield is in Kuwait. She said occupation forces were marking empty houses for Iraqi occupation and three huge statues of Saddam were being erected in Kuwait City. The communique asked Arab powers that had been sympathetic with Iraq to reconsider, and also said Kuwait still supports the Palestinian struggle ``to regain their homeland and rights from Israel'' despite the position taken by Palestinian leaders against Kuwait. It said Kuwait bears no grudges against the people of Iraq - ``We know for certain . . . (they) are helpless and await the hour of salvation when the tyrant of Baghdad and his clique fall.'' The conference was meant also to map post-liberation reform blueprints that call for a democratic system of rule based on free elections. The communique stated in general that ``the people of Kuwait stick to their national unity and legitimate system of government which is based on consultation, democracy and participation in government in the shadow of the 1962 constitution.'' There was no sign whether opposition ranks received assurances they sought beyond good intent. The conference opened Saturday with an ovation for the emir and his crown prince when he promised more Western-style democracy.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Deficit Bill Would Raise Most Americans' Taxes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new grafs 14-15: ``House Republicans,'' with new GOP budget plan
DOC.TEXT: A Democratic deficit-reduction plan under attack from the Bush administration would raise taxes on all but the poorest Americans, socking the richest 1 percent with increases averaging nearly $14,000 a year. The proposal would cut taxes slightly on those with incomes under $20,000 a year, according to an analysis Monday by the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation. Those above the $200,000 income level would face a 7.4 percent tax increase. For people between those extremes, the legislation would result in tax increases in the 1 percent range. That would result from putting higher consumer taxes on alcohol and tobacco; giving up next year's income tax adjustment to offset inflation, and raising the amount of wages subject to the Medicare tax. Economists for the House Ways and Means Committee, which wrote the proposal, estimated its tax changes and cost increases for Medicare beneficiaries would cost the average family $352 next year. Analysts said: -The poorest one-fifth of families, with after-tax income averaging $7,316, would get a $14 tax cut. -The second-poorest one-fifth, averaging $16,917, would pay $114 more. -The middle group, averaging $25,896, would pay $183 more. -The second-richest 20 percent, averaging $36,481, would face a $280 tax increase. -The top 20 percent, whose incomes average $81,934, would pay $1,173 more. Those with incomes averaging over $428,000 - the richest 1 percent - would face a $13,951 tax increase. Although other deficit plans are being considered, the House Democratic version is getting most of the attention now because of the administration's opposition and because it seems to have support from most of the party's House members. President Bush, after meeting with the congressional Republican leaders, Sen. Bob Dole of Kansas and Rep. Bob Michel of Illinois, said Monday that they were ``pretty much on the same wavelength'' in preferring a different tax increase approved by the Senate Finance Committee. ``What I'll do is say the action's in the Congress and I will take a look at what comes out,'' Bush told reporters on a campaign trip to Texas. House Republican leaders, after days of indecision and disputes among the rank and file, decided Monday to advance a budget plan of their own with broad spending cuts and no dramatic tax increases. The only new levies would be some of the increases Bush proposed in his budget last January. In a bow to the party's conservative wing, the GOP plan would not increase taxes on the wealthiest Americans. But neither would it cut the capital gains tax, a long-time goal of the president. Unlike the House Democrats' plan, the Finance Committee version would avoid changes in income tax rates but would limit itemized deductions for people earning over $100,000. The Finance panel's plan would raise taxes by just under 3 percent for families in the $20,000-to-$50,000 income range; 1.9 percent for those between $50,000 and $75,000 and 3.5 percent for those between $100,000 and $200,000. The $200,000-plus group would pay 3.7 percent more. Because differences between the House Democrats' tax plan and the Senate Finance Committee version will take some time to resolve, it becomes more likely that Bush will order the government shut down Saturday morning for the second time this month. More than two weeks into the new budget year, Congress has yet to enact the first of 13 required appropriation bills. A stopgap spending measure expires at midnight Friday and Bush has said he will not agree to another unless Congress has approved a deficit-reduction plan that the administration supports. House liberals say their bill would reverse a 1980s trend that saw higher-income Americans take an increasing share of the national wealth. They note a Congressional Budget Office conclusion that the richest 5 percent of Americans saw their after-tax income rise by 5.4 percent between 1980 and 1990 while all other groups lost ground. The Democratic plan would raise taxes by $148.6 billion over the next five years and require those with incomes above $50,000 to pay about two-thirds of that increase. It would raise from 28 percent to 33 percent the top income tax rate paid by those with highest incomes and require those earning over $1 million to pay an extra 10 percent tax. A new 10 percent tax would be levied on part of the price of boats, private planes, furs, cars and jewelry. And the $51,300 maximum annual wage on which the 1.45 percent Medicare tax is paid would be raised to $100,000. The liberal proposal dropped provisions in other plans that would raise the tax on gasoline and limit itemized deductions allowed people with incomes over $100,000 a year. Keeping hands off the gas tax appeals to rural lawmakers while those from New York and California especially oppose limiting deductions. To make up revenue that other plans would get from the gas tax, liberals propose to forgo next year's scheduled inflation adjustments in the tax brackets and personal exemptions. That would mean higher taxes for everybody who files a return. The least impact would be on those with the highest incomes, who - since they already would be paying the highest rate - face no danger of being pushed by inflation into a higher tax bracket.

DOC.HEAD: Two Spanish Fighters Collide, One Missing
DOC.TEXT: Two Spanish Mirage F-1 Air Force fighter jets collided during a training mission Monday, and one of the two pilots was missing, the Defense Ministry said. The collision occurred near Los Llanos air base outside Albacete, in southeast Spain. The ministry said one pilot parachuted to safety, while the pilot of the other plane was missing. Nine Mirage F-1 jets have crashed in Spain the past six years, killing five pilots and injuring four others.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Consul Denies Drug-Trafficking Reports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 13-14, `Committee chairman...,' with three grafs to UPDATE with Kerry spokesman saying letter clearing Chamorro no longer valid, pick up 15th graf pvs, `Carrasco testified...
DOC.TEXT: Nicaragua's consul in Miami, a nephew of President Violeta Chamorro, on Monday denied new reports linking him to cocaine trafficking as part of a ``guns-for-drugs'' scheme for the Contras in the mid-1980s Adolfo ``Popo'' Chamorro said he knew nothing of a federal investigation growing out of testimony by a Colombian drug pilot who said he paid the younger Chamorro millions of dollars for drug shipments. ``Never in my life have I had anything to do with this type of illicit activity,'' Chamorro said. He said neither Mrs. Chamorro's government nor the United States would have allowed him to take his high-profile post as Nicaraguan consul in Miami if he were under suspicion. News reports about the case only help the Sandinistas, whose leftist government was fought by the Contras, and ``give arms to attack the new democratic government of Nicaragua,'' the newly appointed official said. Two sources who spoke on condition of anonymity have told The Associated Press that Chamorro - along with Octaviano Cesar, brother of Mrs. Chamorro's top aide, Alfredo Cesar - are the subjects of an investigation by the Customs Service and other agencies. Chamorro, 41, abruptly adjourned the news conference when asked if U.S. authorities warned him that drug trafficker George Morales was under indictment when the U.S.-backed Contras accepted cash and planes from him in 1984. Before walking out, Chamorro said both the United States and directors of the Contra group he helped lead had authorized all transactions with Morales, and that he knew nothing about drug charges. Accusations linking Chamorro with alleged ``guns-for-drugs'' deals are not new. Morales testified before a Senate committee in 1987 that Chamorro and Octaviano Cesar arranged the trade of guns and drugs on a Costa Rican ranch owned by U.S.-born Contra supporter John Hull. Morales said he was certain the CIA and the U.S. government authorized the deals, in part because his drug indictment was ignored by the U.S. attorney's office for two years while he helped the Contras. He was not taken into custody until a second indictment in 1986 and is now serving a 16-year sentence. Chamorro's ex-wife, Marta Healey, who married drug pilot Richard Healey after separating from Chamorro, reportedly knew Morales and made the first connections between the trafficker and the Contras. ``That you'll have to ask her, I really don't know,'' Chamorro said Monday when asked about his ex-wife's links to Morales. During the 1987 hearings, Chamorro and Cesar acknowledged receiving help from Morales, and Cesar said he suspected Morales was involved with smuggling. But both men denied any involvement with drugs. At Monday's news conference, Chamorro distributed a July 1988 letter from the committee's chairman U.S. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., saying the Senate investigation had uncovered no evidence linking him to trafficking. But Kerry's spokesman Michael Meehan said Monday that the letter was no longer valid. ``There are three years and plenty of facts that have come forward'' since the hearings, said Meehan. He mentioned the testimony of Colombian drug pilot Fabion Ernesto Carrasco in a Tulsa, Okla., case seven months ago. Carrasco testified he paid millions of dollars to Chamorro and Octaviano Cesar for cocaine flown into Florida by planes that, in turn, carried arms to Central America. Carrasco's attorney in Miami, John Mattes, refused to comment on the testimony except to say prosecutors and the Tulsa jury had apparently found it credible. Carrasco testified he met Chamorro, Octaviano Cesar and Morales at a Miami restaurant in June 1984 to plan the guns-for-drugs arrangement. He said he was the co-pilot on one subsequent flight, and was ordered by Morales to pay the other two men for the cocaine after successful drug flights. In all, a half-dozen flights, each carrying 300 to 400 kilograms of cocaine, were made from Central America to the United States, Carrasco and Morales said.

DOC.HEAD: Union President Calls for Peaceful Solution to Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The Interparliamentary Union opened its 84th general assembly Monday with a call for a peaceful end to the Persian Gulf crisis. Daouda Sow of Senegal, the group's president, told delegations from 85 nations that the conflict ``is a serious threat to peace and world stability and endangers the hopes arising from the long-desired East-West thaw.'' ``If we are not careful,'' Sow said in an inaugural speech, the crisis ``will halt the growth of developing countries and Third World nations will face disaster.'' Members of the Interparliamentary Union, made up of nations employing parliamentary or congressional governments, include many of the nations involved in the gulf crisis. The Union is scheduled to meet at the upscale Hotel San Rafael in this South Atlantic resort through Saturday. The United States was among the 27 nations failing to send delegations.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Officials Claim Support for `Long Haul' in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Monday said Washington is prepared for a ``long haul'' in the gulf and Americans are willing to keep troops deployed there for years. At a news conference after talks with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Cheney rejected the notion of a quick strike or any deadline for sanctions to force Iraq from Kuwait. British Defense Secretary Tom King also said his nation is prepared to keep forces in the gulf indefinitely. Cheney arrived in Britain on Sunday at the start of a 10-day European tour to discuss the gulf crisis. He goes to Moscow on Tuesday and then to Paris. ``No one should make the mistake of assuming this is the kind of operation which will be over in a very short period of time,'' said Cheney. ``The United States is prepared for the long haul if that is what it takes to get the job done.'' ``The pressure is going to tell,'' King said. ``It was never going to be a quick fix, a two-week wonder.'' But Cheney said he was certain sanctions were working. He predicted the embargoes will erode Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's political base within months and reduce the fighting ability of his 1 million-troop army. ``If I were in his (Saddam's) place tonight, I would be concerned over the next few months he will see the erosion of his political base within Iraq, the erosion of his economy within Iraq, and the erosion of the capability of his enormous military machine.'' British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd suggested last week that the effectiveness of sanctions should be assessed within weeks. Britain has deployed planes and naval ships to the gulf, and is sending about 6,000 combat troops, including the ``Desert Rats'' tank regiment. In a British Broadcasting Corp. radio interview earlier Monday, Cheney said the American public would support keeping troops in Saudi Arabia for ``some years.'' ``We're there as long as the Saudis want us ... as long as it takes to get the job done. And no one should underestimate our staying power,'' he added. He also said he believed Iran will stick to the U.N.-supported embargoes against Iraq despite strengthening diplomatic relations with its former enemy. ``The Iranians are not, in our opinion, interested in seeing Saddam Hussein succeed ... they've given every indication that they will for the most part carry through and enforce sanctions,'' Cheney said. At the news conference, Cheney dismissed suggestions that U.S. public support for the gulf deployment is eroding as attention switches to domestic economic problems. ``The notion that somehow we have a short attention span ... a few weeks or months, I don't think is valid,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua to Destroy Textbooks Containing Sex Education Passages
DOC.TEXT: Some textbooks donated by Norway for public schools here will be destroyed because of ``very blunt'' sexual education passages, the deputy minister of education, Hortensia Rivas, said Monday. She denied it was because of their ``leftist'' teachings. The texts were used in public schools under the former leftist Sandinista administration. Ms. Rivas said the only ones to be destroyed are natural science texts used in grades 5 and 6. ``Those books must be changed because they give a very blunt sexual education,'' she said. She gave no details and said she did not know how many books were included. There are 632,900 children in Nicaragua's public schools in grades 1 through 6 and 84,000 more children at junior and high school levels. The replacement will take place when the next school year begins, in March 1991, Ms. Rivas said. Reading textbooks used in grades 2 and 3 also were replaced this year. A news report from Oslo, Norway, said the 5-month-old conservative government will destroy 4 million textbooks donated by the previous Norwegian government to the Sandinistas. Education Minister Sofonias Cisneros has said many textbooks used during the Sandinista era will be replaced because they are highly politicized.

DOC.HEAD: US: No Green Light For Syria In Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: The United States did not give a go-ahead to Syria in the ouster of Gen. Michel Aoun in Lebanon and still urges all foreign forces to leave the country, a State Department spokeswoman said Monday. ``If you're asking me, Did the United States give Syria a green light? I would tell you, Absolutely not,'' spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler told reporters. She said U.S. officials had no contact with Syria about the participation of Syrian troops in the weekend assault that forced Aoun out of his Beirut enclave to refuge in the French Embassy. The U.S. government on Saturday urged all Lebanese to support President Elias Hrawi, who has started reunifying Beirut and moving to create a city free of armed groups after putting down Aoun's 11-month mutiny. Syrian and Lebanese troops defeated Aoun in an eight-hour assault Saturday that killed 160 people and wounded 800. Asked if the United States backs Hrawi's government in its call for Aoun to face a court of law in Lebanon, Ms. Tutwiler said, ``Our position has always been limited to advice that (Aoun) step aside. We have never taken a position on what should happen to him after doing so.'' She said, however, that the U.S. government hopes the matter ``will not delay the urgent work of national reconciliation.'' Ms. Tutwiler said Syrian forces apparently were requested to help oust Aoun by the legitimate government of Lebanon, but she added, ``It is longstanding United States policy that all foreign forces in Lebanon leave.'' Asked when a U.S. ambassador would be sent to Beirut, she noted that the Senate has not yet confirmed a new nominee ``and our determination on sending our ambassador back will be made, as it has always been made, when you take into consideration safety.'' She said the government has no reaction to Aoun's ouster beyond Saturday's statement which regretted the loss of life and said, ``We hope that this ends a sad chapter in Lebanon's history and that the Lebanese people can now move toward reconciliation and rebirth of a united, sovereign and independent Lebanon.''

DOC.HEAD: Americans Still Consuming Too Many Calories, Too Much Fat, USDA Says
DOC.TEXT: Americans may be getting closer to the ideal diet, but they still eat too much fat, cholesterol and sodium, according to a federal report discussed here Monday. The Department of Agriculture report on the nation's eating habits - which includes the USDA's revised dietary guidelines - was the focus of the 73rd annual American Dietetic Association meeting. Participants discussed a draft of the report, which is scheduled for release in its final form Nov. 5. As in the past, the USDA will appeal to Americans to consume less saturated fat, sodium and cholesterol, try a variety of foods that include plenty of vegetables, fruits and grain products, and maintain a healthy weight. Current diets contribute to high rates of heart disease, high blood pressure and diabetes, the report says. But Americans are coming closer to reaching USDA guidelines for a healthy diet, it said. ``Americans are doing pretty well,'' said Susan Welsh, the USDA's director of human nutrition information services. ``We're definitely moving in the right direction, but we still have a ways to go.'' Americans are meeting the USDA's recommended daily allowances for nine of 15 essential vitamins and minerals, Welsh said. But while fat intake has decreased over the past four years from 40 percent to 36 percent of the average American's calories, that level still is too high. ``The USDA has been recommending 30 percent of calories from fat, so we have some work to do in that area,'' Welsh says. Health officials attending the meeting described how they are attempting to persuade Americans to improve their diet. USDA representative Betty Peterkin said the revised dietary guidelines are expected to be similar to earlier guidelines, but be ``more positive, not prohibitive'' in tone.
