The guidelines are expected to factor a person's body mass, waist and hip size and medical status in determining an ideal weight, Peterkin said. Previously, insurance industry tables used a person's height to determine the ideal weight. The report said the guidelines will call for moderation, cautioning Americans to avoid extremes in their diets, because both excessive eating and excessive dieting can be harmful. Welsh said awareness is the main barrier to overcome before Americans completely integrate the guidelines into their diets. ``There's often an inaccurate perception of one's own diet,'' she said. ``Earlier surveys show that 50 percent of Americans surveyed think their diets are all right. But the surveys showed that only 12 percent had healthy diets.''

DOC.HEAD: 2 Live Crew Jury Includes One Black
DOC.TEXT: A jury of two men and four women, one of whom is black, was selected Monday to hear the obscenity trial of rap group 2 Live Crew. Broward Judge June Johnson said the jurors would be sworn in Tuesday morning and sequestered until they decide if the band's performance of four banned songs at a Hollywood nightclub violated community standards for obscenity. If convicted, rappers Luther Cambell, Chris Wongwon and Mark Ross each face up to a year in prison and fines of up to $1,000. Defense attorney Allen Jacobi called the panel ``a pretty good jury.'' ``There's people from different walks of life. They're not all from the suburbs,'' said Jacobi. ``There's a couple of young people; there's a black woman. They all seem to be inquisitive.'' Band members and their attorneys argued the panel couldn't be fair without young, black jurors. Prosecutors said the jurors' race and age was irrelevant. The black woman is a retired cook with Phillips Petroleum. The three alternates are two white men and a black woman. Their ages weren't released. Also on Monday, two Michigan concerts the group had planned were canceled. Ferris State University officials cited liability concerns when canceling a Sunday concert at the Big Rapids campus. Promoters canceled a Saturday concert in Flint after city officials said they had to pay $5,200 for extra police protection.

DOC.HEAD: Guitarist Carlos Santana Sues Miller Beer Over Commercial
DOC.TEXT: Guitarist Carlos Santana sued the Miller Brewing Co. Monday, accusing the beer manufacturer of malice and fraud for televising a commercial he said mimicks his rendition of the song ``Black Magic Woman.'' The lawsuit seeks an unspecified amount of damages. Santana's lawyer, David Phillips of San Francisco, said damages sought could amount to ``over $1 million.'' Miller spokesman Steve Forsythe said the Wisconsin company knew nothing about the suit and had no comment. The suit alleges Miller and its New York ad agency, Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc. violated the federal trademark law. The commercial advertised Miller Lite Beer. The brewer and its agency began running the commercial last fall and continued for several months despite a demand to stop, the lawsuit says. The suit claims Miller knowingly used the commercial ``with the imitation of Santana's distinctive guitar playing therein,'' to help sell Miller Lite Beer. The 1970 hit song was written by Peter Green. Although Santana did not write the song, the suit said, ``the rendition by Santana of ``Black Magic Woman'' has become such a continuing popular musical success that the public identifies the song as Santana's theme song...(his) musical signature.''

DOC.HEAD: Hermitage Director Piotrovsky Dead at 82
DOC.TEXT: Boris B. Piotrovsky, director of the world-renowned Hermitage Museum, died Monday in Leningrad of a cerebral hemorrhage, Tass said. He was 82. Piotrovsky won fame in 1939 for his discovery of the ancient civilization of Urartu, in present-day Armenia. Until his death, he had been working as director of the prestigious Leningrad museum that only recently under glasnost had begun to let some of its treasures travel to the outside world. Piotrovsky published more than 200 works in the Soviet Union, including ``The History and Culture of Urartu.'' His excavations in the Armenia at Mount Karmir-Blur Hill uncovered the remains of an Urartu period town and fortress. After nearly 15 years in archaeology, Piotrovsky became a member of the Armenian Academy of Science in 1944. He became director of the Leningrad branch of the predecessor to the Institute of Archaeology in 1953, then took over leadership of the Hermitage in 1964, according to biographical encyclopedias. Among dozens of Soviet awards, Piotrovsky was awarded the 1974 Firdousi Prize for his research into the ancient cultures of Transcaucasia and Iran, the official news agency said. He also was an honorary member of the British, French and other foreign academies of science. He took part in analyzing the remains of King Tut's tomb and helped decipher dozens of rock drawings in Egypt, Tass said. During his tenure at the Hermitage, cultural freedom in the Soviet Union expanded and contracted, and recently expanded again under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Hermitage, always a focal point of world artistic attention, has taken some advantage of the openness by agreeing to show some works long hidden and let others travel to foreign countries for exhibit. Funeral arrangements were incomplete. No successor was announced at the Hermitage.

DOC.HEAD: British Designers in Overtime with New '90s Swing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS five grafs of new material.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: British designers have reinvented the Sixties with a sexy, snappy '90s swing for next spring and summer. Nostalgia for the '60s isn't surprising for the country that invented the miniskirt. But the designers didn't wallow in it. They pushed it forward into the very modern Nineties with some of the best collections seen here in years. The British look for 1991 is short, simple and sexy. The sportswear influence is strong, with cropped jackets and shorts the hot favorites. But the big news is that dresses are back, especially skimpy shifts ala Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and Audrey Hepburn. It's definitely going to be a white summer in Britain, though the color palette runs from black and navy to summer pastels, occasionally vivid tropical hues, and a smattering of the bright and bold prints featured in Milan. ``It's a '90s version of simplicity dressing,'' said designer Benny Ong. ``I think the '60s heralded the innocence of it, and the '90s makes a full circle and says now we have arrived. I think the difference is, it's a realized woman who is dressing now - and there is a choice.'' Designers who lived through the '60s - Caroline Charles, Edina Ronay and Jean Muir - and those too young to remember - Arabella Pollen, Jasper Conran and Bruce Oldfield - showed very individual, wearable collections with an accent on youth at shows over the weekend and on Monday. Caroline Charles did trapeze-line coats and short little shifts, some in black and white prints, set off by Jackie Kennedy-style pillbox hats and big sunglasses. Arabella Pollen did her sexiest collection yet, featuring houndstooth check jackets worn with hot pants or hipster miniskirts and minishifts for evening decorated with pieces of cut mirror. ``A sort of neon Hong Kong,'' the designer said. Bruce Oldfield featured a pared-down look with fluid nautical print silk shifts, trapeze dresses over slinky jersey bodysuits, and glamorous asymmetrical sand-colored chiffons with gilt chains setting off the bust or derriere. Paul Costello did his classic linen separates in sherbet colors and a lovely white linen shift but his back-to-front jacket dresses in shiny brocades were less successful. Betty Jackson mixed figure-hugging pants with loose jackets and, with an eye to the not-so-young, did some knee-length shifts. Edina Ronay featured mint and pink pastel sequins for evening with chiffon and raw silk in the same colors. Jasper Conran's lean and fluid classically tailored jackets, shorts and short knife-pleated skirts were back on the catwalk. Rifat Ozbek, who has the biggest international clout, opted for a video presentation instead of a catwalk show. Titled ``Afrodizzia,'' it featured hot African colors, sequins and prints as well as Rasta ragamuffins in African print leggings and rough linen tops embroidered with compact discs. London also kept its reputation for the wild and wacky. Vivienne Westwood, who originated punk fashion and won this year's Designer of the Year, marched to her own tune in her ``Cut, Slash and Pull'' collection. It featured very demure '40s-style tailored suits with midi-skirts alongside slashed and ripped denim shorts and dresses and shocking bikinis and shorts embellished with bow-tied phallic symbols. Westwood, honored Monday night at an award ceremony at Royal Albert Hall, developed the punk look and incorporated anarchy into fashion. One of Britain's most unorthodox and influential designers, she has designed for the Sex Pistols, Boy George and Bananarama. Pam Hogg's very sexy cotton bustiers, peek-a-boo catsuits, and short-shorts in dark red, smoked green and mauve, were worn by models with shaved heads and a wide grey stripe across their eyes. Workers For Freedom, the design duo of Graham Fraser and Richard Nott who won the 1989 Designer of the Year award, picked ``Delicate Bondage'' for their theme. Some models were strapped into soft knee-length dresses with leather harnesses. Others wore brightly printed kimono styles and shirts with evil eyes. Body Map's body-hugging ``Square'' collection showed the influence of Mondrian prints. Ghosts featured clinging minis in lime and tangerine. Red or Dead showed a short red playsuit in synthetic rubber diving suit material, shorts with red shield stamps that peel off, and baby dolls embroidered with ``Kiss Me Quick'' and other sayings. Several designers noted there were very few American buyers and said it was due to the weak dollar and strong British pound. But Red or Dead spokeswoman Catherine Morris said it had brought down its prices on clothes and was ``doing outrageously well in America.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Senators Told to Stay Out of Pakistan's Politics
With AM-Pakistan-Elections
DOC.TEXT: Members of Parliament's upper house told 53 U.S. senators on Monday that Pakistani courts, not the U.S. government, will decide if ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto runs in this month's general election. In a letter to President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, 44 Pakistani senators accused the U.S. senators of interfering in Pakistan's domestic affairs and warned this could affect the already strained relations between Washington and Islamabad. The letter comes at a time when anti-American sentiment is growing over U.S. influence in this Moslem nation of 110 million people and the suspension of $573 million in economic and military assistance. The United States suspended aid on Oct. 1, demanding greater assurances Pakistan does not have a nuclear weapon. Some congressional members also want aid cut off if Ms. Bhutto is disqualified from Oct. 24 parliamentary elections. The letter said that ``the question of eligibility of candidates is not to be determined by U.S. senators but by courts of law established under the constitution and law of Pakistan.'' Ishaq Khan dismissed Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government on Aug. 6, citing charges of corruption, mismanagement and failure to provide law and order. She is being tried before special one-judge tribunals that have drawn fire from all quarters as being obviously one-sided. News reports in the Pakistani press said the 53 U.S. senators sent a letter to President Bush that spoke of deteriorating U.S.-Pakistani relations if the 37-year-old Ms. Bhutto was not allowed to run. Some of the most influential members of Pakistan's 89-member Senate, where Ms. Bhutto's foes hold overwhelming control, responded angrily. ``Political leaders should have the liberty to contest elections as they desire. But no political leader should be above the law and all leaders should obey the law,'' they wrote. They asked Ishaq Khan to convey to the Bush administration they are not ready to compromise Pakistan's political sovereignty and national honor and will not tolerate interference in matters exclusively the concern of Pakistan.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Suspects Arrested in Parliament Speaker Killing
DOC.TEXT: Search for killers of Egypt's Parliament speaker continued for a fourth day with hundreds of suspects rounded up Monday, including Iraqis, Palestinians and Jordanian extremists. The Cabinet of Prime Minister Atef Sedki meanwhile recommended stricter security measures to safeguard against terrorist attempts after reviewing a report by Abdel-Halim Moussa, the interior minister in charge of police. Moussa said in his report that the killing of Speaker Rifaat el-Mahgoub, his driver and four security men Friday in Cairo was carried out by Arabs who infiltrated the country by using facilities provided to Egyptians returning from Kuwait and Iraq, according to the state-run newspaper Al Gomhouria. The leading state-owned newspaper Al-Ahram said Monday that security authorities have evidence the killers were Arabs who had sneaked into Egypt. The government has accused Iraq of sending saboteurs to spread terror in Egypt to punish it for its opposition to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Some government officials and analysts have been speculating that el-Mahgoub's murder was carried out by either Iraqi agents or local Moslem fundamentalists. Iraq has denied any involvement in the assassination, saying the accusations were ``based on the promotion of lies'' and meant to ``cover up popular indignation'' against Egypt's support of the U.S.-led forces in the gulf region. Tuesday's editions of Cairos newspapers said up to 300 suspects have been rounded up since Friday. They said 130 were arrested Monday. There were 22 Palestinians, Iraqis, Jordanians and Lebanese among those arrested Monday. No further breakdowns were given. The arrested Palestinians included a soldier in the the Palestinian Liberation Army. The report, in Al-Akhbar, a third state-owned daily, did not identify him further. All the arrested suspects resembled composite sketches of five gunmen compiled from witnesses. Airport security officials said three Arabs carrying Australian, American and Syrian passports were arrested Sunday, but the official Middle East News Agency said the one with the U.S. passport was released later. In addition to the Arabs, Al-Ahram said an unspecified number of local Moslem extremists were arrested for questioning about their possible connection with the assassination. Last week, Moussa announced the arrests of 35 alleged saboteurs and warned of possible terror attacks by Iraqi agents. He warned that officials would be targeted for assassination to punish Egypt for its strong opposition to the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The Palestinians are suspected of being members of Abu Nidal's Palestinian terrorist group. Recent reports said Abu-Nidal, who split years ago with the Palestine Liberation Organization, has moved his headquarters to Iraq from Libya. El-Mahgoub and the four security men were buried Saturday following a state funeral led by President Hosni Mubarak.

DOC.HEAD: Steel Industry Gets Break
DOC.TEXT: House negotiators agreed Monday to give the steel industry more time to comply with tougher new toxic air pollution requirements, congressional sources said. The action moved a House-Senate conference committee one step closer to overall agreement on the first reorganization of the nation's federal clean air laws in 13 years. The development appeared to set the stage for a settlement with the Senate over new controls on toxic chemical emissions from industry as a whole. The section on toxic emissions and another section on acid rain are the two major remaining unsettled issues before the conference committee. Separate clean air bills, imposing new controls on factories, utilities and automobiles, were approved by the House and Senate earlier this year. The conference members have worked since mid-July to try and resolve differences in the two bills. The talks between the House and Senate became stalled over the weekend when the House members couldn't decide on whether special considerations should be given to certain industries such as steel. The steel industry has vigorously argued that it would not be able to comply with the new requirements by the end of the decade and would have to shut down most of the nation's coke ovens. But by late Monday, the House negotiators decided to give steel companies an additional 20 years, until the year 2020, to bring coke ovens in line with the rest of industry. The Senate proposal already has such a provision. Rep. Dennis Eckart, D-Ohio, who fought for special treatment for the steel industry, said steel still would be faced with ``very, tough standards.'' Beginning in 1998, steel companies would have to begin meeting specific ``milestones'' that will force the adoption of new pollution control technologies, said Eckart in an interview. The reductions would be made primarily by installing new pollution control technology. The agreement also would require industry to take additional actions if health risks to residents near a plant are still considered to exceed a certain level. With the issue of the coke ovens resolved, both Senate and House sources expressed confidence an agreement can be worked out. Last week Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., told the negotiating teams they wanted a compromise clean air bill by midnight Sunday with expectations of final floor votes this week. But the Sunday deadline passed with no agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Spread of AIDS Virus Pushing Up Tuberculosis Cases
DOC.TEXT: Tuberculosis-related deaths should increase sharply because of the ``parallel epidemic'' of AIDS, the World Health Organization warned Monday. A survey by the Geneva-based group estimated that almost half of the 6 million to 8 million people believed infected with the virus that causes AIDS also have TB, which claims about 3 million lives annually and is the No. 1 killer among contagious diseases. Data collected by WHO suggest those with both TB and the HIV virus develop acquired immune deficiency syndrome ``dramatically'' faster. ``It is becoming a parallel epidemic and it is this trend that has public health officials worried, '' said WHO Director-General Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima. WHO estimates the number of HIV carriers could rise to 15 million to 20 million by the end of the century. ``Thus, because of the mirror nature of the two diseases, WHO expects TB cases and deaths to rise sharply, especially in Africa, Latin America, and South East Asia, '' said the survey. The agency estimates 2.4 million people in sub-Saharan Africa are infected with both diseases; 300,000 in Latin America; 200,000 in Asia; 100,000 in the United States; and 50,000 in Europe. The AIDS virus is passed during sex or through bodily fluids, but tuberculosis is transmitted through the air when infected people cough or sneeze. Last year, nearly 8 million new TB cases were reported to WHO, including 2.6 million in the less-developed countries of the Western Pacific and 2.5 million in Southeast Asia. The death toll ranged from 932,000 in Southeast Asia to 42,000 in industrialized countries. The survey said the increase in TB cases in central and East Africa is overburdening the medical system. If treated properly, 98 percent of infected TB patients can be cured, it said. In New York, cases of TB have doubled since 1980. As many as 100,000 new cases are possible in coming years, said Jack Adler, director of the City Health Department's Bureau of Tuberculosis.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Bill to Hire Watchdog Official
DOC.TEXT: The House approved legislation Monday to create the post of chief financial officer for the U.S. government, a move designed to fight bureaucratic waste, fraud and mismanagement. The measure passed on a voice vote and now goes to the Senate. Its chief sponsor, Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., said the lack of a watchdog official with jurisdiction over the entire federal budget was one reason for a rash of scandals ``draining the federal treasury and undermining public confidence in government.'' ``It is almost inconceivable that an organization which controls almost one-fourth of the country's gross national product has incompatible and outmoded financial management systems,'' Conyers said. The bill would create a ``centralized and professional leadership structure'' at the Office of Management and Budget, he said. The Bush administration opposes the bill, the OMB said in a statement. While supporting efforts to improve government management, the bill would create confusion and blur the lines between the executive and legislative branches, it said. The administration favors establishing a deputy director for management and a government-wide controller in OMB, as well as chief financial officer positions in each department, the statement said. A staffer with the House Government Operations Committee, which Conyers chairs, said the bill had been amended to address some of the administration's objections. For example, the latest version deletes a provision giving the chief financial officer a four-year term. Also removed was a requirement that the president give his reasons to Congress if he fires the officer. The bill originally required a study of government accounting standards. The administration said that would not be necessary because the treasury secretary, comptroller general and OMB director are establishing a Federal Accounting Standards Advisory Board to perform the task. The comptroller general is a congressional officer in charge of the General Accounting Office, a congressional agency. The latest version of the bill drops the study requirement. But it would require the administration to submit accounting standards developed by the new advisory board to Congress for approval before implementation.

DOC.HEAD: France Refuses to Yield Rebel Lebanese General
With AM-Lebanon, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand said Monday he will reject any request by Lebanese authorities to hand over rebel Gen. Michel Aoun, who took refuge at the French Embassy in Beirut after his weekend defeat. ``I will tell them in advance, `No,''' Mitterrand told a news conference. ``Gen. Aoun is a refugee at the French Embassy. He has demanded political asylum in France, and France has granted it to him. It is a matter of honor for her (France). She will protect Gen. Aoun and his security.'' Aoun called on his rebel Christian soldiers to surrender in the face of an attack by Syrian and Lebanese government forces Saturday. But Lebanese authorities refuse to let him leave for France, saying he should be put on trial. Aoun supporters occupying Lebanon's embassy in Paris meanwhile alleged that Syrian troops are killing Aoun's captured officers with gunshots to the head. A spokesman for the protesters said family members of the officers had been contacted by telephone from Paris. He could not provide an estimate of the number of men killed. The scores of Aoun supporters occupying the Paris embassy and Lebanon's consulate in Marseille demand the general's safe passage to France. Mitterrand said France recognized the government of President Elias Hrawi and would not grant recognition to any Aoun-led government-in-exile. Mitterrand also said Aoun's departure eliminated any justification for the presence of foreign troops in Lebanon. Paris Mayor Jacques Chirac and other leaders of the conservative opposition urged Mitterrand to request an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council to demand withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon. Chirac also said France should stick to its offer of political asylum for Aoun. Scores of Aoun's supporters occupied Lebanon's embassy in Paris and consulate in Marseille on Monday, demanding his safe passage to France after his defeat in Beirut. Paris Mayor Jacques Chirac and other leaders of the conservative opposition urged Mitterrand to request an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council to demand the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon. Chirac also said France should adhere to its offer of political asylum for Aoun. France is home to thousands of Lebanese Christians. When Aoun began his rebellion a year ago, the French government was sympathetic to his goal of resisting domination by Syria and its Lebanese Moslem allies. This support eroded as Aoun increasingly became perceived as an obstruction to any feasible peaceful settlement.

DOC.HEAD: Unprepared East Coast Cities Said Likely to Suffer Killer Quakes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to RECAST lead, CORRECT that National Center isn't an engineering group. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `New York City...
DOC.TEXT: New York, Boston, and other eastern cities are gambling with catastrophes far worse than last year's California earthquake if they don't prepare better for a major quake expected within 30 years. That gloomy prediction Monday from Ian Buckle, deputy director of the National Center for Earthquake Engineering Research, shook up a national quake conference two days before the anniversary of the Oct. 17, 1989, Loma Prieta tremor. ``The earthquake in the Bay area last year is the writing on the wall for the East,'' Buckle told more than 300 scientists, government officials and engineers at a national quake conference. ``This is a race against time, and the odds of winning do not look favorable,'' Buckle said. The California quake on Oct. 17, 1989, measured 7.1 on the Richter scale, killed 67 people and caused an estimated $6 billion in damage. If an equally strong temblor struck an East Coast city, hundreds of thousands of apartment buildings would be in danger of collapsing, along with some bridges, roads and railroad passes, Buckle said. The result would be huge death and injury tolls and tens of billions of dollars in damage, he said. Buckle said seismologists estimate there is a better that 60 percent chance that a magitude 6 quake will occur within 30 years. The shaking in such a quake would be roughly 10 times less powerful than in the California quake, but would still be very damaging in regions of the country with building standards less strict than California's. In September, researchers from the U.S. Geological Survey and Virginia Polytechnic Institute published a study estimating the chance of a damaging earthquake in the East. They said the chance of a magnitude 6.0 quake somewhere in the east or lower Midwest is 29 percent by the year 2000, 64 percent by the year 2020 and 97 percent by the year 2090. The odds were highest in the lower Midwest which includes the New Madrid fault zone, where the New Madrid fault lies next highest in the Southeast and somewhat lower in New England. New York City, hit hard by a quake in 1884, may be doomed to suffer some of the worst damage because of its dense population and thousands of older buildings of unreinforced masonry. If the 1884 quake, estimated at 5.9 magnitude on the Richter scale, occurred now, it would cause $11 billion to $26 billion in damage, depending on its epicenter, Buckle predicted. ``There would be a great deal of structural damage to all the unreinforced masonry, and more than half of Manhattan is of this kind,'' said Buckle, a professor of civil engineering at the State University of New York in Buffalo. Long suspension bridges and skyscrapers, which are built to withstand strong wind, would be less vulnerable to earthquake damage, he said. ``It's the apartment buildings - the 4-story, 5-story, 10-story masonry buildings - that have the right dynamic characteristics and the poor strength to be a recipe for disaster,'' he said. Buildings of that type are common all along the Atlantic seaboard, where moderate and strong quakes have been recorded over the past 200 years. Charleston was struck by a quake estimated at 7.5 magnitude in the 1800s and Boston had an estimated 7.0 magnitude in the 1700s. Some progress has been made in protecting East Coast buildings from quakes, Buckle said. Massachusetts, Connecticut, New Jersey, as well as New York City and Memphis, Tenn., have either adopted or are very close to adopting seismic provisions in their building codes. But he said that would affect only new structures and wouldn't require older buildings to be renovated. But more needs to be done, he said. ``The public clearly should learn what to do in an earthquake,'' he said. ``The drop-and-cover rules that California schoolchildren are taught should be taught to schoolchildren in New York and along the Atlantic seaboard. People should do things to improve the quake resistance of their homes.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush: War-Crimes Trial May Await Saddam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 20th graf, bgng: Bush's second xxx to UPDATE with Nebraska speech.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday condemned ``ghastly atrocities'' by Iraqi forces in occupied Kuwait and warned Saddam Hussein that, like Nazi officials after World War II, he may face a war-crimes trial. ``Hitler revisited,'' Bush said of Saddam. ``But remember, when Hitler's war ended, there were the Nuremberg trials. ``America will not stand aside, the world will not allow the strong to swallow up the weak,'' the president said. Bush leveled his warning as he opened a two-day trip to boost Republican election hopes in Texas, Nebraska, Iowa, Illinois and Michigan. The president combined his attack against Saddam with a blast at Congress for failing to enact a $500 billion package of tax hikes and spending cuts. ``The American people have every right to expect more from their elected representatives,'' said Bush, picking up on a widespread mood of public anger against elected officials. The two conflicts - one in the Middle East and the other on Capitol Hill - have become the staples of Bush's campaign appearances. ``Every day now, new word filters out about the ghastly atrocities perpetrated by Saddam's forces,'' Bush said at a fund-raising luncheon for Clayton Williams, the Republican candidate for governor of Texas. Bush recounted stories of Kuwaiti babies being removed from incubators so the machines could be sent to Baghdad. Similarly, he said dialysis patients were taken from their machines so the machines could be used in Iraq. In another instance, he said, two youngsters who distributed leaflets were executed by Iraqi forces as their parents were forced to watch. Bush said the incidents point up ``the cruel and senseless suffering endured by the people of Kuwait; a systematic assault on the soul of a nation.'' The horrific descriptions paint a background against which the United States may seek new action in the United Nations against Iraq. Sources say the administration is considering a resolution that would condemn Iraq's dismantling of Kuwait, declare Iraq accountable for the damage there and specifically mention the possibility of military action. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the Justice Department has been compiling a list of violations committed in Kuwait by Iraqi forces. He said other countries are keeping similar records. ``The president simply wanted to make the point that Saddam Hussein has to be held accountable for his actions in Kuwait. We're certainly open to considering various ways of doing that,'' Fitzwater said after Bush's reference to the Nuremberg trials. He said Bush's warning was aimed not only at Saddam but also at officers of his armed forces and the soldiers themselves. On the political front, Bush - despite his 25 years of government service - appeared to align himself with the anti-establishment feeling among voters. ``I can't tell you what a pleasure it is to be out of Washington,'' he said to applause in Dallas. Attacking the Congress for its failure to enact a budget, Bush said, ``If this is the best that the system can do, then it's time to build a better budget system.'' In the Texas race, Williams has outspent his Democratic opponent 2-1 and holds an 11 point lead, according to an independent poll last week. Bush's second stop Monday was in Nebraska, where Republican Gov. Kay Orr was trailing her Democratic challenger, businessman Ben Nelson. The most recent survey done for the Omaha World-Herald said Nelson led Mrs. Orr by 8 percentage points - 44 percent to 36 percent. In Omaha, Bush called Saddam a ``dictator bully'' and said his aggression had been condemned by the United Nations as well as most nations around the globe. ``In spite of that condemnation there is this systematic dismantling of Kuwait which is accompanied by unprecedented brutality,'' Bush said. ``It's an ugly scene,'' Bush added. He was loudly applauded when he declared ``all that does is make me convinced even more than ever that this aggression by Saddam Hussein will not stand.'' After a late-night flight Bush was spending the evening in Des Moines where he will resume campaigning on Tuesday. Bush made the budget mess a centerpiece of his speeches. He said Congress has missed its own budget deadlines 37 times in the last 10 years. ``Twice now this year, I've signed emergency legislation to add more time to the clock,'' the president said. ``Well, this Friday, time's up. The American people deserve more than this stopgap government.'' His statement reinforced administration warnings that Bush will not sign another spending extension, preferring instead to let the government shut down in the absence of a budget agreement. Bush was unwilling to say what he might accept in the way of tax increases. ``I'm not going to say what I will or won't do,'' Bush told reporters on Air Force One as it left Washington. ``That managed to get a little confused last week.'' Over the course of the week, Bush signaled he was willing to accept higher taxes on the wealthiest Americans in exchange for a sharply lower capital gains tax rate. Then the White House said Bush had not espoused that strategy. Finally, the White House said Bush liked the idea but didn't think Congress would approve it. The president indicated a preference Monday for a Senate Finance Committee plan that would not affect income tax rates. Instead, it would raise taxes on gasoline, alcohol, tobacco and luxury items and raise Medicare taxes. ``One of my biggest fears,'' he said, ``has always been that the Congress will continue to pay for its spending habits by raising income taxes on everybody.''

DOC.HEAD: Sacramento Union Refuses to Advertise NC-17 Films
DOC.TEXT: The Sacramento Union said Monday it will reject advertising for all movies carrying the new adults-only NC-17 rating. The Union, a morning paper with a circulation of 70,000, joins the 180,000-circulation Birmingham News in Alabama, which last week banned NC-17 ads. The rating excludes all patrons under age 17. The Union's editor, Joseph Farah, said films carrying the new rating are ``nothing more than X-rated films with a polite new name.'' ``We consider the Sacramento Union a strong family paper and we believe accepting X-rated movie ads - whatever they're called - would be a contradiction of our image and philosophy,'' he said in a statement. The NC-17 mark was created by the Motion Picture Association of America on Sept. 26 to replace the X rating. The X rating had became synonymous with hard-core sex films. Filmmakers asked that the new rating be created to identify mature-themed movies that they believed were not pornographic. ``Henry and June,'' a Universal Pictures release, is the first movie bearing the new NC-17 rating. The film is based on the erotic diaries of writer Anais Nin and chronicles her affairs with writer Henry Miller and his wife, June. The film, playing on 189 screens, grossed $1.4 million over the weekend for a strong per-screen average of $7,408. So far, it has made $2.8 million.

DOC.HEAD: House Overhauls Reservist Protection Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House passed legislation Monday that would make certain that reservists called to active duty would not lose their jobs, insurance coverage or rented homes. The bill, approved by voice vote and sent to the Senate, would modernize and strengthen protections previously granted for those called to active duty. Sponsors said activation of reserve forces in the Persian Gulf crisis made necessary an overhaul of the law. One provision is designed to prevent eviction of a service member's family living in a rented home or apartment. While current law prohibits eviction without a court order, the protection only extends to leases where the monthly payment is less than $150. The bill would extend the ceiling to $1,200. Another provision provides that when reservists return to their jobs, employers must provide health insurance benefits as if there had been no job interruption. Insurers would be required to reinstate the coverage as if no military service had occurred. Employment protection in current law only guarantees a reserve forces member a return to a prior job for 90 days of service. The House bill would extend the protection for whatever period the service member was on active duty. A special provision for health care professionals would relieve them from paying liability insurance premiums such as malpractice insurance. The coverage would be suspended for the active duty period. The bill would postpone court actions for damages while the insurance was suspended. The action could be resumed when the insurance was reinstated.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Discovery's Return To Space Center Delayed
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle Discovery cut short its trip from California to Cape Canaveral because of bad weather Monday and was to spend the night at thi base in the Florida Panhandle. Discovery, riding atop a specially outfitted jumbo jet, left Dryden Research Center in the California desert Monday morning and was supposed to arrive at the Kennedy Space Center before nightfall. However, NASA said low clouds caused the Boeing 747 carrier plane to cancel a planned refueling stop at Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio and reroute to Sheppard Air Force Base at Witchita Falls, Tex. There, the aviation fuel needed wasn't readily available, and takeoff was delayed until it was too late to reach the Cape on Florida's Atlantic coast before dark, officials said. Discovery, which launched the Ulysses spacecraft toward the sun's poles Oct. 6, is scheduled to fly again in February on a secret Pentagon mission.

DOC.HEAD: Campesinos March, Guerrillas Recall '79 Coup
DOC.TEXT: About 3,000 people, most of them peasants, marched through downtown San Salvador on Monday to demand land, respect for human rights and demilitarization of this war-ravaged society. The march came on the anniversary of a 1979 coup by progressive military officers. The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the guerrilla army battling the U.S.-backed government, issued a communique calling for renewed commitment to the goals of the '79 revolution. ``To defend the land is to achieve democracy!'' shouted the marchers, whose ranks were augmented by some workers and students. ``Instead of murderous air force planes, land for the campesinos!'' they shouted. The marchers also chanted slogans calling for a purge and reduction of the armed forces. The FMLN, which is participating in monthly peace talks with the government, has demanded a purge and drastic pruning in return for its own demobilization. The 1979 coup that ousted Gen. Carlos Humberto Romero was designed to check repression and corruption, promote democracy and make for a more just distribution of national wealth. But the young officers who carried it out were opposed by a still-powerful old guard, and deepening polarization gave way to civil war. The rebels, in a communique, called on young officers to back a negotiated solution to the civil war, help solve cases of human rights abuse in which the army is implicated and work for democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Bars U.N. Mission There Except as `Tourists'
DOC.TEXT: Israel's U.N. envoy said Monday his government would not receive a U.N. delegation to investigate the Israeli police killing of 19 Palestinians, but that Israel would not keep out individual tourists. After meeting Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to inform him of the Israeli government's official position regarding a mission, Ambassador Johanan Bein told reporters, ``If they want to get in as tourists, they can come. If they come, they can see anybody - Israel is a free country. ``But a delegation from the secretary-general will not be received by the government of Israel.'' U.N. officials said they would not comment or announce a decision on sending a mission until they received answers to their questions from Israel. President Bush said as he left on a political trip to Texas and Nebraska, ``We want to see that U.N. resolution fully implemented.'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said America was ``disappointed that the Israeli government has decided not to cooperate with the mission.'' A stalemate could mean another meeting by the Security Council, which ordered a U.N. investigation Friday night, and open the door to further council involvement, diplomats said. Israel opposes any U.N. visit at this time, even on a tourist basis. Western diplomats said meanwhile that discussions were under way to keep Security Council pressure on Iraq to force its withdrawal from Kuwait. Some diplomats said, however, that pressing too far could force the council to press further against Israel. A senior Kuwaiti official said diplomats were talking about a possible resolution on reparations for damages to Kuwait, seizure of Iraqi assets and limitations on the size of Iraqi missions and on the movement of Iraqi diplomats abroad. Such a resolution, the official said, might be brought to a vote next week, despite the focus on violence in Jerusalem. The diplomats spoke on the condition of not being identified. Bein noted that an independent investigation in Israel is under way in the Temple Mount shootings on Oct. 8. Police intervened with tear gas, rubber bullets and then live gunfire when thousands of Palestinians hurled stones down on Jews praying at the Western Wall, or Wailing Wall. ``Everybody who comes to Ben Gurion Airport can arrive,'' Bein said. ``There are no limitations in Israel. But they (U.N. officials) don't want to come as tourists. If they want to come, they want to come as a delegation and on that I gave the reaction of the government of Israel.'' The Security Council condemned the violence on Friday and requested a U.N. investigation into the deaths. Israel rejected the council action and the call for an outside investigation as a violation of Israeli sovereignty in Jerusalem and in the territories occupied in the 1967 Mideast War. Israel wants to head off any investigation at the outset, Israeli sources said, because it does not want to give the U.N. Security Council any diplomatic toehold or any reason to take further action with regard to Palestinians in Israel and its occupied territories. Bein indicated the U.N. request to visit may be reconsidered after Israel's commission delivers its report.

DOC.HEAD: Tributes Planned for American Musical Great Leonard Bernstein
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 26th graf pvs, `Gerald Schwarz...,' to CORRECT name to Gerard sted Gerald. ^With AM-Bernstein-Works
DOC.TEXT: Flags at Lincoln Center were at half-staff Monday, and the New York Philharmonic said it will play the music of Leonard Bernstein rather than Beethoven in memory of the American musical titan. Bernstein, whose passion at the podium, versatility as a composer and performances on television helped make him the nation's leading classical musician, died Sunday at his New York City apartment. He died of sudden cardiac arrest caused by progressive lung deterioration from a tumor and emphysema, four days after he retired on doctor's orders. His son, Alexander, was at his side. A private burial was scheduled for Tuesday at the Greenwood Cemetery in Brooklyn, where his late wife, actress Felicia Montealegre, is buried. Bernstein wrote the scores for such classics as ``On The Town'' and ``West Side Story.'' He also lured countless thousands of baby-boomers into the world of classical music with his Emmy Award-winning ``Young People's Concerts.'' ``He was the most unique musician of this century, there is no doubt about it,'' said Zubin Mehta, music director of the New York Philharmonic and the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra. Bernstein conducted his first New York Philharmonic concert in 1943 at age 25 when he was called on to fill in for Bruno Walter in a nationally broadcast radio concert. ``I walked on with an awful hangover and don't remember another thing until I heard a thunderous ovation,'' Bernstein once recalled. A memorial concert is planned for Carnegie Hall on Nov. 14, the 47th anniversary of Bernstein's Philharmonic debut. In 1958, Bernstein became the Philharmonic's first American-born director and served in that capacity until 1969, when he stepped down to devote more time to composing. He served as laureate conductor until his death. ``He was the New York Philharmonic in its spirit and very essence and we're going to miss him like crazy,'' Philharmonic Director Nick Webster said. Beginning Thursday night and continuing through Oct. 23, the Philharmonic will perform an all-Bernstein program, orchestra spokesman Neil Parker said. The schedule had called for works by Beethoven and Shostakovich. Parker said a larger musical memorial is being planned and many celebrities have called asking to participate. ``We'll have more about that in a day or so,'' he added. Bernstein, a heavy smoker, announced his retirement from the concert stage Thursday, citing emphysema and other lung ailments. His last conducting performance was Aug. 19 at Tanglewood Music Center in Massachusetts. Despite his increasing ill health, he said then he planned to conduct an Oct. 28 AIDS benefit concert for the Gay Men's Health Crisis at Carnegie Hall. Sponsors said they will perform a musical tribute to Bernstein that night. As a conductor, Bernstein was known for his concert contortions: jabbing, leaping and even an occasional fall into the musicians pit. Bernstein believed conductors should be actors. ``I don't mean that when the music is tragic you've got to act like Barrymore in `Hamlet,' '' he once said. ``But you have to indicate to the orchestra by your body and your face, which is all you've got, what the shape of the phrase is.'' A man of strong passions, Bernstein's fiery professional style melded with his equally strong political beliefs. He once led an orchestra performance at a liberated concentration camp, raised money for the Black Panthers, and celebrated the fall of the Berlin Wall with a performance of Beethoven's ``Ninth Symphony'' in Berlin. ``With him goes a spectacular, special era in American music making,'' violinist Isaac Stern said. Seiji Ozawa, the Boston Symphony Orchestra conductor who in his 20s was an assistant to Bernstein in New York, wiped tears from his eyes as he reflected on his mentor. ``I had no money,'' Ozawa recalled. ``He gave me many food and drink. His wife, Felicia, gave my wife a dress. I think she still has it.'' ``He was too much for one body,'' Ozawa said. ``He lived 10 or 20 times more than the usual person's one life.'' Colleagues who worked with Bernstein said his greatest gift was the ability to bring out the best in a performer. Gerard Schwarz, music director of the Seattle Symphony, said Bernstein made ``every single player in an orchestra feel a part of something terribly important.'' Larry Kert, who played the original Tony in the Broadway production of ``West Side Story,'' said that during the eight weeks of rehearsals, ``Leonard Bernstein played for me every day. ``He could have gotten a rehearsal pianist but he cared too much. I was the new kid on the block and he stroked me and took care of me - and I will never forget him for that.'' ``The loss is too great to consider,'' said Jerome Robbins, who choreographed ``West Side Story.'' In addition to his son, Bernstein is survived by two daughters, Jamie Thomas and Nina Bernstein; his 92-year-old mother, Jennie, of Brookline, Mass.; ister Shirley of New York; and brother Burton of Bridgewater, Conn.

DOC.HEAD: People Discouraged, Poll Says
DOC.TEXT: More and more poll respondents believe the country is going down the tubes and President Bush's approval rating, though high, has hit a new low, according to a poll released Monday. Only 19 percent of people surveyed from Wednesday through Sunday said ``things in this country'' were ``generally going in the right direction,'' according to The Washington Post-ABC News poll. That was the lowest such response since the poll began asking the question in 1982. Seventy-nine percent of respondents said they believed ``things have gotten pretty seriously off on the wrong track.'' Most people still approve of the way Bush is handling his job - 56 percent. But only a week before, 65 percent approved, In early September, three-quarters of respondents approved. Similarly, the proportion approving the way Bush is dealing with then economy fell from 53 percent in September in 38. Bush still got high ratings for his handling of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait - 64 percent, down from 78 percent in September. Respondents were asked if they approved or disapproved of the way the president, Democrats in Congress and Republicans in Congress were handling the deficit. Nobody won high marks. Compared with the previous week, the president's ``approve'' response fell to 33 percent from 38 percent, the Democrats' fell to 30 percent from 32 percent, within the likely margin of error, and the Republicans' fell to 23 percent from 33 percent. The poll interviewed 1,006 people selected at random. In such a poll, the likely margin of error is 3 percentage points either way.

DOC.HEAD: Both Sides Claim Success in Greek Municipal Elections
DOC.TEXT: A government-backed candidate for mayor narrowly won over former actress Melina Mercouri in Athens, but leftist candidates emerged victorious on Monday in three of Greece's five largest cities. Sunday's nationwide municipal elections were widely viewed as a referendum on the economic austerity policies of the conservative New Democracy Party of Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis, who took office in April. Mitsotakis and opposition leaders, including socialist former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, both claimed success in the voting for mayors and council members. In the capital, Antonis Tritsis, a former socialist minister supported by New Democracy, got 50.15 percent of the vote to defeat former Minister of Culture Mercouri, a member of Parliament from Papandreou's Panhellenic Socialist Movement, or PASOK, and star of the film ``Never on Sunday.'' It was the first time in 15 years a candidate for mayor in Athens was elected in the first round, where an absolute majority is needed for victory. Tritsis, twice a Fulbright Scholar at the Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago, takes office in January, He succeeds Nikos Yatrakos, a New Democracy member. Leftist candidates, backed jointly by PASOK and the Communist-led Coalition of the Left and Progress, won races in Piraeus, the country's major port city; Patras, and Iraklion on the island of Crete. Incomplete results from the Interior Ministry indicated 219 mayors were elected and that runoff elections will be held Sunday in 146 races, including mayoral campaigns in Salonica, Greece's second-largest city. No official results were available late Monday from the hundreds of communities throughout the country. In Patras, about 100 miles west of Athens, police used tear gas to disperse rioters early Monday following victory celebrations by supporters of incumbent socialist mayor Andreas Karavolas. The Athens News Agency reported that 33 police and rioters were injured and six people were arrested. In Salonica, about 200 miles north of Athens, conservative Constantinos Cosmopoulos won 48.2 percent of the vote, short of an absolute majority. Dimitris Fatouros, joint candidate of the socialists and the coalition, received 47 percent. Papandreou claimed the results showed conservatives lost 5 percent to 10 percent of their strength nationwide. He did not elaborate on how he determined this. Mitsotakis said the results indicated conservatives increased their presence by at least 20 percent over the 1986 municipal elections, and showed public acceptance of government efforts to revive the flagging economy. Mitsotakis is struggling to control inflation running at 25 percent and reduce a $10 billion public debt. He seeks to sell some state-controlled industries and streamline the bankrupt social security system. Marches and strikes have been staged to protest the programs.

DOC.HEAD: Former Civilian Leader Returns to Haiti to Run for President
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - More than two years after being deposed in a military coup, former President Leslie Manigat returned to Haiti late Monday to campaign for re-election. Manigat, accompanied by his wife, former Sen. Myrlande Hypollite Manigat, arrived in Port-au-Prince on a commercial flight from New York, said a spokesman for Manigat's National Progressive Democratic Rally party. About 300 people welcomed Manigat during a heavy rain about 8 p.m. EDT. The interim civilian government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot previously barred Manigat from returning, fearing he wanted to claim the presidency. But the government, under pressure from human rights and political groups, lifted the ban last week, saying it decided Manigat ``only wishes to return as a citizen in order to run'' in the Dec. 16 elections. Manigat, 60, was elected president in January 1988, but served only six months before being ousted by a military coup. He was the army's choice in the election, which was widely regarded as rigged, and was overthrown and deported after tying to assert his authority over the military. Since his ouster, Manigat has worked as a researcher in international relations in Washington, D.C., Geneva and Paris. He has repeatedly stated his intention to return to Haiti and run again for president. Manigat is one of about 20 declared presidential candidates, including the former director of the feared paramilitary police known as the Tonton Macoutes. Friday is the deadline for filing for a spot on the ballot. The president-elect is to be inaugurated on Feb. 7, 1991, the fifth anniversary of the fall of dictator Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier. The election will be monitored by observers from the United Nations, the Organization of American States and the Caribbean Economic Community. Attempts to hold free elections collapsed Nov. 29, 1987, when assassins supported by the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters at polling stations. Hundreds of others died in pre-election violence.

DOC.HEAD: `Machinal,' Revival of a 1928 Broadway Success, Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.TEXT: The 1928-29 Broadway season produced such hits as ``Street Scene'' by Elmer Rice, ``Holiday'' by Philip Barry, ``The Front Page'' by Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur and ``Machinal'' by Sophie Treadwell. ``Machinal''? Sophie Treadwell? Leave it to Joseph Papp and his enterprising new team at the Public Theater to unearth a dramatic rarity as its first offering of the fall season. And while not a long-lost masterpiece, ``Machinal,'' especially under Michael Greif's taut and tantalizing direction, certainly deserves a major revival after more than 60 years. Treadwell, who died in 1970, was a prominent journalist, novelist and playwright during and after World War I. ``Machinal'' is her best known play, and it has had occasional small-scale revivals in New York over the years. But the version which opened Monday at the New York Shakespeare Festival's LuEsther Hall is the first major reworking of the play. Greif has given it a fascinating production. From the cacophonous opening scene of a busy Manhattan office to the grim final moments on death row, the evening is a series of expressionistic tableaux. They are done in great style and with a firm sense for the period in which the story is set. The 1920s are evoked by a bit of a popular song, the flip of a short skirt or just the way the actors move across the floor. ``Machinal'' is an early feminist tract, loosely adapted from the sensational 1927 murder case of Ruth Snyder, sentenced to die in the electric chair for the murder of her husband. It's the story of a woman as victim, battered by her mother, husband and society into a submission that eventually leads to her downfall and death. Treadwell's heroine, a stenographer named Helen Jones, marries her boss, a porcine capitalist who spouts homilies about big business and marriage. Their marriage not only traps Helen but nearly suffocates her. A child doesn't help. In fact, the baby only makes her feel worse. Helen finds romance in a speakeasy where she meets a young man - who was played in the original 1928 production by Clark Gable. Their love affair is doomed when she kills her husband, a crime not depicted on stage. The theater, LuEsther Hall, with its high ceilings and bank of lighting fixtures, enchances the design of the production created by David Gallo. Actors quickly carry furniture off and on the stage. Light and dark are important components of that design, and the lighting - and even the lack of it - by Kenneth Posner is startlingly effective. The large cast is headed by Jodie Markell as the doomed Helen. She's sweet but also a little scary, a demented woman who touches your heart, too. There are fine portraits by John Seitz as her wealthy husband, Marge Redmond as her nagging mother and William Fichtner as the man she loves. ``Machinal'' is more than a theatrical curiosity. It's an interesting work by a forgotten playwright that helps us understand the past. And it's exactly the type of play the Public Theater should be re-examining.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Radio Station Owner Ambushed, Slain in Car
DOC.TEXT: The co-owner of a radio station, known for his leftist views, was ambushed by gunmen in three cars and shot to death in the capital Monday, authorities said. The Fire Department said in a statement that Humberto Gonzalez Gamarra, 49, co-owner of Radio Nuevo Mundo, was found severely wounded in his car in the southwestern section of the city but died a few minutes later at the hospital. Police said they had no clues who assassinated Gonzalez, or why. Witnesses said assailants in three vehicles chased Gonzalez's car for several blocks, one of them blocked its path at the entrance of a shopping mall, and the other two pulled up alongside, according to the news release. The men then opened fire and fled, the news release said. Gonzalez was one of several politicians organizing the United Revolutionary Party, a leftist organization. His brother, Julio Gonzalez Gamarra of the Revolutionary Party, a center-left group, is a candidate for deputy in the national legislature for Quetzaltenango province in general elections Nov. 11. Their father, Humberto Gonzalez Juarez, served in the 1951-54 leftist government of Col. Jacobo Arbenz and was kidnapped and assassinated several years ago. Arbenz was overthrown by a military coup, and a series of rightist, mostly military governments followed in Guatemala until the 1985 election of Vinicio Cerezo, a civilian Christian Democrat. The overthrow of Arbenz sparked a leftist guerrilla war that simmers on. Human rights organization estimate 30,000 people have been killed in more than three decades, most ofthem suspected leftists assassinated by rightist death squads believed to be linked to the military.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Envoy Meets With Head of Iran's Judiciary
DOC.TEXT: U.N. envoy Reynaldo Galindo Pohl met Monday in Tehran with the head of Iran's judiciary, and praised the Iranian judicial system that is based on draconian Islamic laws. Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Galindo Pohl as telling Ayatollah Mohammed Yazdi that on his visit to the capital's Evin prison he had heard prisoners confess to spying against the Islamic Republic. The broadcast said the rights envoy praised Iran's criminal laws, under which a sentence passed by a lower court can be revoked by the Supreme Court. ``I think this is very good, appropriate and just,'' the radio quoted him as saying. Yazdi told Galindo Pohl that ``under no judicial system, except that based on Islam, were human rights protected.'' Yazdi added that ``the best example of this is the totally free lives led by the minorities alongside the other people of our country.'' Galindo Pohl met with Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Aakbar Velayati earlier Monday, the radio said. Velayati said he hoped such missions would be underaken with ``a spirit of impartiality,'' the radio reported. It is Galindo Pohl's second visit to Iran this year. The Salvadoran jurist visited Iran in January under a U.N. mandate. His report, released in February, was widely criticized for being too soft on Iran. International organization had accused Iran of gross rights violations. The London-based Amnesty International has blamed Iran of torturing prisoners and hanging government opponents on alleged drug-related charges. According to statistics released by Iran's state-run media, more than 1,500 alleged drug smugglers have been executed since December 1988, and tens of thousands of ``drug addicts'' thrown in prison. On his previous visit, Galindo Pohl reported he found no evidence that the drug-related charges were a coverup for hanging or imprisoning government opponents.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Accuses World Community of Hypocrisy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to INCLUDE Israeli defiance on second issue, housing in occupied territory. Picks up 6th graf, `The citizens. . .'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Monday accused the world of hypocrisy, ignoring murders of Israelis while condemning Israel for killing 19 Palestinians in Jerusalem last week. He also warned Iraq in a speech to Parliament that any intervention in neighboring Jordan that upset Jordanian stability would bring swift Israeli retaliation. Shamir defended his Cabinet's rejection Sunday of a U.N. Security Council resolution urging a U.N. investigation of the Oct. 8 deaths on the Temple Mount. Israel defied the United States on a second issue, announcing a new housing plan for Soviet immigrants that ignores American pleas not to settle the wave of newly arrived Soviets in occupied territory. Six of eight new residential communities announced Sunday are to be in east Jerusalem on territory captured by Israel from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war and annexed. America and most other nations do not recognize Israel's annexation. The Bush administration this year approved $400 million in loan guarantees for housing the Soviets on condition it not be used beyond the 1967 line. Sunday's decision was designed to reinforce Israel's claims to the city. ``The heart of the Jewish people needs to expand faster,'' said Housing Minister Ariel Sharon. ``There is no better answer to the political dangers than strengthening the Jewish population.'' Left-wing parties on Monday attacked the Cabinet action regarding a U.N. mission. The largest opposition faction, the center-left Labor Party, said it would join a no-confidence vote against Shamir's conservative government. Shamir, reacting to the Security Council condemnation, said critics ignored that police charged the Mount only after Palestinians unleashed a barrage of stones at Jewish worshipers at the adjacent Western Wall. ``The citizens of Israel and all Jews everywhere cannot but be astonished and protest at the voices of criticism ... in which what stood out was an absence of any mention of the grave attack on the Jewish people's holiest place,'' he said. Shamir complained that the Security Council failed to respond in any way to the murders of 16 Israeli tourists in two attacks in Egypt, one in 1985 by a deranged Egyptian policeman and another last February by unidentified gunmen. ``We did not hear similar denunciations and we did not see the Security Council being convened when whole families were murdered in Ras Bourka or when buses carrying Israel tourists were attacked,'' he said. Shamir did not follow other Israeli politicians in directly criticizing the United States, Israel's chief ally, for joining in the unanimous Security Council vote. But he suggested backing for the resolution was motivated by the need to hold together the U.S.-backed force against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's takeover of Kuwait. ``The Security Council decision ... was a one-sided decision,'' he said. ``One can only conjecture about its motives and the support it received in the present international situation.'' In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler expressed disappointment in Israel's decision not to cooperate with the U.N. investigators. ``We think that a failure to cooperate denies Israel an opportunity to present its case,'' she said. At the United Nations, Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said Monday he was undecided whether to dispatch a team and would wait to hear Israel's position. In his speech, Shamir also condemned the international community for urging Israel to accept increased U.S. arms sales to Arab states while Saddam has repeatedly threatened an attack on the Jewish state. The 74-year-old leader of the right-wing Likud bloc appeared to step up Israeli warnings to Iraq. While previous Israeli statments have pledged retaliation for an invasion of Jordan, Shamir said Israel ``will not hesitate to react in any way we see fit'' if there is an attempt to undermind Jordan's stability. ``Any intervention in the situation there or intervention in its territory by another state is likely to raise tensions ... to levels we cannot accept,'' he said. In a response to Shamir's speech, Labor Party leader Shimon Peres told Parliament that the right-wing government was ruining Israel's standing in the world and upsetting its alliance with the United States. He told a news conference later that Labor would join in a no-confidence vote expected next week, and said the Cabinet's reaction to the U.N. investigation kept international attention on Israel and away from the gulf crisis. ``We with our own hands, instead of extinguishing the fire, we are increasing the flames,'' Peres said. Shamir's defense of the Cabinet decision also followed questions by Israeli human rights activists as to the government's account of the Temple Mount slayings. They indicated the government had overstated the dangers to police and civilians from rioting Palestinians. In storming the Temple Mount - a site holy to both Moslems and Jews - police wounded more than 140 Arabs in addition to killing 19. A half-dozen police and 28 Israelis were injured in the stoning beforehand. On Sunday, the Israeli human rights group Betselem accused the police of firing indiscriminately and noted the ``light character'' of injuries to both police and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Denies Nude Swim With Teen-Age Girls
DOC.TEXT: Republican candidate Jon Grunseth vowed Monday to stay in the governor's race and prove that he is innocent of allegations that he encouraged four teen-age girls to join him for a nude swim at a 1981 party. Two women alleged in sworn statements that they attended an Independence Day party at Grunseth's home when they were 13 and 14 years old. They said Grunseth encouraged them, his daughter, Nina, and another girl to join him for a nude swim, and one of them alleged that he tried to touch her breast. One of the women said Grunseth swam naked but that both girls wore bathing suits. Grunseth maintained that his campaign opponent, Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich, ``was the driving force'' behind the allegations, which he said are ``absolutely false.'' ``Before this is over, there will be many witnesses who will say that this charge is impossible,'' Grunseth told a news conference. ``It will take us a while to find them, but we will find them in the near future.'' ``We can't bring action, get this into court, prior to the election,'' he said. ``That's what's so sad about this.'' Perpich said he knew nothing of the allegations before a reporter called him over the weekend. ``I had no contact with these people,'' he said. ``It's bizarre to say we in any way had anything to do with this, period.'' The women making the allegations said they decided to come forward with the story because of the governor's race. They made the sworn statements with the help of a lawyer and provided them to the Star Tribune of Minneapolis, which reported them Monday. They later provided the statements to other journalists. Nina Grunseth, now 23, said the allegation against her father ``is totally untrue. I know my father, and I do not believe under any circumstances he committed the act of which he is accused or any similar act.'' She said one of the women making the allegations told her in a telephone conversation Sept. 29 that if her father would drop out of the governor's race, ``no other allegations would be made against him and both of our names would be kept out of the newspaper.'' Grunseth aides planned to ask the U.S. attorney's office to determine whether either extortion or blackmail is involved, said spokesman Elam Baer. The allegations were made by Liane Nelson, now 23 and a social worker dealing with sexual abuse cases in the Boston area, and her cousin Elizabeth Mulay, 22, of San Jose, Calif. Nelson said she decided to speak out nine years later because she believes there was sexual impropriety at the party. ``I think that is extremely inappropriate behavior for someone who wants to be governor,'' she told the Star Tribune. She didn't respond to a reporter's message lft on her telephone answering machine Monday. Mulay's telephone number is unlisted. Grunseth has noted that Nelson's parents have been active in Democratic politics in Minneapolis in the past. In her statement, Mulay said Grunseth ``suggested we all take our swimsuits off.'' ``My cousin and I were adamant about not taking them off,'' she said. ``... At one point, he (Grunseth) cornered me in the pool. I tried to swim by, but he blocked me in.'' Mulay alleged that Grunseth tried to pull her bathing-suit strap down and to grab her breast but he missed. The Perpich campaign has in recent weeks focused on Grunseth's temporary refusal to pay some court-ordered child-support and health insurance payments after his 1983 divorce, and for being delinquent in paying some of his property taxes.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean Official Urges Diplomatic Recogition from North
DOC.TEXT: The highest-ranking South Korean official to cross the armed border into North Korea said Tuesday that mutual diplomatic recognition between the nations is necessary to ease tensions on the divided peninsula. ``We will emphasize to the northern side that basic recognition is the first step toward improving inter-Korean relations,'' said Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon. Kang is scheduled to meet with his North Korean counterpart Yon Hyong Muk in the second round of discussions between the rival nations since the peninsula was divided in 1945. The two prime ministers met in the South Korean capital of Seoul in September. South Korea has recognized Communist North Korea as a separate nation, but the North has refused to do the same its southern neighbor, claiming it would perpetuate division. South Korea has said there can be no significant progress in ending hostilities until both governments officially accept each others' existence. ``The Military Demarcation Line ... is a barrier of distrust and confrontation that has blocked travel and any meeting between our people ... and has brought bitter anguish and distrust,'' Kang said before crossing the border at the village of Panmunjom in the Demilitarized Zone between the nations. Kang and the 90-member delegation were greeted by young North Korean girls dressed in brightly colored traditional gowns and carrying flowers. The group left the border area for the nearby town of Kaesong, where they were to take a special train to the North Korean capital of Pyongyang, about 90 miles north of the border. On Sunday, a 17-member South Korean musical delegation crossed the border for a 10-day trip scheduled to include joint concerts with North Korean musicians. The delegation, made up of 14 musicians and musical writers and three reporters, were met by about 500 North Korean officials and villagers in Panmunjom. ``Your visit has marked a breakthrough in self-reliant cultural exchanges between the North and the South, and it is an epochal event in the history of divided peninsula,'' said Kim Won-kun, chairman of North Korean League of Musicians.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Bars Press From Jury Selection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to CORRECT that four legislators have pleaded guilty to bribery sted five, and that one pleaded guilty to drug charges, CLARIFY that media are appealing both the ban on coverage of jury selection and an earlier ruling sealing court records and DELETE incorrect reference to decision on appeal expected in a day or two. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `There has...
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Monday barred the media from jury selection in the bribery trial of a legislator snared in an FBI investigation into vote-buying in the South Carolina Statehouse. The unexpected media ban by U.S. District Judge Falcon Hawkins kept a veil of secrecy over legal proceedings for state Rep. Luther Taylor. Taylor's attorneys have argued that further disclosures about the case would make it impossible to seat an impartial jury. Taylor, 40, a Democrat from Columbia, is one of nine state lawmakers indicted by a federal grand jury in August and September on charges of taking bribes in exchange for their support of a bill legalizing betting on horses and greyhounds. They were charged under the Hobbs Act, a federal law banning acceptance of money or gifts in return for votes or favors. Four lawmakers have already pleaded guilty to bribery. A fifth has pleaded guilty to a drug charge that came up in the course of the investigation. By Monday night, seven jurors had been seated. The jury will be composed of 12 jurors and three alternates. After Hawkins barred the media from jury selection Monday, attorneys for South Carolina news organizations lodged an emergency appeal before the 4th U.S. Circuit of Appeals in Richmond, Va. Hawkins also has issued a gag order barring participants from discussing the case outside court. Aother order sealing court records in the cases of Taylor and three other lawmakers charged separately is under appeal. ``There has to be a balancing process so that any restriction on our right of access is as narrow as can be and still protecting the Sixth Amendment right'' of a fair trial, said Jay Bender of the South Carolina Press Association. ``We think the First Amendment is first,'' Bender said. The First Amendment guarantees the right to free speech. The judge said he feared potential jurors might be more circumspect in answering questions from attorneys if reporters were present. ``If they know what they're saying is to be public, I am of the opinion they will not be near as candid,'' Hawkins said. Taylor's attorney, Joel Collins, did not file a motion to bar the media from jury selection but argued the presence of reporters would jeopardize Taylor's right to a fair trial. Bender, citing the lack of compelling government interest in sealing the proceedings, offered alternatives such as identifying jurors by numbers. Taylor has pleaded innocent to charges he took $4,300 in bribes this year in exchange for supporting a pari-mutuel betting bill. He is also charged with conspiring to obtain bribes. He has served in the state House of Representatives since 1983. If convicted, Taylor faces a maximum sentence of 120 years in prison and a fine of $1.5 million. The 16-month FBI sting employed a former House member-turned-lobbyist, Ron Cobb, who pretended to represent an Atlanta organization that supported efforts to legalize parimutuel betting on horses and greyhounds in South Carolina. The indictment alleged Taylor met with Cobb and agreed to accept money for supporting the pari-mutuel bill. It also alleged he agreed to recruit other lawmakers to support the bill.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Thatcher, Kohl, Walesa Among Leaders Lauding Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with added plaudits from presidents of Israel, Mexico, Chile. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Nobel-Peace, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: World leaders said Monday in congratulating Mikhail S. Gorbachev that the Soviet leader's courage, boldness and role in ending the Cold War make him the rightful winner of the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize. Gorbachev ``has been a courageous force for peaceful change in the world,'' President Bush said, joining in a tide of warm praise from leaders ranging from German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to the 1983 winner, Poland's Lech Walesa. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher termed the award ``terrific'' and ``richly deserved,'' and others said it may help President Gorbachev's efforts to boost the sagging Soviet economy. ``I am of the opinion that if ever an award was justified, this was it,'' German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said in an interview with the Cologne-based Deutschlandfunk radio station. In awarding the prize, the Norwegian Nobel Committee cited Gorbachev for his decisive role in the East's and West's drawing closer together, and allowing greater openness in his homeland. Echoing the committee, Bush said Gorbachev ``has brought historically signficant change, both political and economic, to the Soviet Union and to Eastern Europe.'' Former President Jimmy Carter, speaking at Moravian College in Bethlehem, Pa., said Gorbachev ``would have been my choice. ``His selection is long overdue. In my opinion, in this hemisphere, no one else alive or who has lived in this century has so beneficially changed the world political society as has Mikhail Gorbachev. ``He got the Vietnamese out of Kampuchea (Cambodia). He got his Soviet troops out of Afghanistan. He brought freedom in a great degree to the people of the Soviet Union. He's made possible the liberation of Eastern European countries. He's been a strong enforceable leader even when the United States opposed bringing about nuclear arms reductions, so in many ways, he's superlative.'' Polish trade union leader Walesa said he wished Gorbachev ``further persistence and successes on the road to democracy that you have outlined.'' It was the first peace prize awarded to a Soviet or U.S. chief executive since President Woodrow Wilson won in 1919. Israeli President Chaim Herzog said he believed Gorbachev's policies ``will bring freedom and happiness to many peoples and advance peace throughout the world and particularly in the Middle East.'' Herzog said Gorbachev's role in opening the way for more Jews to emigrate to Israel, ``will be remembered for many generations and the entire Jewish people is full of gratitude.'' From Los Angeles, former President Reagan congratulated his ``friend,'' calling the prize a ``well-deserved tribute to his bold and courageous leadership. ``Under President Gorbachev, the Soviet Union is making fundamental and necessary changes in its political and economic systems - changes which will give the Soviet people the freedoms they deserve,'' he said.
