Germany's Kohl said in a telegram to Gorbachev: ``Your personal contribution to the improvement of relations between East and West, to overcoming the division of our continent, to breakthroughs in disarmament and arms controls and solutions of regional conflicts is worthy of highly deserved praise.'' In Spain, Foreign Minister Fernandez Ordonez called the award an ``act of justice.'' Italy's Premier Giulio Andreotti said the announcement ``filled me with joy.'' United Nations Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar told reporters Gorbachev had not only contributed ``in a remarkable manner'' to detente, but to enhancing the role of the U.N. ``as a peacemaking and peacekeeping center.'' Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek said the prize may boost Gorbachev's standing in efforts for domestic economic reform. ``It won't help him out of his economic predicament,'' London School of Economics Soviet expert Margot Light said. ``But it may make his political position slightly more stable.'' Citing the 59-year-old Gorbachev's contribution to the cause of freedom, Portuguese President Mario Soares said, ``(It is) a choice that I applaud with both hands, enthusiastically and without reserve.'' President Patricio Aylwin of Chile called Gorbachev ``a man who has had the enormous courage of pushing democratic and liberalizing reforms. . . . His efforts have definitely contributed to strengthening peace around the world.'' Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari said in a message of congratulations, ``Your leadership and historical vision have decisively contributed to strengthening peace and detente in the world.'' Bulgaria's president, Zhelyu Zhelev, told Gorbachev he deserved the reward for his ``extraordinary contribution to the dismantling of the totalitarian system'' and for ``the creation of a new political climate in europe and the world in which peace and cooperation among all peoples are the most cherished values.'' Not all reaction was positive. Latvian historian Jan Saltsmanis, whose homeland is among the Baltic republics fighting for independence from the Soviet Union, said the West was too impressed with Gorbachev. ``I reacted with dismay,'' he told the radio in Sweden, where he has lived since 1945. ``Gorbachev has opened up borders, he deserves a certain merit for the development. But you ... should not overestimate his significance in the context.''

DOC.HEAD: Police to Remain on Mohawk Area After Army Withdrawal
DOC.TEXT: Army troops called to a Mohawk reservation during a violent two-month land dispute plan to withdrawal, but police units will continue to patrol the area, officials said Monday. Public Security Minister Claude Ryan said Quebec provincial police and Royal Canadian Mounted Police will oversee highways leading to the Mercier Bridge, a main route to Montreal blocked in July by Mohawks protesting a proposed golf course and condominium project on land claimed by the Indians. Ryan said the police will remain until a ``professional, competent'' Mohawk police force is formed. The 13-member Mohawk Peacekeepers, directed by a Mohawk council, did not attempt to confront armed Mohawks who barricaded the bridge July 11. A provincial policeman died attempting to topple the blockade. Mohawk council members reacted angrily at the news police will patrol the reserve. ``I don't like it,'' said member Alvin Delisle. ``We have a police force which is capable of patrolling the reserve ... it's our jurisdiction.'' About 500 troops are scheduled to leave the area Tuesday, army spokesman Capt. Carol Lefrancois said. The army was deployed in mid-August, and the barricades on the bridge and elsewhere were removed later that month. The troops will remain on alert until the end of the month, Ryan said. A platoon of 50 military police moved into the reservation Monday to help the provincial police and RCMP take over. Ryan said they would stay at least until the end of the month. He said the provincial police will prepare a plan by mid-November to establish a new police force, mostly composed of natives.

DOC.HEAD: Radioactive Dogs, Tons of Excrement Being Buried At Hanford
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of dead dogs, the remains of a Cold War radiation experiment, were shipped to the Hanford nuclear reservation for burial last month. Coming next: 17.5 tons of their radioactive excrement. The 560-square-mile federal reservation in south-central Washington already is a repository for millions of gallons of radioactive waste left over from decades of nuclear weapons production. It also has accepted defunct Navy nuclear subs and retired reactors for burial. The 828 dead beagles, shipped from California in 55-gallon drums, were buried in trenches at Hanford a few weeks ago. Their remains had been stored in freezers at the Institute of Toxicology and Environmental Health on the University of California campus at Davis. The last dog died at the age of 18{ in 1986, 27 years after government-funded beagle experiments began at the university. The beagle clean-up, expected to cost about $22 million, is part of a nationwide Department of Energy effort to clean up radiation contamination at university labs where government research was conducted. The dogs left behind tons of urine and feces. Since the wastes are radioactive, they also must be buried and shipped under regulations governing low-level radioactive waste. The burial closes a chapter in a government effort to test the effects of radioactive fallout. Several West Coast universities were paid to conduct animal experiments in the late 1950s when public concern about fallout from open-air nuclear weapons tests was mounting. At birth, the dogs either were put on a diet of bone-seeking strontium-90, irradiated with cobalt-60 or injected with radium. About a year and a half later, the treatment would stop and the dogs would be sent to live in outdoor cages until they died. The experiments have shown that dogs fed high doses of radiation get cancer more quickly than people. The dogs who received the lowest doses didn't get cancer, said Dr. Otto Raabe, who has directed beagle research at the University of California at Davis for the last 15 years. In a similar case in Iowa, environmental groups have reacted angrily to a plan to incinerate hundreds of slightly radioactive carcasses of dogs that were injected with radioactive isotopes in experiments to improve human health at the University of Iowa. The university has run out of storage space.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Hearing in Camarena Murder Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Monday ordered a hearing on whether jurors who convicted four men on charges stemming from the 1985 kidnap and murder of a U.S. drug agent were exposed to outside information. ``I believe it is necessary to hold an evidentiary hearing to determine the precise nature of the extraneous information that reached the jury,'' U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie said. ``It is unclear what the jury was exposed to.'' Defense lawyers asked Rafeedie to order a new trial based on statements by one juror that other members of the jury had heard or seen news accounts of the case before returning their verdicts against the four defendants. Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, Ruben Zuno Arce and Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez were convicted of various charges of conspiracy, kidnap and violent crimes in aid of racketeering. The case stems from the 1985 killing of Enrique Camarena, a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent. Javier Vasquez Velasco was convicted of violent crimes in aid of racketeering for the deaths of two Americans who were reportedly mistaken for DEA agents in a Guadalajara restaurant the week before Camarena disappeared. Prosecutors say Mexican drug traffickers killed Camarena in retribution for successful drug interdiction efforts in the Guadalajara area. So far, 22 people have been charged in this country in connection with Camarena's slaying. More than 20 have been convicted in Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Oct. 8-15:
DOC.HEAD: Dow Jones Freezes Budgets for Spending, Salaries
DOC.TEXT: Dow Jones & Co. is freezing budgets for capital spending and salaries and imposing other news and business cutbacks to cope with weak financial results and the sluggish economy. The cuts, announced in an internal memo to managers Oct. 11, followed weeks of rumors about a possible retrenchment and triggered concern over possible future layoffs at the media and financial industry giant. Earlier in the week, Dow Jones announced a 17.5 percent drop in third-quarter profit, reflecting a steady downturn attributed principally to the company's acquisition of the financial information service Telerate Inc. Dow Jones also has been hurt by the recession plaguing Wall Street since the 1987 stock market crash. Operating income at Dow Jones' business publications, which include The Wall Street Journal and Barron's weekly, dropped 80 percent in the second quarter. Advertising linage at the Journal dropped 16 percent in the period. The internal memo from Chairman Warren H. Phillips and President Peter R. Kann, freezes all capital expenditures immediately and holds all 1991 department budgets - including total salary costs - at 1990 levels. Accounting for inflation, the budget cut would amount to more than 5 percent for 1991. The memo also said Dow Jones would reduce management bonuses next year, eliminate all temporary help, try to eliminate all editorial staff relocations and reduce space devoted to news in the Journal. ``It's likely we, like many other companies in our industry, will be facing adverse market conditions for most of our publications and services, particularly in the U.S. in 1991,'' the memo said. The memo said the cuts were ``the preferred method of trimming our costs structure'' but Phillips and Kann said they could not guarantee they would meet company goals. The memo did not rule out layoffs. The memo said Dow Jones would sell its corporate jet and reduce its aviation staff, and sell excess land purchased for Journal printing plant expansion and printing presses in storage. Among other editorial reductions, the memo said Dow Jones would reduce Journal special report inserts and table plans for a Journal magazine among other moves to contain or reduce costs.
DOC.HEAD: UPI Dismisses Unspecified Number of Employees
DOC.TEXT: United Press International said Oct. 12 that it would dismiss an unspecified number of employees and concentrate its reporting on 15 populous states. ``There will be some people who will get dismissal notices,'' said Milt Capps, senior vice president for corporate affairs. ``There will be some ups in some places and some downs in others to maintain the staffing equilibrium,'' he said. ``We will have as many people reporting as we have had, given that we are also relying on stringer correspondents and subcontractors.'' Capps declined to say how many people were being laid off. Capps said UPI would continue to have bureaus in ``virtually every state'' and had no plans to announce any bureau closures soon. The 83-year-old wire service announced in September that it was closing bureaus in five states. Executive Vice President Pieter Vanbennekom said UPI planned to intensify its reporting of business and finance, economics and trade, government, crime and ``quality of life'' issues. He said wires known as MetroRegional wires would be established serving California, New York, New Jersey, Texas, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Michigan, Florida, Ohio, Massachusetts, Indiana, New Hampshire, Delaware, Maryland and Virginia. UPI derives about 82 percent of its revenue from the 15 states, Vanbennekom said. Similar wires may be established in other states in 1992, depending on the success of the program, he said.
DOC.HEAD: New Jersey Paper Plans Staff Cuts, But No Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Staff levels will be reduced at The Record as part of a cost-reduction program, but no layoffs are planned, Chairman Malcolm A. Borg said Oct. 11. Borg and Publisher Byron C. Campbell issued a statement saying spending would be scrutinized, other operating costs would be cut and staff would be reduced through hiring controls and attrition. They warned, however, that the decision against layoffs could be reversed if sluggish economic conditions continued in the Northeast. ``If economic conditions deteriorate further, this decision will be revisited,'' the statement said. The statement was issued after published reports about rumors that The Record might cut its staff by 10 percent. Classified advertising at The Record has dropped more than 25 percent, while overall revenue is down by about 12 percent, spokesman Peter Hearne said. ``Ad revenue in the Northeast is off by large proportions and has been for a couple of years. We are just in a position where we must get our costs in line,'' Hearne said. The paper has a daily circulation of about 150,000.
DOC.HEAD: New Hampshire Daily Cuts Staff, Drops Weekly
DOC.TEXT: The dail Valley News laid off nine employees and discontinued its money-losing controlled-circulation weekly Oct. 8, citing a decline in advertising revenue. The layoffs, the first since the paper was founded in 1952, reduced the staff to 81 employees. Publisher Willmott Lewis Jr. told employees the paper had reduced expenses three months ago in the hope layoffs would not be necessary, but the decline in ad revenues had continued. He said revenues had fallen since peaking in 1988. Circulation, which provides about 20 percent of the paper's revenue, is 18,800. Discharged employees received severance pay of a minimum of nearly three weeks' salary.

DOC.HEAD: Knight-Ridder Reinvents a Community Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Knight-Ridder Inc. unveiled a redesigned newspaper Oct. 11 that seeks a share of quality time in this baby boomer-rich suburb. The News, a reconstituted 35-year-old daily, takes its visual cues from USA Today with heavy use of color, maps and indexes, eye-catching graphics and clean lines. In content, short, trendy stories will be the norm. Broadsheet sections have been reserved for the top news, local developments, business and sports. Feature articles are offered in a tabloid magazine called Essentials. ``What we did was to take a very specific community and say, `If we were reinventing the newspaper, if a newspaper didn't exist in this place, and we were trying to create a newspaper that we thought would have the greatest appeal to the people in this community, what would it be?' '' said James Batten, Knight-Ridder chairman and chief executive officer. While many newspapers have evolved along similar lines in recent years, Knight-Ridder put in two years researching approaches aimed at baby boomers. The result transformed The Boca Raton News into The News. ``People were skeptical at first because they were afraid we were trying to reinvent USA Today for the local area,'' said Lou Heldman, the project's corporate coordinator. ``It is meant to have all of the traditional journalistic components: to do investigative reporting, to be a watchdog over government and institutions, to run stories with an edge when that's called for and to not homogenize the writing style.'' Wayne Ezell, editor of the News, said: ``We don't spend much time in the business asking ourselves what our readers are interested in. We tend to engage people who read newspapers. We need to talk to the people who don't read newspapers.'' The newspaper, whose circulation is estimated at 40,000, has been tailored specifically for Boca Raton, a community of 67,000 people between Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach. Its image is that of an upscale retirement haven, but 30 percent of the population is in the baby boomer pool, half of whom have arrived in the past five years. Loyal, older readers haven't been left out. A focus group study of readers over age 45 showed that ``it's a bigger hit frankly with the older readers than the younger readers,'' he said. Batten said he regards The News as a laboratory testing potential applications for Knight-Ridder's other papers.
DOC.HEAD: Baby Bells Get Boost in Electronic Info Bid
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court boosted a bid by the nation's seven regional telephone companies to provide electronic information services to homes and businesses. The court, without comment Oct. 9, rejected an appeal aimed at making it harder for the companies to enter the developing industry. The underlying issue is whether the companies should be allowed to use their phone lines to sell such information as stock market quotes and ``electronic Yellow Pages'' with home-shopping and classified advertising. Last April, the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here threw out part of a 1987 lower court ruling that barred the companies from selling the information services. The appeals court said the ruling by U.S. District Judge Harold Greene, who has overseen the breakup of the AT&T phone monopoly for more than a decade, was too strict. It sent the case back to him with instructions to use a more lenient test - whether lifting the ban would be in the public interest. Asking the Supreme Court for help was a coalition of consumer groups, long-distance phone companies, equipment manufacturers, data-processing businesses and newspapers that want to enter the at-home information market. The coalition, including the American Newspaper Publishers Association, said the appeals court ruling jeopardizes the vigorous economic growth spawned by the breakup of AT&T in 1984. The phone companies said that their opponents are trying to kill legitimate competition and that most Americans will be slow in getting information services unless the Baby Bells participate.
DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf, Gas Prices Most Closely Watched Stories
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis and the resulting increase in gasoline prices were the most closely followed stories during September, but Americans paid much less attention to the federal budget crunch, a media group reported. The Times Mirror Center for The People & The Press said Oct. 10 that 68 percent of Americans surveyed said the Mideast crisis was the most important news of September. Sixty-three percent said they were following very closely news about the U.S. troop deployment to Saudi Arabia and other developments in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. That was the same percentage as in August. Sixty-two percent said they paid close attention to stories about rising gasoline prices, up from 56 percent in August. The percentage of the public who paid close attention to news about hostages held in Iraq and Kuwait declined from 57 percent to 47 percent. Although the poll was taken Oct. 4-7, the period in which budget negotiations broke down and a government shutdown was ordered, only 34 percent said they were closely following news about efforts to resolve the budget impasse. However, 45 percent said they were aware gasoline tax increases were being considered, 38 percent had heard cigarette taxes might be raised and 40 percent knew alcohol tax increases were under consideration. Among people under 30, only 20 percent said they were following the budget news closely. The percentage increased with age and reached 46 percent among people 50 and older. The results were based on telephone interviews of 1,213 adults. The margin of error was plus or minus three percentage points.
DOC.HEAD: Times Mirror Corrects Poll Figures on Republicans and Rich
DOC.TEXT: The Times Mirror Center for The People & The Press said it wrongly reported that a national poll it took last month found that 51 percent of the people surveyed associated Republicans with ``rich, powerful moneyed interests.'' The correct figure was 21 percent, the center said Oct. 12. In a previous poll three years ago, 18 percent made such an association. The big jump to 51 percent was widely published and frequently cited by political commentators. Times Mirror said that the incorrect figure was due to a computing error. It said it also overstated the percentage of people who spontaneously said they associated Republicanism with conservatism, being business-oriented and not being for the people. Scott Sowry, a spokesman for the Republican National Committee, said the party was certain that the apparent jump was an error. ``That's what we've been saying all along,'' Sowry said.

DOC.HEAD: Pioneer Press To Fax Regional News to Troops in Saudia Arabia
DOC.TEXT: A special edition of the Saint Paul Pioneer Press summarizing regional sports and news will be faxed to soldiers in Saudi Arabia to keep them in touch with what's happening back home. The weekly summary, which will be published on Mondays beginning this week, will include prep, collegiate and professional sports stories and scores, and will summarize the news in Minnesota and western Wisconsin, the paper said Oct. 14. ``We began exploring the possibility of publishing the Desert Shield `NewsFax' when we read about the problems the troops are having in getting their mail,'' said Mary Junck, president and publisher of the newspaper. The two-page paper will be sent to the U.S. Central Command in Saudi Arabia and to naval vessels in the region. It will be distributed free of charge to the troops, bypassing the clogged mail system.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Refuses Ads for Movies With NC-17 Rating
DOC.TEXT: The Birmingham News became the nation's first newspaper to reject advertising for the new NC-17 adults-only film ``Henry & June.'' The afternoon paper rejected ads for the Universal Pictures release and said it would refuse ad copy for all subsequent NC-17 films, citing its previous ban on X-rated movies. ``We feel like the NC-17 is not that far removed from X, based on what we're familiar with,'' marketing director Tom Adams said. In Los Angeles, Universal spokesman Allan Sutton said the News was the first and only newspaper to ban NC-17 ads. The movie, which includes two lesbian sex scenes and a shot of an erotic drawing, is based on the diaries of Anais Nin and chronicles her affairs with writer Henry Miller and his wife. It was the first released under the Motion Picture Association of America's new rating, which excludes anyone under 18 and replaces the X rating. Studios long considered the X designation box office poison because of its association with hard-core sex and the inability to place media ads. Jack Valenti, association president, condemned the News' blanket prohibition on NC-17 films. ``If a newspaper wants to live in the Stone Age, I can't do anything about it,'' he said. In an editorial Oct. 7, the News said ``smut was still smut'' and the NC-17 rating could lead to more violent or erotic fare, ``drawing audiences that might have been turned off by the stigma of an X rating.'' The newspaper also published its policy. ``The policy of the Birmingham News in reviewing and accepting advertising for movies will not change as a result of the decision to replace the old `X' designation with the new `NC-17' designation. ``As a general rule, movies that receive the NC-17 rating or are unrated will not be reviewed and advertisements for those movies will not be accepted. Exceptions to that policy will be considered on a case-by-case basis.''
DOC.HEAD: NFL Players Group Asks for Separate Interview Areas
DOC.TEXT: The NFL Players Association is asking the league to set up an area outside locker rooms so players would not be required to participate in media interviews unless fully clothed. The union issued a statement Oct. 8 from executive director Gene Upshaw saying NFL players should be afforded absolute privacy in their locker rooms. ``People deserve to be treated with respect and dignity whether they are male or female, pro football players or members of the media,'' Upshaw said. ``Women in sports media must have the same access as their male counterparts to NFL players.'' So, Upshaw said, keep all reporters out of the locker room and ``provide a separate area . . . where all players would be available on an equal basis to all accredited media, male or female.'' Cincinnati Bengals coach Sam Wych was fined $30,000 for closing his team's locker room to a female reporter. That incident followed one in which Lisa Olson, a reporter for the Boston Herald, accused New England Patriots players of sexually harassing her and humiliating her in the locker room during practice.
DOC.HEAD: Santa Fe Drops Effort To Ban Street Newspaper Sales
DOC.TEXT: City leaders agreed Oct. 10 to drop a move to ban vendors from selling newspapers at intersections. City attorney Jim McKay said he had been satisifed The New Mexican had adequate insurance to cover any traffic accident caused by a vendor. McKay had recommended in July that the council change a 1987 law permitting street sales of newspapers because of the city's potential liability if a vendor or motorist were hurt in a traffic accident. The Public Safety Committee voted 3-2 in August to recommend changing the law and the City Council had scheduled a hearing for Oct. 10. The newspaper's insurer, Daniels Insurance Co., assured McKay the newspaper would pay damages if the city was found negligent due to an accident caused by a vendor's actions. McKay said other newspapers' vendors would be allowed at intersections if they could prove they were adequately insured.
DOC.HEAD: Kid Reporters Get First Interview With Retired Justice
DOC.TEXT: A group of young reporters scored a journalistic coup by interviewing retired U.S. Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr. After suffering a stroke, Brennan retired in July under doctor's orders to reduce his workload and decline all interviews until at least next year. But five reporters and editors from the Indianapolis Children's Express bureau spent 30 minutes in September interviewing the 84-year-old Brennan, who had been the strongest liberal voice on an increasingly conservative court. Their interview was published in The Indianapolis Star on Oct. 8. The team peppered Brennan with questions about children's rights, abortion, drug testing, the death penalty for minors and the mentally retarded, the Equal Rights Amendment and his replacement on the court, David H. Souter. They said Brennan dodged most questions on the newest justice, but indicated he wasn't pleased with him. ``It wasn't so much like we were scooping anybody. We were just talking,'' said Wendy Potasnik, 17. ``It was more like a conversation than an interview,'' agreed Lisa Schubert, 10. ``I mean, I'd ask him the same questions as if I'd ran into him one day.'' The interview was arranged with the help of Brennan's daughter, Nancy, who is a friend of Peter Sterling, president of the Children's Museum. The museum houses the Children's Express bureau, which publishes a one-page, weekly report in the Star on issues of interest to youngsters. Before interviewing Brennan, the young reporters carefully researched his 34-year tenure on the bench. The team met twice a week for six weeks reviewing newspaper and magazine articles on Brennan and some of the more than 1,200 opinions he wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter, Editor Dismissed in Flap Over Personal Investments
DOC.TEXT: The business editor and a reporter for the St. Petersburg Times have been ousted in a conflict-of-interest dispute that raises questions about what personal financial activity is appropriate for journalists. The episode began late last month when reporter James Greiff disclosed he had been short-selling stock of Wells Fargo & Co., the San Francisco-based bank. After consulting with top editors, business editor Leonard M. Apcar dismissed Greiff on Oct. 3. Two days later, Apcar quit under pressure after the superiors learned his individual retirement account was invested in a mutual fund containing Banc One Corp. of Columbus, Ohio. Business journalism ethics have received increased scrutiny since the 1985 insider trading conviction of R. Foster Wi In short-selling, an investor sells borrowed stock on the expectation the price of the issue will decline. The investor profits if the price drops and the shares, usually borrowed from a broker, can be replaced at a lower price. The risky strategy, forbidden to journalists by at least one major business publication, amounts to a bet that a company's stock price will drop. Theoretically, a reporter writing a negative article about a company could ``short'' the stock of that company, expecting the story to drive down the price. Greiff said he had not written about Wells Fargo. He was accused only of bad judgment, not any wrongdoing. Following Greiff's dismissal, Apcar said he told his immediate supervisor that he had bank stock in an IRA, but he didn't name the bank. Greiff, meanwhile, said he told Times executives that Apcar held shares of Banc One, which had been mentioned in a story by Greiff as a possible suitor for a Florida bank. Apcar had edited the story and decided his mutual-fund holding presented no conflict. On Oct. 4, after rumors that Apcar owned stock in the bank filtered through the newsroom, Apcar said he voluntarily told his supervisor that Banc One was in the mutual fund. A day later, Foley asked Apcar to resign. Mutual funds typically contain baskets of different stocks and other securities. Their contents usually are decided by fund managers, not investors. In an IRA, investors cannot withdraw money without penalty until retirement. ``You're not in a mutual fund . . . for a short period of time,'' said Apcar, who was hired by the Times in early 1989 after more than 12 years as a reporter at The Wall Street Journal. ``You're in for the long haul unless you trade, and I don't trade.'' The Times' conflict-of-interest policy does not specifically bar any investments but cautions reporters to avoid even the appearance of a conflict and to raise questions with superiors. Greiff, a Times reporter for more than five years, said he did not violate any policy, written or spoken. He said business writers were told only not to invest in companies they cover or ones based in Florida. ``Within 10 minutes after placing my order with my broker I told several people in my department and told Len,'' he said. ``I said, `Do you have any problem with it?' and he said no.'' Apcar said he did not respond immediately to Greiff's comments. ``It went from being no problem to being a problem to being a firing offense in a matter of a few days,'' Greiff said. Rules governing reporters' investments vary widely. Dow Jones & Co., which owns The Wall Street Journal, has what is considered to be the strictest conflict-of-interest policy in the nation. Reporters and other staffers are barred from short-term trading and must hold securities at least six months. They cannot trade futures or options or sell short. Reporters and their families are prohibited from investing in companies related to their coverage areas. The Society of American Business Editors & Writers' ethics code urges avoiding even the appearance of conflict. It calls for skirting ``active trading and other short-term profit-seeking opportunities.'' Some editors said newspapers may be at fault if they discipline reporters without precise guidelines. ``If there is no specific policy that makes that clear I think the newspaper has overreached,'' said Sandra Duerr, business editor of The Courier-Journal in Louisville, Ky.
DOC.HEAD: Man Pleads Guilty to Attempted Extortion of Malcolm Forbes
DOC.TEXT: A man pleaded guilty to trying to extort $30,000 from the late Malcolm Forbes by threatening to harm his reputation. George Kenneth Warnock, 25, of the Bronx, had been charged in July with mailing two threatening letters to Forbes the previous August and September and a similar letter to Forbes' son Malcolm Jr. after the millionaire publisher died Feb. 24. Warnock pleaded guilty Oct. 5 to one count of using the mail in an extortion attempt. The plea was made public Oct. 10. He faces up to two years in prison and a $250,000 fine when sentenced Dec. 14 by U.S. District Judge Lawrence M. McKenna. The indictment didn't describe the nature of Warnock's threats. A lawyer for Forbes' family said Warnock had never met Forbes.

DOC.HEAD: South Carolina Paper in Agreement With NAACP
DOC.TEXT: The Sun News and the state NAACP signed a landmark agreement stipulating the newspaper will increase opportunities for employment and promotion for minorities at all levels in the company. Representatives of the civil rights organization and the newspaper said the agreement announced Oct. 12 was the first of its kind in the nation. ``Signing this unique and historic agreement we have both agreed is the right thing to do,'' said William F. Gibson, state president of the NAACP and chairman of the NAACP's national board of directors. Gibson signed the agreement at a news conference along with J. Michael Pate, president and publisher of The Sun News; Nelson Rivers, executive director of the state NAACP; and Laura Hensley, vice president of marketing and finance at the newspaper. ``It was a pretty easy task because we took our pluralism policy to them and we sat down and said this is what we want to do and we all worked it out,'' Pate said. One goal is for The Sun News to put blacks in 20 percent of management, senior management and professional positions by the end of 1993. The agreement also calls for The Sun News to make 10 percent of its purchases from minority-owned businesses by 1991, 15 percent by 1992 and 20 percent by 1993. Pate said the percentage of minoriting reluctance of campus administrators to release campus crime reports to the public and campus communities.'' The Legal Defense Fund also provided a $1,000 emergency grant to SPJ chapters in South Carolina to help challenge the state's criminal libel law. In the past two years, two newspaper editors in South Carolina have been arrested on criminal libel charges stemming from their reporting about public officials. SPJ feels such prosecutions, while never brought to trial, have a chilling effect on journalists. In other free speech matters, SPJ directors voted Oct. 14 to give a First Amendment Award to Cincinnati art gallery director Dennis Barrie for his stand on artistic freedom. Barrie was acquitted Oct. 5 of pandering obscenity for exhibiting photos by the late Robert Mapplethorpe at the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati. ``His battle to uphold the principles of the First Amendment came at considerable expense and the threat of jail,'' said SPJ President Frank Gibson, metro editor for The Tennessean in Nashville. SPJ presented two other First Amendment Awards during its convention: -Texas Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Doggett, for longstanding efforts on behalf of governments having open meetings and records. -Peter Sussman, editor of the San Francisco Chronicle's Sunday ``Punch'' section, for publishing the bylined essays of Dannie Martin, a convicted bank robber. The inmate and the newspaper have suedin federal court to try to overturn prison restrictions on Martin's reporting.
DOC.HEAD: Former Reporter Sentenced in Car Death
DOC.TEXT: A former reporter has been sentenced to one year of home confinement in the death in a car wreck of his roommate, a newspaper photographer. Donald W. Manley, 34, pleaded guilty Oct. 9 in Kent County Superior Court to criminally negligent homicide. Manley was drunk when the car he was driving went out of control in May in Dover. Manley's roommate, Sean Rojas, 27, a photographer for The State News in Dover, was killed. Another roommate was injured. Manley is a former reporter for The State News and The Philadelphia Inquirer.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Revives $4 Billion Libel Suit Against ABC
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court revived a $4 billion lawsuit by a millionaire inventor who says ABC's ``20-20'' falsely portrayed him as a liar and hypocrite. The justices told a federal appeals court Oct. 9 to restudy Arthur Jones' libel suit over the 1987 report on the fate of 63 baby elephants Jones rescued from death in Africa. The justices said the case should be reconsidered in light of their June ruling that the Constitution's guarantee of free speech did not ``create a wholesale defamation exemption for anything that might be labeled opinion.'' The June decision, however, did not strip away constitutional immunity for pure expressions of opinion that cannot be proved true or false. Jones, the inventor of Nautilus exercise machines, was the subject of a ``20-20'' broadcast in 1984 - the year he flew the 63 elephants from Zimbabwe to the Ocala, Fla., farm he calls Jumbolair. The elephants had been marked for death as part of a culling, or herd thinning, operation. The elephants lived on Jones' Ocala estate until the summer of 1986, when the herd began to be dispersed. The 1987 report aired by ``20-20'' was preceded by a comment by host Barbara Walters that it would discuss ``the fate of some baby elephants to whom a promise was not kept.'' According to Jones' suit, that comment and others contained in the report ``falsely cast him as a liar and a hypocrite, and accused him of animal cruelty.'' U.S. District Judge Elizabeth Kovachevich dismissed the suit before it reached a jury. She ruled that some of the comments cited in the lawsuit were not defamatory and that those which might be were expressions of opinion not statements of fact. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the dismissal in December. Lawyers for ABC, urging the justices to reject Jones' appeal, said the broadcast ``simply does not contain . . . statements accusing him of hypocrisy, lying, unscrupulousness and cruelty to animals.''
DOC.HEAD: Eight Police Officers Sue Toledo Blade
DOC.TEXT: Eight police officers filed a $24 million suit charging The Blade invaded their privacy and libeled them in a series of articles about the police department. The suit claims The Blade's series, ``The Secret Files of Internal Affairs,'' gave an inaccurate portrayal of the officers. The officers said they were not prosecuted for any of the incidents related in the articles. The suit, filed Oct. 11 in Lucas County Common Pleas Court, said the plaintiffs had suffered humiliation and mental anguish because of the series. Jonathan Hart, a lawyer for The Blade, said the newspaper stood behind the stories. ``The newspaper researches, reports and publishes important facts affecting the public interest of the citizens of Toledo, as The Blade believes it did in news articles complained of by these officers,'' Hart said from his Washington office. ``The Blade believes the news articles were true when they were published and continues to believe them to be true.'' The series, which ran in June, was based on a review of nearly 1,000 disciplinary files of former and current officers. The files are maintained by the police department's Internal Affairs unit. The Blade reported that officers have committed crimes but have not been arrested. The newspaper also detailed social problems facing the division, including substance abuse and domestic violence.
DOC.HEAD: Photographer Charged With Obstruction During Arrest
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper photographer was charged with obstructing a police officer after he took pictures of Cherokee County sheriff's deputies capturing an escaped prisoner. Joe Cook, of the weekly Cherokee Citizen, was charged Oct. 8 because he ignored officers' orders to step back from the arrest scene and because he swore at them, Sheriff John Seay said. Cook said deputies arrested him because they were afraid he had pictures of them beating the prisoner. He said his camera was taken from him and the film removed. ``They thought I had pictures of them roughing him up,'' Cook said. ``He was groaning and said, `Please, no more.' '' Sgt. Jim Harvey denied the prisoner was beaten, saying he struggled with deputies. ``Any scuffle would look like you're roughing the subject up,'' he said. Cook said he was making pictures of the prisoner being carried to the street and was told to step back. He said he stepped back to a point designated by officers. He said he continued to photograph the capture but was continually thwarted by an officer who stepped in front of him. ``I pointed my finger at him and said, `Get out of my way,' '' said Cook, who admitted swearing at the officer. Cook posted bail of $1,200. He said his camera had black and white film when he was arrested but contained exposed color film when it was returned to him.
DOC.HEAD: California High Court Denies Petition for Press Access
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court denied a petition by the Radio and Television News Directors Association that press photographers be allowed in the courtroom during the murder trial of Ramon Salcido. The court issued a one-sentence denial Oct. 10, without explanatory comment. The news association had wanted the court to overrule a judge's order barring television and still cameras from the Redwood City courtroom where the Salcido trial began several weeks ago. Salcido is accused of killing seven people, including six members of his family, during an April 1989 rampage in the wine country.
DOC.HEAD: Houston Newspapers Ask Court To Quash Writers' Subpoenas
DOC.TEXT: Two newspapers are asking a state appeals court to intervene on behalf of two reporters who have been ordered to appear at a trial to identify witnesses to a double murder. Attorneys for The Houston Post and the Houston Chronicle contend the 14th Court of Appeals should order state District Judge William Harmon to quash subpoenas for Post reporter Felix Sanchez and Chronicle reporter James T. Campbell under the qualified privilege of the First Amendment. The reporters wrote stories about a double killing last May and interviewed witnesses who asked to remain anonymous. Harmon ordered them to appear at the murder trial and identify any spectators who might be among the people they interviewed. The defendant is accused of murdering two other men during an argument at a high school graduation party in east Harris County. After the killings, Sanchez and Campbell arrived at the scene and interviewed partygoers who asked to remain anonymous. The reporters say they don't know the names of their sources.

DOC.HEAD: Pravda Editor Says He Survived Reporters Revolt
DOC.TEXT: The editor of Pravda says he survived a mutiny by reporters, who want to raise plummeting circulation by replacing rambling speech text with more lively copy. On Oct. 11, Pravda published an unsigned denial of reports that the newspaper's Communist Party organization called last week for the resignation of Ivan Frolov, who was appointed editor a year ago. The notice, buried on page 8, acknowledged that the newspaper's party organization had ``sharp, sometimes tough'' discussions during two days of meetings and that ``criticism of the leadership was expressed.'' But, it said, the meetings ``did not adopt a no-confidence resolution in the chief editor.'' Frolov said at an unusual news conference on Oct. 10 that ``these people thought they could organize a mini-coup.'' Outside in the hallway, Pravda writers held what they called a ``parallel'' news conference about their efforts to unseat Frolov. They said they sought to improve the newspaper, officially described as the ``organ of the Central Committee of the Communist Party.'' Pravda satirist Vladislav Yegorov told reporters the party organization at the newspaper had passed a resolution asking the Central Committee to ``review the question of the editorial board.'' He said 140 workers at Pravda who are members of the Communist Party cell had considered calling for Frolov's resignation but dropped the idea as too provocative. Last year Pravda's circulation dropped by 3 million, to about 7 million, and it appears to be falling further during a subscription drive now under way, Yegorov said. He said readers were bored by the format of Pravda, which last week devoted its pages to the full texts of speeches from a two-day meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee - a body of diminishing relevance in Soviet politics. ``Our readers don't want that,'' said Yegorov. ``The most important thing is to make it a newspaper that is interesting to readers.''
DOC.HEAD: Singapore's Prime Minister Blames Press for Tiananmen Massacre
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore lashed out at the media Oct. 15, blaming television for the bloody crackdown on China's pro-democracy movement and the Western press for the fluctuations in Hong Kong's stock exchange. Lee also defended his country's rigid restrictions on foreign media, accusing newspapers such as the Asian Wall Street Journal of interfering in Singapore's domestic politics. Lee made his comments in a speech before the Commonwealth Press Union, which comprises more than 500 newspapers, news agencies and periodicals in 30 countries of the British Commonwealth. He said China's students were seduced by television into believing they could change China. ``I believe it is this contextless television experience that led to the tragedy of Tiananmen on June 4,'' he said. Lee said students in China for years had watched Chinese news reports on demonstrations in the Philippines and student protests in South Korea. ``China's students forgot that China was a very different country from either the Philippines or South Korea, two countries with close links to the United States where the media and Congress wield immense influence,'' he said. Lee also blasted the foreign press in Hong Kong for trying ``to foist Western values'' on the British colony. He blamed the foreign press for causing large drops on Hong Kong's stock market. ``Much of the gyrations . . . could have been lessened if the Western press based in Hong Kong had not crusaded for their vision of democracy in Hong Kong,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Press Institute Calls Kenyan Magazine Ban Outrageous
DOC.TEXT: The International Press Institute criticized Kenya's single-party government for banning a magazine that had repeatedly called for multiple political parties. The Nairobi Law Monthly was the fourth publication banned by the government in two years. In a message to Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi, institute director Peter Galliner said: ``This outrageous attack is only the latest incident in a campaign of intimidation and harassment of this publication. ``Freedom of the press is an internationally recognized right and we urgently call on your government to take immediate steps to see that the banning order is withdrawn.'' The institute, an independent organization of publishers and editors in some 60 countries, released a copy of the leader Oct. 9. The magazine was banned Sept. 28 under an order signed by Kenyan Attorney General Matthew Muli. The ban came two days after Moi threatened to arrest critics as part of a renewed crackdown on those calling for multiple parties. The magazine's editor, Gitobu Imanyara, was detained for three weeks earlier this year and was charged with sedition in July.
DOC.HEAD: Press Institute Concerned Over Sri Lankan Broadcaster's Abduction
DOC.TEXT: The International Press Institute said Oct. 9 that it is deeply concerned about the abduction and disappearance of a Sri Lankan broadcaster. The broadcaster, Kumaraguru Kugamoorthy, a Tamil, was abducted Sept. 6 on his way home from work in Colombo. He worked as a program producer for the Tamil service of the Sri Lankan Broadcasting Corp. A London-based human rights group, Article 19, quoted witnesses as saying he was seen being dragged into a jeep by a group of armed men, including one in khaki uniform. Police returned his motorbike to his family, but did not tell them the circumstances under which it was found nor provide further information, Article 19 said Oct. 1. Peter Gallinger, director of the press institute, called for an investigation in a letter to Sri lankan President Ranasinghe Premadasa.
DOC.HEAD: Joint Soviet-Western Periodicals Carving Their Niche
DOC.TEXT: Shortly after the U.S.-Soviet business weekly Commersant hit the newsstands in January, government ministers started calling editorial offices to find out how to muzzle its sharp commentaries. ``When they found out we were independent, they kind of lost their bearings and gave up,'' said Vladimir Yakovlev, Commersant's editor in chief. Commersant and two other new Soviet periodicals owe their independence in part to the policy of glasnost and in part to their backing from investors in the United States and other Western countries. Commersant is backed by the U.S. investment company Refco. The tabloid provides a weekly barometer of the ups and downs of foreign enterprises' performances in the Soviet Union and critical features on Soviet economics. Its Russian circulation is 350,000 and its English distribution is 30,000, Yakovlev said. Commersant recently went on sale in the United States. According to officials of the State Committee for the Press, joint ventures have filed 23 applications to start publications, while private individuals filed 60 and political parties and public groups filed 20. Izvestia and Hearst Publications published a pilot issue of a new English-Russian newspaper on July 4 and hope to be issuing a regular edition next year. The weekly magazine Business Week brought out a dual language edition last summer and also hopes to publish regularly. Special one-time editions of Western magazines, including Ladies Home Journal and Paris Match, also have appeared.

DOC.HEAD: Hilliard Elected Treasurer of ASNE
DOC.TEXT: William A. Hilliard, editor of The Oregonian in Portland, was elected by the board of the American Society of Newspaper Editors to become treasurer of the organization next April. The selection at the board's meeting Oct. 5-6 put Hilliard in line to become the society's first black president in 1994, after rising through the group's offices. Hilliard, who began working at The Oregonian in 1952 as a copy aide, joined ASNE in 1979 and has been a member of the board since 1985. He is chairman of the society's Writing Awards Board and has been chairman of the education for journalism, literacy and membership committees. In other business, the board passed resolutions supporting women sportswriters, encouraging diversity in the newsroom, supporting educating the public on the First Amendment and welcoming the innocent verdict in the obscenity trial over the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibition in Cincinnati. After the meeting, an ASNE delegation left on a two-week tour of Poland, Germany, Hungary and Czechoslovakia. The group, led by ASNE President Burl Osborne, editor and president of The Dallas Morning News, planned to meet with journalists and media organizations as well as political leaders. Accompanying Osborne are Robert P. Clark, retired vice president of Harte-Hanks Newspapers; George M. Ewing Sr., editor and publisher of The Daily Messenger in Canandaigua, N.Y.; Gregory Favre, executive editor of The Sacramento (Calif.) Bee; Robert H. Giles, editor and publiser of The Detroit News; Robert J. Haiman, president of the Poynter Institute for Media Studies in St. Petersubrg, Fla. Also, David Lawrence Jr., publisher of The Miami Herald; Ted M. Natt, editor and publisher of The Daily News of Longview, Wash.; Peter S. Prichard, eidtor of USA Today; Watson Sims, director of the Communications Exchange Organization in Princeton, N.J.; and Lee Stinnett, executive director of ASNE.
DOC.HEAD: Newsprint Recycling Board Named in Maryland
DOC.TEXT: Gov. William Donald Schaefer appointed a nine-member board Oct. 10 to oversee Maryland's newspaper recycling law. The law passed this year by the General Assembly requires that by 1992, 12 percent of newsprint used by Maryland newspapers must be recycled paper. The quota rises to 40 percent by 1998. Fees will be levied against publishers that do not meet the goals. The Newsprint Recycling Board will have authority to waive the fees for publishers that prove they cannot reach the quota. The board is made up of representatives of newspaper publishers, state agencies, private businesses and environmental groups.
DOC.HEAD: Post, Paper Firm in Venture To Boost Newspaper Recyling
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post and a Baltimore waste paper processor are planning a newspaper recycling venture. The Post and Canusa Corp. hope to open a paper-bundling plant in Dundalk that could handle up to 6,000 tons of old newspapers a month. A corporation they formed, Capitol Fiber Inc., has submitted the proposal to Baltimore County. Under a county law the plant must be approved by county environmental officials. The plant would sort and bundle the papers in 2,000 pound bales, prior to shipment to recycling plants, said Bruce Fleming, president of Canusa. Capitol Fiber's application says it would initially be getting about 1,800 tons of old newspapers a month picked up from Washington sidewalks. The company would charge the city $10 a ton for the paper. Fleming said he hoped to strike similar deals with Baltimore and Baltimore County for their newspaper, once they implement recycling plans.
DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Newspapers Set Use of Recycled Newsprint
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers in Louisiana will begin printing on recycled newsprint by 1992, officials of the Louisiana Press Association said Oct. 9. The voluntary plan calls for recycled paper to account for 10 percent of the state's newsprint consumption in 1992, 20 percent by 1995, 30 percent by 1997 and 40 percent by 2000. David Manship, associate publisher of the State Times and Morning Advocate in Baton Rouge, said the program is similar to one now in place in New York state. He said most major producers should be able to supply newsprint with recyclable fibers by 1992.
DOC.HEAD: BROADCAST NEWS
DOC.TEXT: CBS Earnings Down 30 Percent in Third Quarter

CBS Inc. reported a 30 percent decline in earnings in the third quarter, citing higher television expenditures, partly for news coverage of events in the Middle East. The network said Oct. 10 that its after-tax profit fell to $43.5 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared to earnings of $61.9 million during the same period in 1989. Revenue rose 12 percent to $662 million from $593 million. Laurence A. Tisch, CBS president and chief executive, said increased programming costs contributed to the weak quarter. He said the televison network spent more money on new program development, first-run summer programming and the aquisition of program rights for sporting events. The company said revenue growth increased primarily from broadcasts of major league baseball games. ``CBS's earnings rre likely to continue to decline,'' Tisch said. ``However, CBS has the cash reserves to steer through an economic downturn, while sustaining our long-term plan to improve ratings.'' For the first nine months of the year, CBS earned $266.8 million on revenue of $2.34 billion. That compared to a net profit of $236.8 million on revenue of $2.10 billion a year earlier.
DOC.HEAD: CBS's New Late News Show Yields Lower Ratings
DOC.TEXT: CBS's new late-night ``America Tonight'' news program was third in late-night ratings its first week and had a smaller audience than the entertainment shows it replaced. The half-hour series co-anchored by Charles Kuralt and Lesley Stahl averaged a 2.3 rating in the first week of October, two-tenths of a ratings point less than the preceding week's entertainment shows. ABC's ``Nightline'' was well ahead of ``America Tonight,'' averaging a 4.7 rating, but NBC's ``Tonight'' show was the leader, at 5.6.
DOC.HEAD: `20-20' Producer Resigns Over Bogus Buckwheat Interview
DOC.TEXT: A producer responsible for an interview with a ``Buckwheat'' impostor on ABC's ``20-20'' resigned, the network said. Lynn Murray resigned in a ``mutual decision'' with ABC because of the Oct. 5 segment, ``Whatever Happened to `Our Gang?','' spokeswoman Maurie Perl said Oct. 11. The news magazine aired an interview with a man who claimed he played Buckwheat in the ``Our Gang'' comedies of the 1930s and '40s and was now working as a grocery bagger in Tempe, Ariz. William Thomas, who actually portrayed Buckwheat, died in 1980. Victor Neufeld, the program's executive producer, decided Murray did not properly handle research for the segment, Perl said. Murray had worked with ``20-20'' in several capacities for 10 years, Perl said.

DOC.HEAD: Financial News Network Fires Executive
DOC.TEXT: Financial News Network, the 24-hour business-oriented cable television service, said Oct. 12 that it fired a top executive for improper financial dealings. The company said C. Steven Bolen was dismissed as chief financial officer following a board investigation that concluded he ``received compensation payments that were not properly authorized and . . . that certain bank accounts administered under (his) direction were not properly recorded.'' The company said two other employees in the accounting staff were put on leave while FNN reviews their status. Bolen has been on leave since summer, when questions about payments to him first surfaced, said sources close to FNN who spoke on condition they not be identified. Bolen, who had been with the company for about five years and worked out of its Los Angeles office, earned $185,000 annually. No charges have been filed against him. Bolen could not be located for comment. FNN said it believes all the funds have been accounted for. FNN spokeswoman Amber Gordon would not comment on how much money was involved. Separately, FNN and Infotechnology Inc., which owns 47 percent of the news service as well as 97 percent of UPI, said they had terminated the services of their accounting firm, Deloitte & Touche. A committee comprised of FNN board members recommended the termination because it didn't think the firm ``would be able to complete the audit work in a timely fashion,'' FNN said. Deloitte, in turn, notified FNN, Infotechnology and UPI that the financial statements it prepared for them should no longer be relied upon. Deloitte said it was withdrawing its 1989 opinion of FNN's financial health because of fresh information concerning some transactions between FNN and UPI, as well as questions about 1989 financial statements by Bolen. FNN since has retained Coopers & Lybrand as its auditors.
DOC.HEAD: ABC, British Agency To Send News to Japanese Network
DOC.TEXT: ABC News and Worldwide Television News have agreed to provide domestic and international news reports to Fuji TV, Japan's largest commercial network. The deal, announced Oct. 10, was the second in two months between American and Japanese networks. CBS and the Tokyo Broadcasting System agreed in September to combine resources and technology for worldwide newsgathering. The CBS contract is exclusive and gives Tokyo Broadcasting the right to air in Japan such programs as ``CBS Evening News'' and ``60 Minutes.'' The ABC-WTN contract with Fuji is non-exclusive, according to WTN, a London-based agency serving 1,000 clients worldwide, including CBS and CNN. The Fuji deal also doesn't provide for sharing facilities overseas nor does it give the Japanese company rights to air ABC's regularly scheduled news programs, said Scott Michaelis, WTN's regional executive for North America. Fuji will be allowed to excerpt news reports broadcast on ABC's ``World News Tonight,'' he said. Fuji also will get all of WTN's international news reports under the agreement. ABC, which owns 45 percent of WTN, recently agreed in principle to raise its stake in the company to 80 percent. London-based Independent Television News and Australia's Nine Network would share the remaining percentage.
DOC.HEAD: Rural Backyard Dishes Favored in Cable TV Deal
DOC.TEXT: A new proposed compromise for re-regulating cable TV would require the industry to sell network programs to some 3 million mostly rural owners of backyard satellite dishes, its Senate sponsors said Oct. 12. Providing details of an accord negotiated over the past two weeks, Sens. Al Gore, D-Tenn., and Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., said cable networks could still restrict their programs to subscribers of local cable distributors. But Gore said the compromise also now includes ``critical language protecting the backyard home satellite dish market'' - a provision that cable operators have vigorously fought the past eight years. However, he acknowledged that the bill could still be stymied in the waning days of the 101st Congress by objections from other senators and the Bush administration. Both the Senate bill and a similar measure passed by the House last month would require cable operators to provide a ``basic tier'' of service - local and public TV stations plus government-access channels - at rates to be regulated by the Federal Communications Commission.
DOC.HEAD: Dorfman Switches From CNN to CNBC; Loeb Joining FNN
DOC.TEXT: Financial reporter Dan Dorfman is leaving CNN to join CNBC, and Fortune magazine editor Marshall Loeb will join Financial News Network as a commentator, the two cable networks said Oct. 8. Both will start their new jobs on Oct. 15. Dorfman, who will continue a twice-weekly financial column for USA Today, signed a multiyear contract to report for CNBC, a 24-hour consumer and business news cable service co-owned by NBC. Loeb, who previously did financial commentary for the CBS Radio Network, will continue at Fortune. In his new FNN job, he will do a daily 60-second commentary called ``Managing Today.''
DOC.HEAD: CBS Sportscaster Apologizes for Polish Comment
DOC.TEXT: CBS sportscaster Jack Buck apologized Oct. 10 for comments he made after entertainer Bobby Vinton flubbed the national anthem before a baseball playoff game. Vinton stumbled over several lines of ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' before the Cincinnati Reds' 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates on Oct. 9. Afterward, Buck said, ``Well, when you're Polish and you're from Pittsburgh, you can do anything you want with the words.'' Vinton, a native of nearby Canonsburg, is known as ``The Polish Prince.'' Buck's comment drew criticism from Lawrence R. Wujcikowski, president of the Polish Falcons of America, a Polish hertiage group based in Pittsburgh. ``If (Buck) wanted to comment on Mr. Vinton's singing, then he should have done that. But he could have left being Polish and living in Pittsburgh out of it,'' Wujcikowski said. Buck said he meant his remarks as a compliment to Vinton. ``On the heels of the national anthem, I tried to pay a compliment to Bobby Vinton and it didn't come out right,'' he said. ``I was saying that if he messed it up, that's OK because everybody loves him. And he did mess it up, didn't he?''
DOC.HEAD: Virgin Island Cable TV Company To Buy FM Radio Station
DOC.TEXT: St. Croix Cable TV agreed to buy a Virgin Islands FM radio station that halted operations in September after being severely damaged by Hurricane Hugo in 1989. Todd Klindworth, a spokesman for St. Croix Cable TV, said the purchase price for WVIQ-FM was $200,000. Tom Carter, spokesman for Texas-based Caribbean Media Services, owner of WVIQ, said the FCC had agreed to expedite the approval process because of the financial strain the station has been under since Hurricane Hugo. He said previously that the station had run up $225,000 in losses since the hurricane, including an unpaid $175,000 insurance claim.

DOC.HEAD: Harnett To Head Hawaii Newspaper Agency
DOC.TEXT: USA Today executive Richard Harnett was named president of Hawaii Newspaper Agency Inc. on Oct. 11. The company manages the building, facilities, circulation and advertising of The Honolulu Advertiser and The Honolulu Star-Bulletin, which publish under a joint operating agreement. Harnett, who has been vice president of circulation for USA Today, also will serve as president and chief operating officer of Gannett Pacific Corp., which publishes the Star-Bulletin. He replaces Albert Dolata, who will join the Gannett corporate staff in Rosslyn, Va., as associate director of labor relations.
DOC.HEAD: Lindsay Named Publisher in Fergus Falls, Minn.
DOC.TEXT: Ronald L. Lindsay, who managed a suburban newspaper group the past 10 years, has been named publisher of The Daily Journal. He succeeds Tim Craig, who has become advertising consultant for the Kansas City Division of Thomson Newspapers after 2{ years as publisher-general manager of the Journal, which is owned by Thomson. Lindsay came to the Journal from Kansas City, Mo., where he has managed Townsend Communications, a suburban newspaper group. He began his career as an advertising salesman with The Morning Star and Register Republic in Rockford, Ill., becoming assistant advertising director during his 12{ years there. He moved to Keokuk, Iowa, in 1973 as general manager of Daily Gate City Co., a group of several newspapers.
DOC.HEAD: Nadler Joins Sun-Times as Executive Editor
DOC.TEXT: Mark B. Nadler, managing editor of the Saint Paul (Minn.) Pioneer Press, was named Oct. 8 as executive editor and vice president of The Sun-Times. He assumes the new job Oct. 29. Before moving to St. Paul in 1986, Nadler was on the staff of The Wall Street Journal in New York, most recently serving as editor of special projects. During his 17-year journalism career, Nadler also has worked for The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer and the Lexington (Ky.) Herald-Leader.
DOC.HEAD: Coghlan New Executive Editor in Pensacola, Fla.
DOC.TEXT: Curtis Coghlan, executive editor of The Jackson (Tenn.) Sun, moved to the same post at the Pensacola News Journal on Oct. 10. Both newspapers are owned by Gannett Co. Inc. Coghlan succeeds Anne Saul, who was named corporate news systems editor for Gannett in Arlington, Va. He began his career as a reporter at the Jackson (Miss.) Daily News and later was UPI bureau manager in Mississippi. He returned to the Daily News as city editor in 1982 and was named managing editor of The Jackson (Tenn.) Sun three years ago.
DOC.HEAD: Roler Named Editor in Grants Pass, Ore.
DOC.TEXT: Dennis Roler was named editor of the Grants Pass Daily Courier on Oct. 12. Roler, who joined the paper in 1986 as city editor, replaces Roger Morton, who left in July. Roler previously was business editor and assistant city editor at the Marin (Calif.) Independent Journal, and editorial page editor, business editor and reporter for The News-Review in Roseburg, Ore.
DOC.HEAD: Parsons Named Managing Editor in Sarasota, Fla.
DOC.TEXT: Allen Parsons, managing editor of the Spartanburg Herald-Journal, has been named managing editor of the Sarasota (Fla.) Herald-Tribune. Both papers are part of the New York Times Regional Newspaper Group. Parsons will take the post in November. He succeeds Diane McFarlin, who was promoted to executive editor.
DOC.HEAD: New York Times Appoints Four Senior Editors
DOC.TEXT: The New York Times announced four senior editing appointments Oct. 7. Warren Hoge, an assistant managing editor, is moving to the staff of The New York Times Magazine to prepare to succeed magazine editor James L. Greenfield, who is retiring at the end of the year. Joseph J. Vecchione, sports editor, was named senior editor and is moving to the newsroom administration group that manages personnel, recruitment and finance matters for the Times' 1,000-member news staff. Neil Amdur, deputy sports editor and a former sports reporter, succeeds Vecchione. Paul Goldberger, architecture critic of the Times, will become cultural news editor, heading a department of more than 50 critics, reporters and editors. He succeeds Marvin Siegel, who will move shortly to another senior editing post. Greenfield, 66, became foreign editor of the Times in 1969 and assistant managing editor in 1976. Hoge joined the Times in 1976 as a reporter. He became deputy metropolitan editor in 1977 and bureau chief in Rio de Janeiro in 1979. He was named foreign editor in 1983 and an assistant managing editor in 1986. Vecchione joined the Times as a copy boy in 1960 and worked as a makeup editor and deputy picture editor before becoming editor of Sports Monday and later deputy editor of the national edition. He became sports editor in 1980. Amdur reported for the Times from 1968 to 1975 and from 1976 to 1984. He also worked for The Miami Herald and CBS Sports. Before rejoining the Times this year, he spent six years as editor-in-chief of World Tennis magazine. Goldberger joined the Times magazine staff as an editor in 1972. He was appointed architecture critic in 1973 and won the Pulitzer Prize in 1974 for distinguished criticism.
DOC.HEAD: Taylor Named AP's Correspondent in Norfolk, Va.
DOC.TEXT: Joe Taylor, a newsman in the Richmond bureau of The Associated Press, was named the news cooperative's correspondent in Norfolk on Oct. 11. Taylor joined the AP in Richmond in 1979. He previously worked at two weeklies, The South Hill Enterprise and the Brunswick Times-Gazette.
DOC.HEAD: Executives Named at Time, Sports Illustrated
DOC.TEXT: Sports Illustrated Publisher Donald J. Barr was named an executive vice president of Time Inc. Magazine Co. on Oct. 8, and the company promoted two veteran editors of the sports weekly. Barr joined Time in 1957 and had served as publisher of Sports Illustrated the past five years. He will join the company's corporate policy committee and report directly to Time Chairman Reginald K. Brack Jr. Mark R. Mulvoy steps up as publisher of Sports Illustrated from his post as managing editor. Mulvoy began his career as a reporter for the magazine in 1965. The new managing editor is John L. Papanek, who most recently was managing editor of Sports Illustrated for Kids. Separately, Richard W. Angle Jr. was named a senior vice president of Time Warner Publishing, which includes Time's magazine and book companies. He previously served as senior vice president of operations and chief administrative officer at Time Inc. Magazine Co.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to delete `End of Industry News' tag at end. An 11th add moved as a7011.
DOC.HEAD: TV Guide Reorganizes Editorial Staff
DOC.TEXT: Joe Robinowitz was appointed editor in chief at TV Guide on Oct. 8 and Roger Youman was named editor as part of a reorganization that merges all editorial functions. The magazine's national section and local sections had operated as separate units, with Robinowitz managing the national features section and Youman responsible for the 110 local sections. Robinowitz had been national editor of TV Guide since joining the magazine in September 1989. Prior to that he was general manager of WFXT-TV in Boston for three years and editor of the Boston Herald for four years. Youman has held various positions with TV Guide for 35 years.
DOC.HEAD: Lois Weekes Beck
DOC.TEXT: Lois Weekes Beck, editor of the Las Vegas Optic since 1972, died Oct. 11 after a lengthy illness. She was 63. Mrs. Beck began her journalism career as society editor of the San Antonio Express and later worked as a reporter for The Odessa (Texas) American. Her husband, Stuart, and his brother, Robert, bought the Optic in 1967, and her husband became publisher. Robert Beck is president of the Roswell (N.M.) Daily Record. Survivors include her husband and two daughters.
DOC.HEAD: Anatole Broyard
DOC.TEXT: Anatole Broyard, a literary critic and former editor of The New York Times Book Review, died Oct. 11 of prostate cancer. He was 70. Broyard was a daily book critic for nearly 15 years before serving three years as editor of the Times book review section. After retiring in 1989, he continued to write a monthly essay, ``About Books,'' and compiled a weekly, unsigned column of excerpts from books titled ``Noted With Pleasure.'' Survivors include his wife, a son, a daughter and two sisters.
DOC.HEAD: Douglas Edwards
DOC.TEXT: Douglas Edwards, a World War II radio correspondent who became the nation's first network television anchorman, died of cancer Oct. 13 at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 73. Edwards, who spent all but 10 of his 56-year broadcasting career with CBS News, retired from the network in April 1988. Forty years earlier, CBS tapped Edwards to anchor its nationwide TV news broadcast, titled ``Douglas Edwards with the News.'' He held the job for 14 years before surrendering the seat to Walter Cronkite. He is survived by his wife, three children from a previous marriage, two stepsons and four grandchildren.
DOC.HEAD: Jimmie Earle Fletcher
DOC.TEXT: Jimmie Earle Fletcher, who owned and operated radio stations across Texas, died Oct. 12. He was 76. Fletcher owned radio stations in Fort Worth, Alice, Waco, Midland, San Antonio, Corsicana, Conroe, Kingsville and Cleburne at different times in his career. He owned KNGV in Kingsville and co-owned KOPY and KDSI in Alice at his death. He is survived by his wife and two sons.
DOC.HEAD: Dave Patridge
DOC.TEXT: Dave Patridge, who chronicled his three-year battle with AIDS in a column for the Herald & Review, died Oct. 6. He was 33. Patridge had used the pen name ``Jacob'' to protect the privacy of family and friends, but he allowed the Herald & Review to record his last days in words and pictures. Patridge shared the experience of living with AIDS by keeping a journal that began Nov. 22, 1987, and ended 33 chapters later this past Sept. 9.
DOC.HEAD: Ed Reed
DOC.TEXT: Ed Reed, a nationally syndicated cartoonist, died of leukemia Oct. 7 in Cheltenham, England. He was 82. Reed began his career in the 1940s as a cartoonist for the now-defunct Dallas Journal. He was syndicated in more than 400 newspapers across the United States and Europe. ``Off The Record'' and ``Three Bares'' were two of Reed's many cartoons. Reed retired during the mid-1980s and moved to Europe. He is survived by his wife.
DOC.HEAD: Charles L. Sanders
DOC.TEXT: Charles L. Sanders, managing editor of Ebony magazine, died Oct. 4 after a long illness. He was 58. He began his career at the Cleveland Call & Post as a reporter and feature writer and later was general editor of the newspaper's state editions. In 1963, Sanders joined Ebony as an associate editor. He opened the magazine's first overseas bureau in Paris in 1965 and returned three years later after being named managing editor. Survivors include two sisters and a brother.
DOC.HEAD: Lois Anne Mackay Scripps
DOC.TEXT: Lois Anne MacKay Scripps, wife of Charles E. Scripps Sr., the chairman of E.W. Scripps Co., died Oct. 8 after a two-year illness. She was 62. She married Scripps in 1949 and was active with her husband in promoting literacy. She also worked through the Iner American Press Association to promote a free press in the Western hemisphere. She is survived by her husband, four children, including Charles E. Scripps Jr., general manager at The Courier-Journal in Jupiter, Fla., and Marilyn J. Scripps, news producer at WCPO-TV in Cincinnati, and four grandchildren.
DOC.HEAD: Alma Stead
DOC.TEXT: Alma Stead, a longtime staff writer for the Oxford Eagle, died Oct. 5 after a long illness. She was 62. Stead had worked for the Eagle for 12 years and reported on local government and courts. She previously worked for other nce to Tokyo and other cities in Japan, the Department of Transportation announced on Monday. Three air carriers - United Air Lines, Delta Air Lines and American Airlines - were authorized to serve Tokyo. Delta, America West Airlines and Hawaiian Airlines were authorized to serve two other Japanese cities, Nagoya and Fukuoka. The route awards were granted under a November 1989 agreement which laid the foundation for a major expansion of air service between the United States and Japan. In making the announcement the department noted that the U.S.-Japanese market currently generates more than $6 billion in revenue for both countries. Last year the Japan market ranked third in numbers of passengers, after Canada and Great Britain, and was first in passenger revenue. Monday's announcement is the last of several awards authorizing new flights to Japan. In July, Federal Express, which had been providing all-cargo service to Tokyo, was permitted to serve Nagoya as well. In August, United Cargo Service was selected to operate a new all-cargo service to Tokyo. And in September the department allotted the 450 charter flights authorized by the agreement. Patrick V. Murphy, deputy assistant secretary for international affairs, made the following new selections: -Chicago-Tokyo authority to United with backup authority to American if United does not choose to fly the new route. -Los Angeles-Tokyo authority to Delta with backup authority to American. San Jose-Tokyo authority to American with backup authority to Continental Airlines for Houston-Tokyo service. -Honolulu-Nagoya authority to America West with backup authority to Continental. -Honolulu-Fukuoka authority to Hawaiian Airlines with backup authority to Continental for Los Angeles-Nagoya service. -Portland-Nagoya authority to Delta with backup authority to Continental for Seattle-Nagoya service. Nine air carriers submitted 23 proposals for the new routes, the department said.

DOC.HEAD: AWARDS AND HONORS:
USA Today Executive Receives SPJ's Highest Award
DOC.TEXT: Paul K. McMasters, deputy editorial director of USA Today, was honored Oct. 13 with the Society of Professional Journalists' highest award. The longtime supporter of the society and current chairman of SPJ's Freedom of Information Committee was named as the 1990 Wells Key recipient at the society's annual awards banquet. The Wells Key award memorializes Sigma Delta Chi's second national president, Chester Wells, who died in 1913, shortly after assuming office. The society has since been renamed the Society of Professional Journalists. The incoming society president, Frank Gibson of The Tennessean in Nashville, described McMasters as ``the epitome of the SPJ volunteer.'' ``As chairman of the Freedom of Information Committee, he has given long and unselfish service to carry forward the bedrock mission of SPJ's past and its future,'' Gibson said. On Oct. 12, delegates at SPJ's convention named three Fellows of the Society of Professional Journalists: Loren Ghiglione, editor of The News in Southbridge, Mass.; Georgie Anne Geyer, syndicated columnist for Universal Press Syndicate; and Bernard Shaw, Washington anchor for CNN. Designation as an SPJ Fellow is the highest honor the society gives for public service. Ghiglione, who just complete
DOC.HEAD: Broder To Receive Colby Journalism Award
DOC.TEXT: Syndicated columnist David S. Broder of The Washington Post was selected as this year's recipient of the Elijah Parish Lovejoy award given by Colby College. The award is presented annually in memory of the Colby alumnus who is considered America's first martyr in the struggle to protect freedom of the press. Lovejoy was killed in 1837 while trying to defend his abolitionist newspaper from a pro-slavery mob. Broder, the winner of the 1973 Pulitzer Prize for distinguished commentary, will be honored as the 38th Lovejoy fellow in a Nov. 16 convocation at Colby.

Ted Turner will receive the 1990 Walter Cronkite Award for Excellence in Journalism and Telecommunications from Arizona State University. The award will be presented by Cronkite during a Nov. 7 luncheon in Phoenix. . . . Former NBC-TV chief Grant Tinker says television has lost its magic and most people simply regard it as furniture. ``There are so many viewing alternatives that there just aren't enough creative people to supply the software just to feed the hardware,'' he said in an interview on the syndicated ``Personalities.'' . . . Talk show host Larry King says his fantasy interview would be with Jesus Christ. ``I would ask him if he believed that he was born of virgin birth, because whatever the answer is changes or reinforces the world,'' King said in an interview in People magazine's Oct. 22 issue.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News
