DOC.HEAD: CBS Records to Change Name to Sony Music Entertainment
DOC.TEXT: Sony Corp., which acquired CBS Records Inc. in 1988, will change the music company's corporate name to Sony Music Entertainment Inc. under the terms of the aquisition agreement, the company announced Monday. CBS Inc. had agreed to allow Sony to use the CBS Records name for three years. The name change will take effect Jan. 1, 1991, but it won't affect the company's domestic record labels, which are Columbia, Epic, Associated and WTG, said spokesman Bob Altshuler. The company's artists include Michael Jackson, New Kids on the Block, Bruce Springsteen, Billy Joel and Barbara Streisand. In a separate announcement, Sony said it had acquired the Columbia label for international use from EMI. EMI had owned the rights to use the name outside the U.S. except in Japan and Spain. Starting Jan. 1, Sony will use the Columbia name internationally except in those two countries. The music of Columbia artists, including Springsteen, Joel and Streisand, had been released in foreign markets under the CBS trademark.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Trade Surplus Shrinks
DOC.TEXT: Japan's trade surplus in September fell from a year ago as the Gulf crisis pushed up oil import bills, the Finance Ministry said Monday. The nation's exports exceeded its imports by $6.9 billion in September, down 3.9 percent from the same month last year, the ministry said. In trade with the United States, Japan's surplus narrowed to $4.31 billion in September from $4.78 billion a year earlier. Exports to the United States fell 5.7 percent to $8.26 billion, while imports grew by 1.5 percent to $3.96 billion. Overall, exports rose by 6.1 percent to $25.80 billion from $24.31 billion in September 1989. Imports increased by 10.3 percent to $18.89 billion from $17.13 billion a year earlier. After Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the cost for crude oil imports soared 48.7 percent from September 1989 to $2.54 billion. A barrel of oil averaged $22.32 in September, up 31.9 percent from a year earlier. Aside from oil, economists said overall import growth has continued strong because of Japan's firm demand for industrial and consumer goods. Amid September imports, gold accounted for $844.76 million, up 352.4 percent from a year earlier. Finance Ministry officials said they couldn't explain the surge. Economists said investors might be tending to buy gold for security during the Gulf crisis. For the first half of fiscal 1990, which began April 1, Japan's trade surplus shrank by 11.4 percent to $29.10 billion from $32.86 billion in the 1989 period, the ministry said. Exports in the first half rose 1.6 percent to $139.43 billion, while imports climbed 5.7 percent to $110.33 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Gilmore to Retire as Editor of Reader's Digest
DOC.TEXT: The Reader's Digest Association Inc. said Monday that Kenneth O. Gilmore plans to step down at the end of the year as editor-in-chief of Reader's Digest for health reasons. Gilmore, 59, will be replaced after six years in the top editorial post by Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, 46, currently the magazine's deputy editor-in-chief. The announcement said Gilmore has Parkinson's disease and decided to step down because ``I cannot carry as full a workload as the editor-in-chief role requires.'' Gilmore became editor-in-chief at Reader's Digest in 1984. He joined the magazine in 1957 in the Washington editorial office, and moved to the company's world headquarters in Pleasantville in 1973 as assistant managing editor. Tomlinson joined Reader's Digest as a staff writer in the Washington editorial office in 1968, held a variety of positions with the magazine and moved to Pleasantville as senior editor in 1981. Reader's Digest is published in 15 languages and 39 editions and claims a readership of 100 million worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Pepsico Earnings Up 25 Percent in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Pepsico Inc. said its third-quarter earnings rose 25 percent as all of its businesses posted sales and profit gains. The soft drink, food and restaurant company said it earned $336.6 million, or 42 cents per share, in the quarter ended Sept. 8, up from $269.3 million, or 34 cents per share, in the same period of 1989. Revenue increased to $4.48 billion from $3.9 billion. Pepsico said its soft drink business had an 11 percent revenue gain, to $1.7 billion, while operating profits in that division rose 16 percent to $239.3 million. The company said its U.S. soft drink operations chalked up gains despite the loss of business from Burger King fast-food restaurants, which switched to Coca-Cola soft drinks from Pepsico's brands. Pepsico's soft drinks include Pepsi-Cola, Diet Pepsi and Mountain Dew. Pepsico said revenue from its snack food business rose 16 percent to $1.2 billion, while operating profits were up 14 percent to $240.6 million. The company's snack food brands include Doritos, Tostitos, Crunch Tators and Santitas. The firm's restaurant business recorded an 18 percent gain in revenue, to $1.5 billion. Operating profits increased 6 percent to $147.3 million, after $17.6 million was deducted for the closing of unprofitable restaurants. Pepsico's restaurants include Kentucky Fried Chicken, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut. For the first nine months of the year, Pepsico reported earnings of $811 million, or $1.01 per share, up from $699.3 million, or 88 cents per share, in the same period of 1989. Revenue for the three quarters rose to $12.36 billion from $10.45 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Upjohn Reports Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Third-quarter earnings of Upjohn Co. rose 10.9 percent mainly because of increases in profits for its core pharmaceutical business, the company said Monday. Upjohn said it earned $112.2 million, or 60 cents a share, during the July-September period this year compared with $101.1 million, or 54 cents a share, during the same time last year. The earnings came on revenues of $748.3 million in the quarter, up from $663.2 million last year. The company said worldwide health-care product sales rose 11 percent during the period. Leaders included Ansaid, an anti-inflammatory agent and, in overseas markets, steroids. U.S. and overseas sales each rose 13 percent during the period. The jump was due to price and volume increases, as well as currency fluctuations. For the first nine months of the year, Upjohn's earnings rose 12.1 percent to $342.2 million, or $1.80 a share, on sales of $2.2 billion, compared with $305.2 million, or $1.64 a share, on revenues of $2.1 billion. Upjohn makes human and animal health-care products, agricultural products and specialty chemicals.

DOC.HEAD: Intel Announces Powerful New Chips for Laptop Computers
DOC.TEXT: Intel Corp. announced Monday a set of compact, power-saving microprocessor chips that will enable computer makers to produce smaller laptop computers with longer battery life. In picking Tokyo to announce the new version of its highly popular 386 microprocessor, dubbed the 386 SL, the U.S. chip company underscored Japan's growing domination of laptops - one of the fastest-growing areas of the computer market. Intel's powerful 386 microprocessor is used as the ``brains'' of many IBM-compatible personal computers, but previous versions consumed relatively large amounts of power, helping drain the batteries of portable computers. Intel said the new chips, made especially for laptop and smaller ``palmtop'' computers, would cut power use in half. The announcement of the 386 SL and other associated chips represents Intel's entry into the market for ``chip sets,'' or packages of chips used by computer makers to build clones of IBM and other computers. Advances in semiconductor technology since Intel introduced the first 386 processor in 1985 also have allowed it to combine the functions of many chips in one microprocessor. Intel said the new 386 SL processor contains 855,000 transistors, and includes a short-term memory, a main memory controller and computer management circuitry. With the new chip set, a computer that mimics the popular AT model of International Business Machines Corp. can be built with only 10 chips plus memory on one circuit board measuring four by six inches, compared with 170 chips for early 386-based computers, Intel said. By 1993, only one chip plus memory will be needed to make the same computer, said David House, president of Intel's Microcomputer Components Group. ``We have shrunk the 386 to a fraction of its original size,'' said Intel President Andrew Grove. ``This also made it possible for the chip to run faster and for us to make it more cheaply. But more importantly, it leaves us the room to add additional chip functions.'' Included in the 386 SL is a new power management system that automatically shuts off unused computer components to conserve battery life. Lower power consumption also allows manufacturers to reduce the weight of laptops by using smaller batteries, one of the heaviest components. Intel said the 386 SL will cost $176 in bulk. Computers containing the chips will become available early next year, it said. Grove said Japan now accounts for 10 percent of Intel's approximately $4 billion in annual sales - a share that may grow with the new chip set. ``We brought this introduction to Japan in recognition of Japan's leadership in computer packaging and display technology, which are the other key technologies in portable computers,'' Grove told reporters. While U.S. companies remain strong n desktop computers, Japanese companies have introduced a flurry of high-performance laptops and are rapidly increasing their world market share. Laptop sales have grown particularly rapidly in Japan, where limited housing and office space often prohibits the permanent use of desk space for a full-size personal computer.

DOC.HEAD: United Places Order Worth Up to $22 Billion With Boeing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with further details
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines' parent company today announced an order worth up to $22 billion for 128 Boeing aircraft, the largest airplane deal in history. The agreement includes firm orders for 34 Boeing model 777s - the first-ever purchase of that new plane - and 30 Boeing 747-400s, plus options on 34 model 777s and 30 model 747-400s. United, one of the nation's biggest airlines, had come close to placing the wide-body order earlier this year but postponed it in July at the request of UAL's labor unions, who were leading an effort to buy the company. The employees failed to get bank financing for a $4.4 billion bid and UAL's board rejected their offer last Tuesday. This is United's third major aircraft order in 18 months. Its last order, for 370 narrow-body Boeing jetliners, came in April 1989. ``This purchase will allow United to replace older aircraft as well as expand both its domestic and international services,'' said Stephen Wolf, chairman of UAL Corp., the parent company of Chicago-based United. ``In short, it will ensure that this company is positioned to compete aggressively around the world,'' he said in a statement. In Seattle, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group spokesman Richard Schleh said the twin-engine 777, designed to fill a market niche between the 747-400 and the existing 767-300 widebody, will be 209 feet long, have a wingspan of 197 feet, and will seat 360 to 390 passengers in two classes. ``The importance of today's commitment for Boeing cannot be overstated,'' said Boeing chairman and chief executive officer Frank Shrontz. ``With a ratification by Boeing's board on Oct. 29, this order will launch an all-new 777 aircraft family - which will set a new standard for very large twin-engine operations around the world.'' United is to receive its first 777s in May 1995 and the first of its new 747s in 1994, Schleh said. Both planes will be powered by variations of Pratt & Whitney's PW4000 engine. United had long been rumored as the 777's ``launch'' customer. Boeing confirmed this summer it was discussing the 777 with United and seven other carriers, including American Airlines, British Airways, Japan Airlines and Cathay Pacific. United's 777s will seat 363 passengers, 38 in first class and 325 in economy. The 747s, which normally seat 412 in three classes, will be in a variety of configurations tailored to specific markets, Boeing said. Boeing earlier had said it planned the 777 for 350-375 passengers. Boeing plans to build the jets with folding wingtips, to allow it to fit at existing airport gates. United, however, has not yet selected the folding wings as an option, Schleh said. The 777 will have a range of up to 4,800 statute miles. That compares with the long-range 767-300, which can carry 261 passengers in mixed classes 7,200 miles, and the 747-400, the world's largest commercial jet, which can fly 8,000 miles. Boeing already is talking about building a ``family'' of 777 aircraft and has proposed a version that could haul 300-320 up to 7,600 miles. The design eventually could be adapted further with a stretched fuselage, Boeing says.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Minister Discounts Skyrocketing Oil Prices in Event of War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 5 grafs after 4th graf, But he, to expand on Saudi capacity to combat oil crisis. Picks up 5th graf pvs, Ameeri was.
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaiti Oil Minister Rashid al-Ameeri Monday discounted speculation that oil prices would reach $100 a barrel in the event of a military strike to liberate Kuwait. Ameeri, who is with the Kuwaiti government-in-exile set up in Saudi Arabia after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion, told a press conference that oil prices would increase in the event of hostilities, but not that high. He said Iraqi troops have placed mines around Kuwaiti oil fields, refineries and other installations. War would result in further damage to Kuwaiti oil installations, he said. But he added that Kuwaiti leaders have drawn up contingency plans to reconstruct the facilities with international assistance. Ameeri's statements were clearly intended to reassure the world about the oil supply as more and more Kuwaitis are heard expressing impatience with the U.N. sanctions against Iraq and pressing for a U.S.-led military strike to end the 10-week-old Iraqi occupation of their country. Independent oil industry executives have said the market would suffer a severe upheaval in the event of a military conflagration, but the extent of the oil price hikes would depend on the amount of damage to the oil facilities and the duration of hostilities. They've also noted that Saudi Arabia, which sits on one-third of the world's proven oil reserves, would exert itself to stabilize the market. The Saudis were instrumental in offsetting the shortfall caused by Iraq's invasion, which took 4 million barrels per day off the market. The kingdom increased its own output by about 2 million barrels per day to 7.5 million barrels and urged other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase their production. Oil experts note that the kingdom is also preparing to reuse oil facilities that were laid to waste during the lean years of the glutted world oil market in the early to mid-1980s. Ameeri was attending a three-day conference in Jiddah of prominent Kuwaiti exiles discussing their country's plight and its future. He said the recent increase in oil prices was not the result of a shortage in oil supplies, but of fears about war in the Gulf. Former Saudi Oil Minister Ahmed Zaki Yamani said recently that oil prices would rise to $100 dollars a barrel if war broke out. Ameeri noted that oil production has increased to make up for lost supplies from Kuwait and Iraq. He also said countries could release oil from their strategic reserves. ``If the crisis is resolved quickly, then the shortfall in the market can be offset,'' he said. ``But if the crisis lingers on, the market would not be able to put up with the adverse consequences.'' Ameeri estimated Kuwait was losing $50 million to $60 million a day in income because of the shutdown of its oil industry. Kuwait's pre-invasion output was 1.5 million barrels a day. He also estimated that the Iraqis are now pumping about 90,000 barrels a day, just meeting the needs of local power stations and desalination plants.

DOC.HEAD: East Europe's First Cellular Phone Used To Call Quayle
DOC.TEXT: The first cellular telephone system in Eastern Europe went into operation Monday in Budapest, and the first call went to U.S. Vice President Dan Quayle, officials said. The phone system is operated by WesTel Radiotelefon Ltd., a joint venture of U S West Inc. of the United States and the Hungarian Telecommunications Co. The Hungarian phone company holds a 51 percent stake in the venture, while U S West, a regional phone company based outside Denver, owns the rest. Hungary's minister of commerce and trade, Akos Peter Bod, telephoned Quayle and U.S. Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher, the venture said in a statement. The new system initially will serve 3,000 subscribers in the capital, and double that by February, officials said. The venture plans to expand service to the highway corridor between Budapest and Vienna by the end of 1993. U S West also has an agreement to build a cellular system in Czechoslovakia, and said it is bidding to provide the service in Poland

DOC.HEAD: Big Three Report Early-October Sales
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: The early October sales rate for cars and trucks made by the Big Three automakers in North America dropped 4.8 percent from the same period last year, when sales began a three-month slump, the automakers said Monday. Year-to-year comparisons were clouded by wild swings in the September and October sales rates last year, prompted mainly by incentives and announcements of price increases. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said their domestically made cars and light trucks sold at an average daily rate of 27,620 from Oct. 1-10 this year, compared with a daily rate of 29,016 during the same time last year. Car and truck sales fell 1.5 percent and 10.7 percent, respectively. Consumers who planned to buy cars in the last quarter of 1989 headed to dealerships early to take advantage of incentives before they ended and to avoid previously announced price boosts for 1990-model cars and trucks. For example, GM offered its dealers big incentives in September 1989 to clear their lots for 1990 cars and trucks. Customers flocked to showrooms, and that resulted in sharply lower sales rates in October. In turn, that colored Monday's year-to-year, early October comparisons. GM's car sales were up 15.9 percent while those of Ford, which didn't offer incentives like GM did last year, dropped 23.8 percent. Through Oct. 10 of this year, sales of cars and trucks by the Big Three were running 8.1 percent behind last year's pace, with car sales down 10.4 percent and truck sales off 4.4 percent. Ford said its early October car sales fell 17.2 percent and truck sales were down 23.8 percent, combining for a 21.3 percent decline in vehicle sales. The company's year-to-date car and truck sales were down 9.1 percent. GM said its vehicle sales were up 13.3 percent over last year. In addition to the 15.9 percent increase in car sales, GM's light truck sales were up 7.3 percent. GM's car and truck sales so far this year were running 5 percent behind last year's pace. Chrysler said its combined car and truck sales for early October were 10.8 percent lower than last year, with car sales rising 2.6 percent and truck sales dropping 26 percent. The company's vehicle sales so far this year were 14.6 percent behind last year's pace.

DOC.HEAD: They're Not Waking Up to Pepsi AM, Soft Drink Maker Finds
DOC.TEXT: After a year of test-marketing a high-caffeine soft drink, Pepsi-Cola Co. evidently has woken up and smelled the coffee. The No. 2 beverage maker behind Coca-Cola Co. says it has stopped testing its extra-kick Pepsi A.M., although Pepsi will continue to test a marketing strategy aimed at luring coffee drinkers to its regular cola in the morning. Pepsi-Cola had begun testing Pepsi A.M. in August 1989 in Waterloo, Iowa, but decided to discontinue the beverage this past August, company spokeswoman Leigh Curtin said Monday. There are no immediate plans to brink the drink back. ``What we found from the test was we didn't need to reformulate our product for consumers to enjoy it in the morning,'' Curtin said. Pepsi A.M. had about 25 percent more caffeine than regular Pepsi. The compny wanted to see if the added jolt would attract coffee drinkers, but sales proved slow and some Iowa consumers said the beverage tasted flat. While the test has ended, Pepsi has not given up on converting coffee drinkers to its soft drinks in the morning, said another Pepsi spokeswoman, Rebecca Madeira. She said a promotional test begun in August 1989 in Fort Wayne, Ind., is continuing using the slogan ``Pepsi in the Morning'' for its regular cola. Coca-Cola also has used periodic promotions in some markets that pitched its regular soft drinks for consumption in the morning. Industry experts say the percentage of soft drinks consumed in the morning has risen to 15 percent of all soda sales from 10 percent a decade ago, an important increase because each 1 percent share of the market represents more than $400 million in retail sales. Coffee consumption, meanwhile, has shown signs of declining, though it remains one of the prevalent wakeup beverages in the country. ``We think there is a lot of potential there to expand,'' Ms. Madeira said.

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Mixed At Four Major Banks
DOC.TEXT: A handful of the nation's largest banks announced mixed third-quarter earnings Monday, with No. 2-ranked Chase Manhattan reporting a huge loss while J.P. Morgan returned to profitability and Security Pacific's net declined. Banks continue to grapple with problem loans to less-developed countries as well as with a declining U.S. economy and deteriorating real estate holdings, each of which has taken a toll on balance sheets. Chase Manhattan Bank said it lost $623 million, or the equivalent of $5.03 a share in the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with a $1.11 billion loss, which equaled $12.45 a share, a year ago. Results for both the recent and year-ago quarters include the effects of several special items. Last month Chase said it would post a major loss as it set aside $650 million to cover potential losses from bad loans, particularly in the bank's domestic real estate portfolio. At the time Chase also announced it was eliminating 5,00 jobs and cutting its stock dividend in half in a restructuring designed to help the bank ``reach higher levels of capital.'' Chase said last month that it expects earnings in the final quarter to exceed $140 million. For the first nine months, Chase reported a loss of $527 million, or the equivalent of $4.74 a share, compared with a shortfall of $840 million, or $10.01 a share a year earlier. At New York-based J.P. Morgan & Co., net income totaled $208 million, or $1.08 a share for the quarter, compared with a loss of $1.82 billion, or the equivalent of $9.92 a share a year ago, when the company added $2 billion to its reserves to cover problem Third World loans. Morgan Chairman Dennis Weatherstone noted that ``trading results were excellent, net interest revenue was stronger and revenue from investment management and operational services continued to grow.'' Morgan is the nation's fourth-largest bank. For the first nine months, Morgan said net income totaled $814 million, or $4.23 a share, compared with a loss of $1.43 billion, or $7.87 a share in the equivalent 1989 period. Security Pacific Corp., headquartered in Los Angeles and the nation's fifth-largest bank, said net income for the third quarter slipped 27 percent to $135.3 million, or $1.05 a share, from $185.1 million, or $1.55 a share a year earlier. Security Pacific Chief Executive Robert H. Smith noted that the bank has taken a number of steps to ``fortify our balance sheet.'' Among them, the bank strengthened its reserve pool for loan losses and over the course of the year has added $5.7 billion in new core deposits through acquisitions and aggressive marketing, he said. For the nine-month period, the bank reported net income of $518.9 million, or $4.18 a share, down 5 percent from $548.9 million, or $4.67 a share in the 1989 period. At First Chicago Corp., the nation's 13th largest bank, net income for the quarter totaled $36.2 million, or 45 cents a share, compared with a loss of $23.3 million or 50 cents a share a year earlier. The Chicago-based holding company said the improved performance reflected a smaller provision for loan losses - $160 million versus $200 million a year earlier - and tax benefits associated with a 1987 net operating loss. Chairman Barry Sullivan said in a statement that ``we recognize that the near-term economic outlook is hostile and we are tightening our belts accordingly.'' For the first nine months of 1990, First Chicago reported net income of $192.2 million, or $2.60 per share, down 18 percent from $235.8 million, or $3.33 per share for the 1989 period.

DOC.HEAD: Harvest Weighs On Soybean, Corn Futures
DOC.TEXT: Harvest pressure helped push most grain and soybean futures prices lower Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Analysts said dry weekend weather in the Midwest allowed farmers to get back into their fields to resume the soybean and corn harvest, which was stalled by heavy rains early last week. More rain is forecast for the region later this week but coverage is expected to be light, said William Biedermann, grains analyst with the futures brokerage Allendale Inc. A National Weather Service outlook released on Friday predicted below-normal rainfall in the Midwest for the five-day period beginning Thursday. Analysts said the early dip in futures prices also reflected a reluctance by farmers to sell their crops at current prices. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent to 3 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.65{ a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 2} cents lower with December at $2.28 a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to } cent higher with December at $1.20 a bushel; soybeans were 6{ cents lower to 1} cents higher with November at $6.14 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Penn Central Considers Acquisition of Sister Insurance Companies
DOC.TEXT: The Penn Central Corp. said Monday it has offered $408 million to buy a group of non-standard automobile insurance companies from American Financial Corp. American Financial is privately owned by the Lindner family, and owns 41.6 percent of Penn Central's common shares. Carl H. Lindner is principal shareholder and chairman of American Financial, and is chief executive of Penn Central. The insurance group in the deal proposed Monday includes Atlanta Casualty Co., Windsor Insurance Co., Stonewall Insurance Co. and their subsidiaries. The companies had net premiums of $328 million and net income of $31.3 million last year, and an estimated shareholders' equity of $207 million on Sept. 30, Penn Central said. The sale requires approval of a committee of Penn Central directors and government regulators, among other conditions. Penn Central officials said they hoped it would be completed by the end of the year. Penn Central operates industrial manufacturing, defense service, insurance and energy businesses.

Stock prices showed some spotty gains today in a session of multiple changes of direction. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up about 12 points in the early going and down 16 points at midmorning, sported a 23.27 gain at 2,421.29 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers slightly outnumbered losers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 776 up, 720 down and 464 unchanged. DOC.HEAD: ABC Considering Cutbacks, Report Says
DOC.NOTE: EDS: NEW throughout to UPDATE with ABC comment; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The high cost of covering the Persian Gulf crisis and a sluggish national advertising market have prompted ABC News to consider cutting back its news operations. According to Monday's Wall Street Journal, the network is considering closing several bureaus and furloughing a small number of employees. While ABC is about to make major investments in a handful of foreign news bureaus, it is taking a hard look at reductions in domestic operations. ``If there is some movement in domestic bureaus, it will more a product of reorganization than cutbacks,'' said Sherrie Rollins, an ABC spokeswoman, when contacted for comment. She said it was ``premature'' to say whether a reorganization will result in a net loss of employees. ABC, a unit of Capital CitiesABC Inc., also decided not to proceed, at least temporarily, with a new overnight news broadcast that was scheduled to debut in January. Because of the cost of covering the Middle East crisis, ABC has trimmed its projection for an operating profit to $50 million this year, compared with $75 million that had been anticipated earlier, according to the Journal. ABC is the top-rated evening network newscast, which features Peter Jennings. Other major broadcast networks also are considering cuts. NBC News, owned by General Electric Co., said it was laying off 25 people and has held its 1991 budget to this year's levels.

DOC.HEAD: State Announces $100 Million Automaker Refund
DOC.TEXT: State Attorney General Robert Abrams on Monday announced a settlement with 12 car manufacturers that will provide up to $100 million in refunds to consumers. The settlement was reached under the state's ``lemon law'' and could set a precedent for other states, officials said. Abrams said he believes it to be the largest refund by automakers in the nation's history. The settlement will provide refunds for all New York residents who bought or leased new cars after Aug. 2, 1986, and have been forced to pay for repairs that should have been covered by warranty. The repairs must have been made after the manufacturer's basic warranty expired (normally during the first 12 months or 12,000 miles, whichever comes first), but before the first 24 months or 18,000 miles, or whichever comes first. The state's lemon law requires manufacturers and their dealers to make repairs under their warranty, at no cost to the customer, for a period of two years or 18,000 miles, whichever comes first. The carmakers who entered into the agreement are Chrysler, Ford, General Motors, Honda, Hyundai, Isuzu, Mazda, Mitsubishi, Nissan, Subaru, Toyota and Volvo. Each company also paid the state $10,000 in costs, for a total of $120,000. But they did not admit wrongdoing in signing the settlement. Some carmakers, such as Mercedes-Benz, were not included in the settlement because their warranty programs are broader than the state's lemon law, Abrams said. Abrams said the settlement was reached after a ``long-fought effort'' of four years to get the auto manufacturers to agree on the terms. Within the next month, the automakers will place advertisements in major New York newspapers detailing the refund plan. The ads will run for six weeks and consumers have 4{ months to respond. ``What happens in New York becomes very important to the rest of the nation and we may see other states taking a look at this,'' Abrams said. Since the state's lemon law was expanded in 1986, a record $60 million has been recovered on behalf of consumers, Abrams said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sees Long Convoluted Proceeding in Keating Case
DOC.TEXT: Charles Keating declared his innocence Monday before a preliminary hearing on charges the former chief of American Continental Corp. bilked investors out of more than $250 million. ``It's dangerous to be right when government is wrong,'' he told reporters outside the courtroom. His lawyer, Stephen Neal, asked to explain the comment, said: ``Mr. Keating is innocent. He believes in his innocence. He's confident that when the evidence is developed he will be vindicated.'' Keating, 66, remained jailed Monday on $5 million bail after Superior Court Judge Lance Ito set a tentative trial date of Nov. 26. Keating and three others are accused of defrauding investors with American Continental junk bonds sold through the now defunct Lincoln Savings and Loan. Experts place the cost of bailing out the failed California S&L at about $2 billion, making it the most expensive bailout. Keating, an Arizona developer, was chairman of Phoenix-based American Continental, which owned Lincoln. Also in court Monday were Keating's co-defendants, all of whom are free on bail. They are Ray C. Fidel, 32, former Lincoln president; Robin S. Symes, 37, former Lincoln chief executive officer; and Judy Wischer, 42, former American Continental president. Each of the four defendents is charged with 42 counts of fraud and could face up to 10 years in prison if convicted of six or more counts. Neal said he was still pursuing a bail reduction for Keating in federal court after losing similar bids in state appeals courts. The bespectacled Keating was permitted to change from his prison uniform into slacks and an open-collared beige shirt before entering the courtroom, where he listened to the proceedings with a slight smile. Ito scheduled a motions hearing Oct. 26. ``I expect this will be a long and convoluted discovery proceeding,'' the judge said.

Stock prices gained ground today, extending Friday's rally in an on-again, off-again session. Brokers said investors' spirits got a lift from declining oil prices. The figure came in toward the lower end of Wall Street estimates.

DOC.HEAD: Romania to Devalue Leu, Liberalize Prices; New Currency Seen
DOC.TEXT: Romania will devalue its national currency by almost half and lift subsidies on most consumer goods beginning Nov. 1, a government official said Monday. Economics Minister Eugen Dijmarescu said in an interview that the government had decided to devalue the Romanian leu from the current official rate of 20 to the dollar to 35 to the dollar. The government also plans to replace the leu with a new currency early next year, according to official sources. Romanians will be able to change their lei, still emblazoned with the Socialist emblems of Nicolae Ceausesacu's former dictatorship, for the as-yet-unnamed new currency at a rate of 10-to-one, the sources said. Officials said the measures should help the leu become fully convertible, help attract foreign investment, and help Romania's devastated economy adjust to free market practices after four decades of Communist central planning. The government also hopes the devaluation will stimulate exports and redress a spiralling trade deficit, observers said. Dijmarescu said the new measures will enable the leu to achieve convertibility ``sooner than initially thought possible.'' Western observers say at least three years will be needed for full convertibility. He said subsidies will be lifted Nov. 1 on most consumer goods. But prices of staples such as bread, meat, and electricity would remain fixed, to protect low wage earners from the inflationary effects of the liberalization package.

DOC.HEAD: Rates on Bills Nearly Unchanged at Auction
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities were virtually unchanged in Monday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $9.4 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.18 percent, down from 7.19 percent last week. Another $9.4 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.22 percent, up from 7.21 percent last week. The rates for three-month bills were the lowest since they sold for 7.18 percent on Oct. 1. Rates for six-month bills were the highest since they averaged 7.33 percent on Sept. 24. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.41 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,818.50, and 7.60 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,635.00. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 7.62 percent last week, up from 7.58 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Group: Five Top Insurance Companies in Shaky Condition
DOC.TEXT: A consumer group said Monday that five of the nation's top 20 property and casualty insurance companies would be threatened with insolvency in the event of a severe economic downturn. Spokesmen for four of the firms took issue with the report by the Ralph Nader organization Public Citizen and said the companies are healthy. Comment was not immediately available from the fifth firm. ``They either used the wrong facts or they got the wrong numbers,'' said Howard Smith, senior vice president and comptroller for the American International Group. In addition to AIG, the companies listed as potentially at risk were Aetna, the Hartford, Liberty Mutual and United States Fidelity & Guaranty. ``Although, during the present high phase of the insurance cycle, none of these companies are on the edge of insolvency, the underlying weakness in their financial condition is clearly evident,'' the consumer group said. Shawn Mooney, senior vice president of the Insurance Information Institute, called the study irresponsible. ``You can precipitate a run on a company by putting out statements that such and such a company is in bad financial shape,'' he said. Public Citizen president Joan Claybrook said she would not advse people holding policies with any of the companies to change to another insurer. But she said they should write to their companies and urge corrective action. The study analyzed six factors that it said could cause companies to fail during a downturn in the insurance business. It said the five companies were each vulnerable to four of the factors. The 124-page report analyzed shrinking surpluses, the ratio of surplus to losses and unusually wide premium swings over the years 1969 to 1988. Three short-term factors were also examined: the amount of risk the company insures compared with the size of its cushion against unexpected losses, the degree to which its investments could be converted into cash, and the extent of its investment in high-risk junk bonds. Joyce Willis, a spokeswoman for the Hartford Insurance Group, said Hartford rates high in assessments by credible agencies. ``It would surprise me that suddenly someone else could come in and use what appear to be similar criteria and announce that we are vulnerable,'' she said. Ms. Claybrook said Public Citizen believes the standards used by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, a commonly accepted rating group for insurers, ``are not tough enough.'' Her group's report said a combination of low premium volume, high claims and weak return on investment could mean potential financial trouble for the companies. It said all of these factors occur during an insurance cycle downturn. ``The failure of just one insurance giant would overwhelm the state funds designed to protect policyholders,'' Ms. Claybrook said. ``The result could be another taxpayer bailout on the model of the savings and loan industry.'' Smith of AIG said he was ``flabbergasted'' that his institution would be considered vulnerable. He said AIG had a 17 percent return on equity in last year's annual report plus the highest premium volume of any commercial writer in the country, and ``our cash flow continues to be exceptionally strong.'' Jonathan Powell, a spokesman for Aetna, called the five firms named by Public Citizen ``very strong companies'' and said he was astounded that the consumer group would find otherwise. Whit Lancaster, manager of corporate communications for Liberty Mutual, labeled the report ``absurd and reckless.'' Other firms included in the survey were Allstate, CignaINA, Chubb, CNA, Continental, Crum & Forster, Farmers, Fireman's Fund, Kemper, Lincoln, Nationwide, St. Paul, State Farm, Travelers and USAA. Only Allstate and State Farm failed to register any of the potential danger signals, the study said. Public Citizen recommended several steps to ease the problems it found. Among them are repeal of the McCarran-Ferguson Act that exempts insurers from anti-trust laws; use of the Racketeer Influence and Corrupt Organizations law to prosecute fraud and wrongdoing by insurance executives; use of more insurance tax dollars for regulation; and a yearly federal report on the effectiveness of state regulation.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Companies Suffer Effects of Higher Crude Prices
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil price hikes hampered third-quarter growth in the chemical industry - a situation analysts say will worsen by the end of the year. Third-quarter earnings are not yet out, but chemical company stock prices have taken a beating because crude oil prices have nearly doubled since the Persian Gulf east crisis began. Companies with large chemical units like Exxon Corp., Chevron Corp., Mobil Corp. and E.I. Du Pont de Nemours & Co., which owns Conoco, will offset their chemical earnings squeezes with higher profits from crude oil sales. But companies that focus on chemicals have no crude-oil profit buffer. Makers of chemicals used in making a variety of plastics will be hit the worst, analysts say, because oil represents a large portion of their costs. ``If conditions stay as they are, it's bound to be worse in the fourth quarter'' because a recession will follow, said analyst Leslie C. Ravitz with Salomon Brothers in New York. Companies that buy commodity chemicals and further refine them to make plastics are a little more insulated because a relatively smaller portion of their feedstock cost is directly related to the price of oil, analysts say. ``Feedstock prices have gone up more quickly than product prices,'' said Earl Armstrong, a consultant for DeWitt & Co., a Houston consulting firm that specializes in the chemical industry. Armstrong said prices for some refined products began catching up with the higher costs this month. But most companies were forced to swallow the higher costs during the first month of the oil increase because of price protection clauses in supply agreements that require them to give manufacturers 30 days' notice of an increase. ``Everybody got hurt pretty badly on the time lag,'' Armstrong said.

DOC.HEAD: Polaroid's Third Quarter Earnings Up
DOC.TEXT: Polaroid Corp. reported Monday that its third quarter earnings increased 5 percent over last year, aided by strong international sales gains. The firm said net earnings for the quarter were $31.3 million, compared with $29.9 million for the same period last year. Total sales increased 6 percent in the quarter to $463.7 million, compared to $437.7 million last year. The earnings report followed news on Friday that U.S. District Judge A. David Mazzone had ordered Eastman Kodak Co. to pay Polaroid $909.5 million in damages and interest for infringing on seven Polaroid patents. Mazzone said the infringement was not willful and declined to award the $12 billion Polaroid had sought in punitive damages. U.S. sales were down 6 percent for the quarter ending Sept. 30, while international sales increased 27 percent. The firm attributed the gains to strong international sales, aided by a weaker dollar. Higher unit sales also contributed to the increased margins, but were offset by higher marketing costs, resulting in a 5 percent drop in operating profit, the firm said. But profit before taxes increased due to lower interest expense. I. MacAllister Booth, president and chief executive officer, said in a statement the firm remained ``committed to making the marketing, product development and capital expenditures necessary to support sales and to secure our competitive position in the growing imaging marketplace of the future.'' The third quarter earnings reflected those investments, Booth said. For 1990 operating profits were expected to be flat or slightly down from last year, reflecting the uncertainties of the U.S. business climate and continued investments in product development, Booth said. Polaroid supplies instant photography, cameras and films, as well as conventional films, videotapes and electronic visual communication products to family, business and technical and industrial markets.
