DOC.HEAD: Gold Prices Plummet, Dollar Mostly Higher
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices fell more than $12 Monday, driven by a drop in the price of oil and by rumors of a negotiated settlement in the Middle East. The dollar finished higher against all major currencies except the Japanese yen. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery fell $12.50 to settle at $375 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $375.70, down $12.30 from late Friday. Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat met with Saddam Hussein on Sunday and said later that the Iraqi president was showing a ``certain flexibility'' regarding his claims to Kuwait. Iraq on Monday denied it was softening its stance, but traders said the news from the Middle East helped drive down the price of gold. Also affecting prices was the energy futures market, where the near-term contract for oil settled at $37.95 a barrel, down $1.74 from Friday. Gold also fell in dealings overseas. In London it dropped to a late bid of $379.75 a troy ounce, down from $388.15 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $379.50, down from $388.00 bid late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, the metal fell $2.68 to close at a bid $385.08. In New York, the dollar finished up against most major currencies, after also rising overseas. One British pound fetched $1.9498, less expensive than $1.9675 on Friday. In London, the pound fell to $1.9545 from $1.9740. However, the dollar fell against the yen across the board. It closed in New York at 127.73 yen, down from 129.05 Friday. In Tokyo, it fell to a closing 128.83 yen from 129.98 yen Friday. Later, in London, it fel to 128.05 yen. ``Most of the activity was in cross trading with movement out of high-yielding currencies ... and movement mostly into yen,'' said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer with Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago. Holzer said traders moved out of Australian dollars after the country lowered interest rates. Other selected late dollar rates in New York compared with late Friday rates included: 1.5262 German marks, up from 1.5243; 1.2905 Swiss francs, up from 1.2860; 5.1120 French francs, up from 5.1055; 1,143.00 Italian lire, up from 1,142.25; and 1.1540 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1471. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday included: 1.5230 German marks, up from 1.5175; 1.2870 Swiss francs, up from 1.2780; 5.1035 French francs, up from 5.0555; 1.7165 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7110; 1,141.50 Italian lire, up from 1,137.25; 1.1520 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1470. Silver bullion for current delivery slipped to settle at $4.132 a troy ounce, down from $4.306 Friday. In London, silver fell to a late bid price of $4.22 a troy ounce, down from $4.34 bid late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Decline In Calmer Market
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices declined in active but calm trading Monday as the market sensed some easing of tensions in the Persian Gulf. A drop in refinery demand for crude oil contributed to the slide. The November contract for delivery of light sweet crude fell $1.74 to $37.95 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange after dropping 73 cents on Friday. Analysts said trading was influenced by a Soviet report that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein might be willing to withdraw his troops from Kuwait in return for some Kuwaiti land bordering the Persian Gulf. Peter Beutel, an oil market analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., said the market believed tensions were lessening somewhat. If that is the case, the likelihood of war would be reduced, and so would a cutoff in oil supplies from the Gulf. However, the situation in the Gulf and the market remained touch-and-go. ``Tomorrow morning may be a completely different story,'' Beutel warned. Abundant supplies of crude oil and refined products also helped bring prices down Monday. The November contract for home heating oil tumbled 3.29 cents to $1.0207 a gallon, while wholesale unleaded regular gasoline slipped 2.18 cents to 94.95 cents a gallon. Both contracts advanced on Friday. Refiners are currently retooling their equipment to turn out more heating oil and less gasoline for the winter months. This seasonal lull reduces the need for crude, and with traders feeling more optimistic about the Middle East situation, allows supply-and-demand forces to have an impact on trading. Beutel said technical forces were also at work in the market Monday. Under current conditions, refiners are not willing to pay $40 and more per barrel for oil, and are balking at the higher prices, he said. In natural gas trading, the November contract closed at $1.900 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.950 on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Precious Metal Debacle: Gold, Silver, Platinum Plummet
DOC.TEXT: Silver prices hit new 14-year lows Monday and gold plunged to its lowest level since before Iraq invaded Kuwait, reflecting new hopes for peace in the Middle East and skepticism in the investment value of precious mtals. On other commodity markets, oil futures fell; near-term orange juice rebounded; grains and soybeans were lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $12.50 to $14.20 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for spot delivery at $375 an ounce, the lowest spot gold price since Aug. 1. Silver futures ended 17.4 cents to 19.9 cents lower on the Comex with October at $4.132 a troy ounce. Platinum plunged $22.80 to $23 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where the October contract ended at $394.10 a troy ounce, platinum's first drop below $400 since early 1986. Analysts said the sell-off was partly triggered by a sharp drop in petroleum prices that was in turn prompted by a Soviet press report that Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein might withdraw his troops from Kuwait in exchange for some Kuwaiti territory on the Persian Gulf. But analysts said the slide in gold, silver and platinum also was an indication that more and more investors no longer view precious metals as desirable assets in times of economic and political uncertainty. Although the market is not following its traditional path, ``it's hard to imagine a scenario more bullish'' for precious metals than the current situation, said Frederick Demler, metals analyst at PaineWebber Inc. ``Ten years ago we would have seen gold at $500 or $600,'' he said. Analyst William O'Neill of Merrill Lynch Futures said gold- and platinum-producing countries such as the Soviet Union and South Africa were heavy sellers of those metals Monday. Monday's lower oil prices also were linked to expectations that U.S. consumption of crude oil has begun to weaken on a seasonal basis as refineries retool to produce more heating oil and less gasoline, said Peter Beutel, energy analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group of Hoboken, N.J. Light sweet crude oil futures settled 57 cents to $1.74 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with November at $37.95 a barrel; heating oil was 2.17 cents to 3.29 cents lower with November at $1.0207 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.55 cents to 2.7 cents lower with November at 94.95 cents a gallon. Frozen concentrated orange juice for November delivery rose 4.5 cents to $1.1795 a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange, rebounding from a loss of 16.45 cents Friday. All other orange juice contracts fell their permitted daily limit of 5 cents, though, in a continued reaction to a government report that predicted a bumper Florida orange crop. Harvest pressure helped push most grain and soybean futures prices lower Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Analysts said dry weekend weather in the Midwest allowed farmers to get back into their fields to resume the soybean and corn harvest, which was stalled by heavy rains early last week. An Agriculture Department report released after the close showed the soybean harvest 40 percent complete and the corn harvest 32 percent complete as of Sunday. The progress rate was below average for both crops. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent to 3 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.65{ a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 2} cents lower with December at $2.28 a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to } cent higher with December at $1.20 a bushel; soybeans were 6{ cents lower to 1} cents higher with November at $6.14 a bushel. Cattle futures finished narrowly mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures ended mostly lower, led by the pork belly market, which erased limit gains amid expectations for sharply lower cash prices next week. Live cattle settled .03 cent lower to .13 cent higher with October at 78.97 cents a pound; feederccattle were .30 cent lower to .15 cent higher with October at 87.32 cents a pound; live hogs were .63 cent lower to .68 cent higher with October at 58.30 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .80 cent to 1.77 cents lower with February at 65.42 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Rise Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Government bond prices closed slightly higher Monday after a listless session. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond gained 7-32 point, or $2.19 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, slipped to 8.93 percent from 8.95 percent late Friday. ``It has been an extraordinarily quiet day,'' said Susan Hering, a Treasury bond economist at Salomon Brothers Inc. Government bond prices rose slightly when the market opened after rising overseas, then slipped slightly and remained at virtually the same level the rest of the day. Ms. Hering said the market had almost no reaction to news that auto sales dropped 4.8 percent in the first 10 days of October. ``I think people were expecting them to be weak, so that diffused the impact,'' she said. Often, a sign of growing economic weakness boosts bond prices because it makes it more likely the Federal Reserve will ease interest rates. A dip in oil prices also had little impact, she added. Usually, bond prices rise on signs that inflationary pressures may be easing. Inflation is a major concern of bond investors since it devalues the fixed-return securities. Ms. Hering said she believed bond investors were awaiting the results of the ongoing budget negotiations in Washington and the release Thursday of September consumer price figures. Also Monday, interest rates on short-term Treasury securities sold at auction were virtually unchanged. The Treasury sold $9.4 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.18 percent, down from 7.19 percent last week. Another $9.4 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.22 percent, up from 7.21 percent last week. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments were unchanged to 3-32 point higher, intermediate maturities rose from 1-16 point to 5-32 point, and long-term issues were up as much as 7-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 1.23 to 1,147.99. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 7.37 percent as the discount rose 2 basis points to 7.16 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 7.54 percent as the discount rate rose 4 basis points to 7.18 percent. Yields on one-year bills remained at 7.56 percent as the discount stood at 7.08 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 percent, up from 7~ percent late Friday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 88 1-32, up 3-32 from Friday. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.83 percent from 7.84 percent.

DOC.HEAD: IBM's Profit Jumps 27 Percent, NCR's Slips
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Revenue at ...,' to CORRECT revenue figure to $15.28 billion sted $15.8 billion.
DOC.HEAD: With BC-IBM-Glance, BC-NCR-Glance
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: IBM said Monday its third-quarter profit jumped almost 27 percent despite the economic downturn and persistent sluggishness in the computer industry. However, Wall Street did not cheer the news and sent IBM's stock price down $1 to close at $99.25 in New York Stock Exchange trading. ``From what had been anticipated this was on the low side,'' analyst Stephen Cohen of SoundView Finanical Group Inc. in Stamford., Conn., said of the earnings. International Business Machines Corp. said profit for the three months ended Sept. 30 totaled $1.11 billion, or $1.95 a share, up from $877 million, or $1.51 a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue at the world's largest computer company rose nearly 7 percent to $15.28 billion, from $14.30 billion in the year-ago period. Analysts expressed concern partly because IBM declined to say how much its results benefited from the lower value of the dollar during the quarter. IBM derives more than half its revenue and profit outside the United States. A weaker dollar means overseas sales translate into better results in dollar terms. Because of this, analysts want to know whether the benefits of the weaker dollar are masking any underlying trouble. In a conference call with analysts, IBM said it gained from the dollar's decline but would not elaborate. Cohen estimated the boost amounted to 30 cents out of the $1.95 in per-share earnings. In addition, about 5 cents came from lower federal tax rates this year. With this in mind, he said, ``1.95 does not look like that big a number.'' IBM's product sales slipped 1.5 percent to $9.01 billion, but revenue from support services, software, equipment rental and financing posted double-digit increases over the year-earlier quarter. IBM, based in suburban Armonk, told analysts that sales of personal computers were unchanged during the third quarter. While this came as little surprise, analysts said it presented one more worry as the economy declines. IBM also told analysts that revenue from mainframe computers was not as robust as other products because of the transition to the new System-390 mainframe line, announced in September. IBM said it hasn't been able to meet demand for the powerful, new-generation machines, crimping revenue, said John Jones, an analyst at Montgomery Securities Inc. in San Francisco. Jones called the decline in IBM's stock price a ``bear-market knee jerk.'' ``Some people may have hoped that IBM would come through with a big surprise,'' he said. In a statement, IBM Chairman John F. Akers said the company was seeing the benefits of a cost-cutting plan announced late last year. The restructuring, which includes the elimination of about 10,000 jobs and plant consolidations, was prompted by the computer industry slowdown. ``Our portfolio of products and services, which is the strongest in our history, and our geographic diversity are serving us well,'' Akers said. ``Assuming no further deterioration in the world's economies, we continue to expect substantially improved financial performance for 1990.'' For the year's first nine months, IBM reported a profit of $3.56 billion, or $6.21 a share, up 12 percent from $3.17 billion, or $5.43 a share in the 1989 period. Revenue for the nine months totaled $46.0 billion, up almost 9percent from $42.2 billion in the same period a year earlier. Meanwhile Monday, NCR Corp., another major computer maker, said profit slipped 3 percent in the third quarter due to a share-repurchase program. NCR, based in Dayton, Ohio, said it earned $91 million, or $1.36 a share, down from from $94 million, or $1.23 a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue rose 9 percent to a record $1.52 billion, from $1.39 billion a year earlier. NCR said it repurchased 2.2 million common shares during the quarter under a continuing stock buyback program. That increased earnings per share while decreasing net income, it said. For the first nine months, profit was $258 million, or $3.73 a share, a 3 percent decrease from $265 million, or $3.40 a share, a year earlier. Revenue increased 5 percent to $4.39 billion from last year's $4.17 billion. Charles E. Exley Jr., NCR's chairman and chief executive, said the company didn't expect profit to increase for the entire year due to disappointing domestic orders in the second and third quarters.

DOC.HEAD: United's Parent Places Order with Boeing Worth Up to $22 Billion
LaserPhotos CX6, SE2
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines announced plans Monday to buy as many as 128 new Boeing aircraft to rejuvenate and expand its fleet in an order worth at least $11 billion and potentially a record $22 billion or more. The deal includes Boeing's new 777 model, the first-ever order for that plane, and represented a significant coup for Boeing over its leading competitors, McDonnell Douglas Corp. and Airbus Industrie of Europe. It also came a week after a protracted employee effort to buy United failed, and seemed to signify an attempt by one of the nation's leading airlines to refocus attention on its long-term competitive position. ``This purchase will allow United to replace older aircraft as well as expand both its domestic and international services,'' said Stephen Wolf, chairman of Chicago-based UAL Corp., United's parent company. ``In short, it will ensure that this company is positioned to compete aggressively around the world,'' Wolf said, The agreement includes firm orders for 34 Boeing model 777s and 30 Boeing 747-400s, with a total value of about $11 billion. In addition, United has the option to purchase an additional 34 model 777s and 30 model 747-400s. If all those options were excercised, the total value of the purchase would swell to at least $22 billion and make it the largest order in history. For United customers, Wolf said, the order means ``more service to more destinations in the world's newest, most modern and efficient aircraft.'' ``For our shareholders, it means more revenue growth'' to be reflected in increased shareholder value. Wolf declined to discuss plans for financing the order. But he said it wouldn't affect employee contract negotiations. ``We don't intend to ask them to make concessons to pay for the fleet,'' he said. ``We anticipate raises.'' Wolf said the expansion ``provides a sense of security'' for United's 74,000 employees. United said it chose Pratt & Whitney 4000 engines to power the aircraft. Assembly on the 777s is to start in late 1992. As they are delivered, United said, they will replace the company's DC-10 aircraft on domestic routes and provide expansion capacity. Delivery of the 747-400 aircraft would start in 1994. A number of 747-400s from a previous order are expected before that and will be used for continued expansion of United's international market. Wolf said the company would more than double its service to Europe in 1991 by adding destinations. A large United purchase had been expected for some time, although the uncertainty of the buyout negotiations with employees had raised questions about the timing and size. It was well known throughout the industry that Boeing, Airbus and McDonnell Douglas were competing aggressively for the order. ``The importance of today's commitment for Boeing cannot be overstated,'' Frank Shrontz, Boeing's chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement from the aircraft maker's Seattle headquarters. ``With a ratification by Boeing's board on Oct. 29, this order will launch an all-new 777 aircraft family - which will set a new standard for very large twin-engine operations around the world.'' Boeing Commercial Airplane Group spokesman Richard Schleh said the 777, designed to fill a market niche between the 747-400 and the existing 767-300 wide-body, will be 209 feet long and have a wingspan of 197 feet. United's 777s will seat 363 passengers. Boeing plans to build the 777 at its Everett, Wash., wide-body plant north of Seattle, Schleh said. It now has about 3,400 employees working on the plane. Shrontz said the buildup in the 777 program will mean 8,000 to 10,000 jobs. But not all will be new jobs, he said, because some will come from other company operations. Like other leading airlines, United has been seeking to replenish its fleet with younger airplanes that are more fuel efficient and require less costly maintenance than their aging predecessors. The latest order is United's third in 18 months. United's last aircraft order, for 370 narrow-body Boeing jetliners, was in April 1989. UAL spokeswoman Sara Dornacker said the average age of United's fleet was 12.7 years at the end of August compared with 13.6 years a year earlier. The largest order in the industry, excluding options to purchase aircraft, is $16.8 billion, made in April 1989 by an Ireland-based aircraft leasing company, GPA Group Ltd. It ordered a total of 308 planes from Boeing, Airbus Industrie and McDonnell Douglas. United had come close to placing its wide-body aircraft order earlier this year but postponed the plans in July at the request of UAL's unions, which were then still in the midst of leading an attempt to buy the airline. Last week, the employees failed to get bank financing for a $4.4 billion bid, prompting UAL's board to reject their offer.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Computer Introduces New Lower-Priced Macintoshes
DOC.TEXT: As expected, Apple Computer Inc. on Monday unveiled a lower-cost line of its popular Macintosh machines, tempting consumers but worrying investors and dealers. Apple priced the Macintosh Classic at about $1,000, the Macintosh LC at $2,500 and the Macintosh IIsi starting at about $3,800. However, shoppers can expect better deals after retailers discount the products, experts say. ``We are prepared to do whatever it takes to reach more people with Macintosh,'' said Brodie Keast, an Apple product marketing manager. ``The plan is to get as aggressive on price as we need to be.'' Analysts said the strategy will work only if the Cupertino-based company sells enough computers to offset the smaller profit margins on them. The risks are making investors jittery that Apple won't be able to make changes necessary to thrive on lower margins. Apple's stock closed Monday at $27.75 a share in national over-the-counter trading, down 50 cents from Friday and well off its 12-month high of $50.37{. The new computers, unveiled at Apple's factory in Fremont, also are raising concerns among Apple's 1,700 authorized dealers. They worry that they ultimately will lose business if Apple, in its effort to boost sales, recruits more dealers or sells through retail outlets previously shunned, analysts said. ``Clearly, this is something Apple is evaluating,'' said Walter J. Winnitzki, an analyst for the brokerage firm Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. in New York. The base Macintosh Classic, available immediately, comes with 1 megabyte of memory and a floppy disk drive. Another version for about $500 more offers 2 megabytes of memory and a 40-megabyte hard disk drive. Both versions feature the processor and black-and-white video screen in a single unit. The Macintosh LC comes with 2 megabytes of memory and a 40-megabyte hard dis drive. It will be available in limited numbers until January, when production is stepped up. The Macintosh IIsi, a lower-cost version of Apple's more powerful business computers, is available immediately. Both the LC and IIsi models are available with either black-and-white or color screens. ``To reach new customers, we didn't just lower the prices of our existing products. We redesigned these computers from the ground up with the features customers have told us they value most,'' said John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive officer.

DOC.HEAD: Pilots Association Launches Campaign To Improve Pilots' Image
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts in 1st, 4th grafs to reflect claim that campaign is long planned. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Air Line Pilots Association is opening a long-planned television and radio campaign to burnish its members' professional image in the immediate aftermath of the conviction of three pilots for flying while drunk. The campaign theme: ``Safety is a daily commitment.'' The $250,000 cost to buy air time for the commercials was paid for by individual contributions from 2,500 pilots, said Capt. Henry Duffy, president of the association that's also the pilots' labor union. Although the advertising campaign was conceived two years ago, it follows widespread negative publicity from the arrest and conviction of three Northwest Airline pilots for intoxication while flying. One of them testified he had consumed up to 20 rum and Diet Cokes at a lounge the night before piloting a flight from Fargo, N.D. to Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport. ``We go quickly by 19,000 successes and focus on an occasional slip,'' Duffy said, referring to the number of flights safely concluded each day in the United States. ``Pilots have the feeling that there is no understanding of how much training they undergo, of how many checks they are subject to and how many physicals they've had to take,'' he said. ``I think any time the media focuses on some negative aspect of the aviation industry there are going to be questions in the public mind,'' Duffy said. ``We want to balance that with the high level of competence in the cockpits.'' Duffy said the association's ``image enhancement campaign'' was prompted by concerns expressed by many of the 42,000 pilots who belong to the association. ``Pilots themselves aren't at all good in being their own PR agents,'' Duffy said. ``No matter how skillful a feat of airmanship a pilot performs, you'll usually only hear him or her say, ``I was just doing my job.'' The television commercial will be aired 150 times on CNN Headline News from Oct. 22 to Nov. 18. and is aimed, Duffy said, at business travelers, ``our key target audience.'' It also will be shown on the late evening news in Miami, Chicago, Minneapolis, Pittsburgh and Atlanta. The radio commercial will be broadcast beginning the week of Oct. 22 with sponsorship of games 4, 5 and 6 of the World Series on the CBS Radio Network. It also will be aired on the Mutual Radio Network during college and professional football shows, talk shows and news reports. The 30-second television commercial cuts from the cockpit where the crew calmly carries out its duties to the cabin where a little girl plays with a teddy bear and naps. The narrator: ``More than a million people rely on us every day. It takes experience, ability and dedication to be a professional airline pilot.''

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Launches 777, Its First All-New Aircraft in 12 Years
DOC.TEXT: A huge order Monday from United Airlines gave The Boeing Co. the go-ahead for its new 777 jetliner, a plane Boeing hopes will be the basis of a new, high-tech family of aircraft for the early 21st century. The twin-engine plane, slightly smaller than a 747 jumbo jet, is the first all-new aircraft to be launched by Boeing since 1978. To build the jet, Boeing plans to add as many as 6,500 more jobs in the Seattle area over the next four years. United ordered 34 of the jets and took options on another 34 as part of a 128-plane order potentially worth more than $22 billion. United also bought 30 Boeing 747-400s and optioned 30 more in what would be the largest commercial aircraft purchase in history if all options are exercised. At a news conference, Chris Longridge, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group executive vice president for sales, called the order ``mind-boggling.'' The total value of all Boeing's announced orders in 1987 was $19.9 billion, a company record at the time, he noted. Longridge said Boeing already is talking about building a ``family'' of 777 aircraft and has proposed a version that could haul 300-320 people up to 7,600 miles. The next logical step would be a stretch version to carry more than 400 passengers, Longridge said, adding that ``some operators have been talking to us about that.'' Boeing designed the 777 to fill a market niche between its 767-300 and 747 widebodies. It's big. It will seat 360-390 passengers in two classes, compared to a 747-400, which holds 412 people in three classes. At 209 feet, the 777wwill be about 23 feet shorter than a 747. But its body will be 2 inches wider at 20 feet, 4 inches, and its 197-foot wingspan 2 feet more than the jumbo jet's. Each engine will be 20 percent more powerful than those of a 747 and large enough to swallow the body of a mid-sized jetliner. The most visible change from previous models will be the folding wingtips that will allow the jet to use airport gates now used by mid-sized planes. But the plane will have an all-new wing and fuel-stingy engines that Alan Mulally, vice president of engineering for Boeing's New Airplane Division, says will make it 30 percent to 40 percent more fuel-efficent than existing DC-10s and L-1011s. To save weight, the plane will make extensive use of composite materials rather than metal. Airlines today order jets 10 years in advance and expect to fly them another 20 years after that. For that reason, Mulally said Boeing's potential customers wanted the 777 design to be as flexible as possible. The 777 will be plumbed and wired to allow galleys and lavatories for different seating patterns. Seats can be placed anywhere from five to 10 abreast. The 777 will have a range of up to 4,800 statute miles. That compares with the long-range 767-300, which can carry 261 passengers in mixed classes 7,200 miles, and the 747-400, the world's largest commercial jet, which can fly 8,000 miles. Three Japanese companies - Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries - will build large portions of the plane's fuselage. The companies also build part of the 767. Longridge said the 777 program eventually will employ 8,000 to 10,000 people, with assembly at Boeing's Everett widebody plant. About 3,400 are working on it now. Boeing, which has about 100,000 workers in the Seattle area, has been trimming its workforce and the new jobs could offset that somewhat, he said. Although it's introduced several variations of existing models, the last all-new planes Boeing brought out were the mid-sized 757 and the 767 in 1978. United and Boeing struck their deal Sunday night, Longridge said, after the airline heard last-minute presentations by Boeing and competitors McDonnell Douglas Corp. and Airbus Industrie. United long was rumored to be the initial 777 customer. The company postponed its order last July at the request of its unions, which were making an ultimately unsuccessful attempt to buy the carrier. Longridge said Boeing is discussing possible 777 sales with American Airlines, Delta Airlines, Cathay Pacific, British Airways, Qantas, Japan Air Lines and All Nippon Airways. He said it's likely All Nippon could make its decision within the next few weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Strikes Down $500 Million Bond Approval for PSNH Takeover
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Monday struck down state approval for Northeast Utilities to issue $500 million in bonds to help pay for its $2.3 billion takeover of bankrupt Public Service Company of New Hampshire. Merrimack County Superior Court Judge Kenneth McHugh said approval of the bonds by the state Industrial Development Authority, Gov. Judd Gregg and the Executive Council was ``arbitrary, unreasonable and capricious.'' He ordered the IDA to hold a public hearing on the bond application. The state is reviewing the ruling and has not decided whether to appeal. McHugh issued his ruling on a complaint by the Campaign for Ratepayer's Rights, which has opposed the Seabrook nuclear plant built by Public Service and has fought electricity rate hikes planned to help pay for the $6.6 billion plant. The Executive Council, which is elected to review certain appropriations, approved the pollution-control bonds 5-0 several weeks ago on recommendation of the IDA. The bonds, half of which are tax exempt, are among a number of bond issues Northeast Utilities, of Berlin, Conn., planned to use to finance its friendly takeover of PSNH. McHugh earlier rejected as premature a petition by the Campaign and others to block the bonds. But he said the court would review their claims before the bonds are issued. McHugh ruled only on whether the public had been given a proper chance to participate in the IDA decision. Utility and authority officials denied the allegation. They said they had reviewed the process carefully and were confident of its legality.

DOC.HEAD: CAW, Chrysler Open Talks
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian Auto Workers union prepared to open contract talks with Chrysler Canada Ltd. on Monday after reaching new contracts with Canadian subsidiaries of General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. The union represents about 10,000 Chrysler workers in Canada. In the United States, Chrysler Canada's parent company, Chrysler Corp., is negotiating with the United Auto Workers for a new national agreement covering about 63,000 workers in what could be tough talks. ``The company has made a lot of money in Canada,'' CAW spokesman Larry Bauer said. ``If we listened to them every time they pleaded poverty, we'd be making $2 an hour.'' Chyrsler's unionized Canadian workers currently make more than $17 an hour. The CAW, like the UAW, expects to sign very similar agreements with each of the Big Three automakers. The CAW's contracts with Ford and GM Canadian subsidiaries call for annual wage increases of 7.5 percent, 6.7 percent and 4.8 percent in each of the three years of the contract. In the United States, the pattern agreement reached with GM and Ford provides for a 3-percent wage increase in the first year and lump-sum payments equal to 3 percent of wages in the second and third years. Chrysler Canada spokesman Lois McTavish said it was irrelevant to compare the company's contract talks with negotiations under way in the United States. ``There are two completely independent, separate sets of negotiations, issues and unions,'' McTavish said. ``And we'll have to wait and see if we'll agree to a contract similar to Ford's and GM's.''

DOC.HEAD: Winnebago Reports Record Loss for Fiscal Year, 5th Straight Quarterly Loss
DOC.TEXT: Winnebago Industries Inc.'s bottom line improved in the most recent quarter, but the motor home company still had a $3.8 million loss on sagging sales. The market for recreational vehicles has been sent into a tailspin by soaring gasoline prices and fears of a recession, a combination that leaves consumers reluctant to spend $27,000 and up on a motor home. The quarterly loss was Winnebago's fifth consecutive. The company recently offered gasoline rebates to new customers in an attempt to revive its slumping business. Winnebago's loss in the quarter ended Aug. 25 came to 15 cents a share, compared with a loss of almost $11.3 million, or 46 cents a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenue slipped 4 percent to $85.9 million from $89.5 million. For the full fiscal year, the loss came to $17.8 million, or 72 cents a share, and surpassed the previous record loss of $13.5 million in fiscal 1980, another period when gas prices soared and the economy contracted. A year ago, Winnebago had a loss of almost $4.7 million, or 19 cents a share. Revenue fell 23.4 percent on the year to $335.1 million from $437.5 million. Winnebago makes recreational and commercial vehicles and its Cycle-Sat subsidiary delivers television commercials by satellite. The fourth fiscal quarter loss was aggravated by a settlement of an Internal Revenue Service audit that increased the net loss by $2.3 million, said Fred Dohrmann, Winnebago's chief operating officer. Results for the fiscal year were hurt by reduced sales volume for recreational vehicles and operating losses at the company's new commercial vehicle business and at Cycle-Sat, Dohrmann said. But he said the company had operating income from its recreational vehicle division in the fourth quarter of the fiscal year. Winnebago said it has been able to substantially increase sales volume of the Winnebago Warrior and Itasca Spirit micro-mini motor homes. In an attempt to reassure customers spooked at the gas pump, Winnebago last week guaranteed to rebate gasoline expenses above 99.9 cents a gallon for new motor homes purchased through the end of the year. The rebates will be in effect for 12 months or 12,000 miles, whichever comes first. Winnebago also laid off 1,500 workers at Forest City at the end of last month because of high inventories of unsold recreational vehicles. On Monday, it called back 1,000 workers, but said there were no plans yet to bring back the remaining 500 idled workers.
